story:
Summary

In an act of dedication to our art, 30 actors have come together at the University of Northern Illinois to study under the tutelage of Master teachers such as Kathryn Gately, Richard Poole, Deborah Robertson, Stanton Davis, Patricia Skarbinski and Alex Gelman. Techniques from Sanford Meisner, Catherine Fitzmaurice, Michael Chekhov, Stanislavsky and Loyd Williamson have been lovingly and carefully drawn from to harness each actor’s individual talents. The result? 30 Artists were born. Now, as graduation approaches and the real world awaits, we artists desire integration into the professional film and theatrical worlds. We desire to become an integral part of this country's artistic community and we need your help. Support the actors at NIU as they strive to bring their artistry to a larger audience. Help them propel their careers and honor the lineage of their training. 

Breaking It Down

Our goal now is to infiltrate the artistic communities with the great theatrical lineage that has been generously passed down to us. We feel a duty to continue creating and inspiring. We each have a distinct artistic voice, and we hope to let those voices be heard. What we need HELP with is our integration into the professional artistic communities. That is the purpose of our Showcase Reels. We need tools by which to open the sometimes-exclusive gates of the professional theater and film industries. 

The Cost

The cost of filming two scenes each for 30 actors is $18,000. Our group is in a fundraising frenzy and hopes to earn 1/3 of the money through Holiday shows, Cabarets, Bake sales, Trivia Nights, etc. (to stay up on these events visit our facebook page http://www.facebook.com/NIUactors2013) but we need your support to make our final goal. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you can't afford to contribut financially, please help us by forwarding this link to friends and family and by attending our upcoming fundraisers! We are grateful for any support you can give.

story:
We at LAStheatre are raising funds for the second show in The Enlightenment Cafe series - Deadinburgh.

 

Deadinburgh

An unknown pathogen ravages Scotland’s capital, turning the unlucky souls into bloodthirsty ambling beasts. You are one of the last uninfected citizens in a city under martial law, cut off from the rest of the UK.

Now, with help from real scientists, you have only hours to decide how to save Edinburgh, and perhaps the world.

Through the outbreak of a zombie epidemic Deadinburgh asks ‘what does it really mean to be human’ whilst offering parallels with real life science, disaster response and diseases such as HIV and TB. In a theatrical world with actors playing the infected hordes and besieged soldiers, the audience will meet real scientists using real science to solve a fictitious disease. 

Deadinburgh's zombie scientists will include: The Roslin Institute; London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine; Heriot Watt University; Wellcome Trust Centre for Cell Biology; Centre for Eating Disorders (Scotland); Manchester Metropolitan’s School of Healthcare Science and Edinburgh University. 

At the end of the show , taking into account everthing they have learned, the audience must vote to destroy the city, kill the infected or search for a cure; the fate of the city is in their hands.  

 

 

Background

The Enlightenment Café series creates thrilling theatre that brings together artists, scientists and pioneering thinkers, placing them in a setting that enhances the way they talk about their work.

Scotland has a long tradition of excellence in biomedical and life sciences (as highlighted in The Royal Society of Edinburgh’s Winter 2012 publication) and with two thirds of our collaborators from Scottish Institutions, Deadinburgh provides a unique opportunity to engage the public with the amazing work happening on their doorstep.

It is also an important time to discuss epidemiology and infectious diseases. Time Magazine this month (March 2013) released an article on TB stating ‘humanity could be facing a new Black Death’ as further strains of tuberculosis emerge in India that are resistant to all known drugs.  The collaborators involved in this Enlightenment Cafe are on our frontline defence to outbreaks like this.

The Enlightenment Café is about creating innovative theatre, science communication for all ages and encouraging critical thinking.

 

The Enlightenment Café at the Old Vic Tunnels, June 2012

The Enlightenment Café at The Old Vic tunnels brought together experts in Astrophysics, Mathematics, Ballet, Chemistry, Psychiatry, Comedy and Natural History.  Alongside this motley crew was a troupe of 15 performers who created the Victorian world through interactive performances including: Speed Debating; an Institute of Victorian Etiquette; an Anthropometric Lab and a Music Hall Clairvoyant. The event played 4 sold-out evenings to 1000 people telling the story of Victorian Science and Medicine.

 Watch a short documentary about the show HERE.

 

How You Can Help

Your funds will ensure that we can pay the actors and scientists, develop a series of short films along the lines of TEDtalks, and add to the design of a show; helping to create the apocalyptic environment.

It is so important that we can properly pay all the brilliant people working towards this fascinating project, so the more money we raise the more we can look after the people working with us.

We want our Zombie Virus to go viral in an airborne contagion of infectious ideas. The more we can shout about this project the more impact it will have.  In doing so, our scientists and performers will have the platform they deserve.

 

Beneficiary Perks 

The perks include: naming characters in the show after you; your name on our wall of deceased; zombie swag; and becoming part of the story by filming a short news clip documenting your reaction to the outbreak for our website.

 

Any help would be wonderful! Share the fund raising page and help us save the world!

story:
First and foremost we are raising money for PLANE TICKETS to fly from the US to the UK and vice versa. Alhtough money will help us to buy plane tickets, we are also hoping that some of you will have access to either air miles or buddy passes to help us out! Here are the flights we need.

 

 

 

Atlanta GA to Edinburgh UK: August 9th - August 31st (2013)

 

Edinburgh UK to Chicago IL: Jan 2nd - Jan 13th (2014)

 

Atlanta GA to Edinburgh UK: January 28th - February 18th (2014)

 

Atlanta GA to Edinburgh UK: March 24th - April 15th (2014)

 

Edinburgh UK to Atlanta GA: June (2014)

 

 

 

If anyone has miles, buddy passes, or connections to airlines they can use to  help get us on any of these flights please let us know!!

 

 

The Backstory: Rain and Sarah have been making art together since 2007. Rain fell in love with an American who cannot move abroad and Sarah fell in love with a Brit who cannot move abroad. The conundrum is two artists separated by an ocean, committed to working with each other, but without sacrificing love to do so.

 

Although we live on opposite sides of the Atlantic our wish to create art together remains alive and vibrant.  Your contribution will pay for three trips across the atlantic in order for us to choreograph, design, create and perform together our pieces Unhinged and Unchained

 

This past January, Sarah flew west to join Rain in Atlanta for a three week development period. During this time we built the apparatus, designed and fabricated our costumes, began the choreography and shot the demo for our latest artisitic endevor, Unchained.  However,  the piece is unfinished. We would like to continue developing this piece by having Rain fly to Scotland.  Our goal is to show Unchained in front of an audience for the first time in 2013.

 

We will also be expanding one of our existing aerial pieces,Unhinged.We will be working with a photographer / graphic designer to create a live narrative photo essay which will be projected with slide projectors and integrated with our movement on aerial silks.  We will be presenting this piece at the Manipulate Festival in Scotland on February 6th at the Traverse Theatre in Edinburgh, Scotland.

 

Your contribution is valuable because it brings together two artists who will create work that inspires, provokes and changes the landscape of aerial arts around the world.  See some of our work samples to learn more about us.  Thank you all for you support.


For more information or questions about any of our work feel free to contact us.  info@paperdollmilitia.com
 www.paperdollmilitia.com

story:
Negotiated Space/ETCHED

Light Switch Dance Theatre (LSDT) announces an exciting new partnership with VisArts in Rockville, MD where we will be premiering two new site-specific movement and dance projects June 6-20, 2104.

 We need your support to help us complete our first official season with VisArts!  

The premieres of Negotiated Space and ETCHED, both choreographed by LSDT Artistic Director, Sandra C. Atkinson, will incorporate original live music by LSDT’s resident musician Wesley Meyer and NYC based Thief’s.  Both of these performances present the audience with multi-disciplinary experience through installation art, film, music and dance.

We want you to be part of this amazing partnership. VisArts is providing space and modest resources for costuming and live music, but we need your help to make this a great experience for everyone. 

What We Need & What You Get

Your donation will make our partnership with VisArts a success for the dancers, musicians, and community. Donations will support choreographer/ dancers/musicians and production costs associated with offering these performances to the public. 
  • Costumes
  • Music equippment for travelling musicians
  • Marketing (Advertisement cost)
  • Equipment for performance/exhibition (set, props, and installation)
  • Travel: Musicians, curator and artists to be a part of performance and talks associated with ETCHED.
  • Food and Water for dancers/musician during extent of performances. 

The Impact

Light Switch Dance Theatre is a sites- specific project based contemporary dance company dedicated to multi-disciplinary performances in non-traditional spaces. Sandra Atkinson, MA (Artistic Director) creates work in a collaborative manner inspired by humanity, science and art of all mediums. LSDT strives to bring FREE performances to the general public making any place a performance space.  

Both of these works are an artistic comment on race, class, gender and basic human needs. With these performance LSDT strives to engage the community through dance, music, visual art, and film as a discussion about about these elementst of everyday life. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about this campaign (share link:https://www.visartsatrockville.org/galleries/gibbs-street-gallery?task=view_event&event_id=107) and performances (share FB link: https://www.facebook.com/LightSwitchDanceTheatre).
  • Come to ETCHED and Negotiated Space (share link: http://lightswitchdance.wix.com/lsdt#!performance-season/c18jz)
  • Donate objects that can be used in the Negotiated Space Installation: found objects exhibition- in need of tarp, slats, fish wire and blueprints.

And that’s all there is to it!

story:
Short Summary

Inspired by the work of New York City-based photographer Sol Aramendi and “The Art of Toreo” or bullfighting, Ramos created EN LA ARENA NO TODO ES ROSADO/IN THE ARENA NOT EVERYTHING IS PINK.  

In this new work, Ramos explores themes of sexuality and the disappointments of queer dating after the sudden end of a 13-year relationship. The work shows the everyday struggles of new beginnings. Bullfighting, with its paradox of beauty and cruelty, pits the Toreo (bullfighter) against the brave but suffering bull. Like this provocation, the work shows how we fight for survival in a similar battle to the death. This struggle motivates the emotional and physical content of the work.

This is being presented by The Young Roots Performance Series at Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture. Funded by the Rockefeller Foudnation NYC Cultural Innovation Fund 2010-12, this series showcases emerging artists experimenting with the artistic roots of Afro-Latino traditions to create new branches that reach into the future. theyoungrootsperformanceseries.blogspot.com.

The work was developed as part of a Studio Series residency at New York Live Arts, as well as an ongoing residency at El Museo del Barrio. Ramos deeply identified with two works by Aramendi on display at El Museo del Barrio’s The (S) Files 2011 exhibition. Aramendi's photographs, "Bailando Conmigo" ("Dancing with myself"), shows a woman ironing records by hand as they melt under her touch. Another work, “El Amor Duele” ("Love Hurts"), depicts a bride who hangs her heart on a coat rack. These works motivated Ramos to examine real life, quotidian events such as eating, having sex, or taking pills in a surreal way.

Endless thanks are due to Jane Gabriels and Pepatian for the never-ending support, and for making every part of the process a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5000 to pay our build a set, light the piece, finish the costumes, and of course pay the dancers. In exchange, aside from our excellent rewards, you will be supporting one of the few queer Puerto Rican voices currently coming to prominence in the contemporary dance world of New York City. You will also be supporting a truly amazing work of art.

The Impact

Antonio's work has been presented by some of the most important dance venues in New York City (DTW, New York Live Arts, and The Kitchen, to name a few), and it has been extremely well-received. Still, with all of that wonderful support, he has never had an evening-length solo show. If this project is a success, it will absolutely start a new and necessary chapter for Antonio and his choreographic career.

Other Ways You Can Help

Many people do not have the funds to contribute, and of course we totally understand! You can definitely still support us.

1) Come to the show! We need people to show up and let the Bronx see that we want contemporary dance to live and grow in Bronx venues. Come alone, or better yet bring a ton of friends! November 29 and 30 at Hostos College at 149th and Grand Concourse. Seriously, it's faster than getting from North to South Brooklyn friends!

2) Maybe you don't have money, but you know someone who would be thrilled to support this work and has some cash to spare. Send them the link, put them in touch with us, and/or bring them to the show.

story:
Short Summary

Greetings! We are the Squidling Bros. Circus Sideshow based out of Philadelphia PA.  This Fall 2013 the Squidlings embark on our annual coast to coast tour of the USA.  In order to get from town to town we need to repair our Atlantic City Jitney short bus and print tons of posters and fliers to get the word out about the shows.  With the help of your contributions our bus will be running in tip top shape and we will be able to get the word out to the masses!  And if we reach or exceed our goal cover some of the many travel costs along the way.

What We Need & What You Get

Bus Maintenance $3,000

Fliers and Posters $1,500 for printing and mailing out to over 20 cities

Travel expenses $2,000 for 6 weeks of food/lodging for 6 people.

Gas expenses $3,500 traveling coast to coast to over 25 cities.

Total expenses $10,000

We are looking to cut our costs in half through your contributions!  A tour sponsored by the people for the people.

Receive fabulous prizes and souveniers such as signed tour posters, t-shirts and sideshow DVD's!  Get a free pass to staple a clown.  Cheapest form of therapy around!!  Even receive a Squidling Bros. performance at your private party!!

If we don't reach our 'goal funds' what ever money we earn will go toward getting our Bus road ready. So every little bit helps.

 The Impact

Circus Sideshow is not a thing of the past, it is very much alive!  This fall we will be bringing a unique cast of characters to over 25 cities across America.  What you get is a real live freakshow.  Sword swallowing, aerial acrobatics and fire arts.  The strongman and the circus freak.  Live music by the Velvet Crayon and Matterz the Impenetrable Music Man.  Feats of human strength and endurance that make the impossible possible.

The Squidling Bros. have been touring for over 5 years.  Always bringing a new and amazing cast of characters along with them.  Every night the performers in this show risk their lives for your entertainment.  With insanely high gas prices and cost of living your contributions ensure that the performers in the show will earn a decent living and not have to worry about the expenses of being out on the road. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute please get the word out about the campaign and tell people who can!

Use the indiegogo share tools and spread the word on facebook!

Thank you, thank you, thank you.

story:
Donate now! Click to make a tax deductible donation via Fractured Atlas.

Fathers of the Dark Knight is a stage play that chronicles the true story account of three young men from the Bronx who in 1939 collaborated to create The Batman mythology for the comic book industry.  Side by side with their poignant tale, the play will present their iconic creations come to life on stage in their own spectacular storyline, inspired directly from the pages of their comic book adventures! 

The play was initially developed as a small high school production in October 2011, to awaken student interest in theater. Mr. Williams realized that although many of his students described themselves as Batman fans, none of them were aware that Batman was born in their Bronx back yard.  Roberto saw an opportunity to inspire his students with the true tale of great achievement against all odds that his students could relate to.  Over time, Mr. Williams steadily transformed the scope and scale of Fathers of the Dark Knight into a more ambitious project to match the growing passion and commitment of his students.   It was important to him to instill in them the drive to supersede their own expectations.  Many of these students suffered great adversity at home so this production served as a creative outlet where they could shine and discover kindred spirits. 

Tax-deductible receipts will be emailed to you from Fractured Atlas.

Credit card donations transactions will list Fractured Atlas on your credit card statement.

story:
In order to promote the pursuit of higher education in dance related fields, ANAHATA Dance is hosting, "Celebrate H'Doubler," a collection of works by the University of Wisconsin-Madison faculty and NYC-based alumni.  The concert is named in honor of Margaret H'Doubler, the creator of the first dance class in a tertiary institution which inspired the first Dance Degree program in America at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.  H'Doubler's radical ideas about training methods for dancers, generated by her extensive knowledge of Human Anatomy and Kinesiology, have inspired the dance curriculum in major universities as well as public high schools and elementary schools across the country.  The concert will take place on Saturday October 12 and Sunday October 13 at the Salvatore Capezio Theater at Peridance.  On Sunday, all NYC public school students will be offered drastically reduced ticket prices (the cost of which will be determined by the success of this campaign.)

The collaborators in this event have taken their exceptional training from the lineage of Margaret H'Doubler and brought it to life in many different areas in the field of dance including Dance Movement Therapy, Dance Education, Dance Education Outreach, Choreography, Arts Administration, Production Design, and Performance.  Choreographers include Professors Kate Corby, Li Chiao-Ping, and Chris Walker; Faculty member Collette Stewart; Alumni Nicole Roerick, Lauren Rosenstein, Ella Rosewood, Beth Soll, Natalie Teichmann, Megan Thompson, and Taryn Vander Hoop; and Alumni-sponsored companies, ANAHATA Dance, Beth Soll and Company, Ella Rosewood Dance, the Nicole Roerick Collective, and Summation Dance.  Special guest performance by the KIPP NYC College Prep Dance Team.

 We need your help in order to be able to offer the discounted tickets for the NYC public school youth.  Even the smallest contribution can go a long way towards achieving our goal.  Thank you so much for your support and interest in our campaign.

About our company:  ANAHATA DANCE is a company that is comprised of dancers with open hearts and courageous minds. The company does not discriminate based on technical skill level or previous accomplishments, but rather the willingness to work hard, to dedicate oneself to a passion, and to resolve to dance both efficiently and non-toxically.  The goal of the company is to use dance to heal, to grow, to challenge, and to stimulate both the dancer and the audience.

(Small photo Beth Soll by Barry Hetherington)

story:
Controversy erupts in a small California town in 1945 when a local hero returns from World War II with his Japanese bride.

 

Written by Samantha Macher, author of last year's critically acclaimed and sold out SkyPilot production, TO THE NEW GIRL.

 

Directed by Nancy Dobbs Owen

 

Starring Julia Sanford, Brett Fleisher, Sachiyo K, Jeffrey Markle, Kelly Goodman, Katie Apicella, Amelia Rose, Ethan Zachary Scott, Alicia Foo, Yukari Koseki, Reesa Ishiyama

 

It is the fall of 1945. Private Alvin Rhodes is returning home to his mother Catherine in Merced, CA. He has an injury that he doesn’t want to discuss and a new wife, a Japanese nurse named Yumi. Yumi is greeted with suspicion and fear, even outright hatred. The bombs were dropped only two months prior and Japanese Americans are still unjustly interned at Manzinar, not far away. She is shy and withdrawn, but with the help of Catherine’s old friend Richard, a Japanese/English dictionary and 1000 paper cranes, her story is slowly revealed. WAR BRIDEcombines sharp, witty dialogue with Japanese Butoh influenced contemporary dance to create a completely new play that will tear at your heart while challenging your ideas of right and wrong.

 

WAR BRIDE tells a compelling story from the point of view of the women: Catherine, Yumi, the neighborhood girls. Roles for women are far too few in American theater. We have also authentically cast both Japanese and American actors, filling a gap in the Asian acting community. Finally, the lessons of World War Two are relevant in a world where we still lock people up without a trial based upon irrational fears and prejudice.

 

 

The Theatre Company

SkyPilot Theatre Company is a non-profit organization dedicated to fostering new relationships with provocative playwrights to develop the most compelling, challenging and humorous new plays for the Los Angeles theatre going audience. Skypilot is a member of the LA Stage Alliance.

WAR BRIDE is the fourth production of the 2012 season, our second full year of exclusively producing world premiere plays.

 

Be A Part of WAR BRIDE

Your donations will be a great help to this production in a number of ways. The money will be used towards set design and construction,lighting, visual effects and publicity.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about WAR BRIDE with your friends, family and co-workers!

Share our information on your Facebook, Twitter and all other social media pages.

Visit our website and sign up for updates on all of our upcoming plays and events at www.SkyPilotTheatre.com

Like us on Facebook 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/SkyPilot-Theatre...

Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/#!/SkyPilotTheatre

 

 

Thank You

Your support is greatly appreciated by all who are a part of this amazing company. We thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

story:
Music Theatre Montreal

                                              presents

                    The Virgin Courtesan - A World Premier

Set amidst the decadence of early-renaissance Venice, The Virgin Courtesan follows the story of a virtuous young woman as she embarks on a dangerous journey towards self-discovery, freedom and love*. 

We are proud of, and honoured to work with artists such as Frayne and Blair, and are excited, along with our incredible team, to present to you, The Virgin Courtesan.

*Full synopsis and in the Gallery section of this campaign, or on our site at:

http://www.musictheatremontreal.com/index.php?page=productions

SEE our Cast List below!

..And you might say a World Premier for Music Theatre Montreal too!

The Virgin Courtesan marks our launch of the Music Theatre Montreal new works development initiatives, in which we work with writers and composers to workshop new pieces in development, presenting them in concert for the public and industry.

Our goal is to provide a platform for our artists to refine and develop new works beyond what would be possible without getting it up on its feet and seeing it in action.  This is also an important opportunity to have the work seen by industry professionals, connecting our writers/composers with potential patrons and producers with an eye on a fully-mounted production down the line. 

Music Theatre Montreal was created in order to give opportunity to emerging artists while enriching the culture and tradition of musical theatre in Montreal. We are a federally registered not-for-profit organization that fosters open involvement and collaboration.

What We Need

In order to make this project a success, our goal is to surpass $5,000. Funds go towards materials, set construction, transporation, rehearsal and performance space rental, costumes, technical aspects, union fees where applicable, publicity costs, etc.

Made up primarily of volunteers, the majority of our cast, crew, artistic and administrative team donate their time, and in many cases other resources (financial and property).  Producing high-calliber productions and concerts can be a daunting endevour financially and we thank you for your support!

When You Support Our Show You Can Get All Sorts of Fun Perks*

- Signed copy of this orignal script by playwright and composer

- Your name on our public acknowledgments patrons' page/list

- Reserved prime seating for the world premiere of "The Virgin Courtesan" on September 22nd 2012

- A signed eco-friendly stainless steel MTM water bottle signed by composer and playwright, Blair Thomson and Frayne McCarthy

- Discounted tickets for future MTM productions

- Our eternal gratitude, and that warm feeling that comes from making a difference in the community and the arts!

- And More!

*Please note that not all "perks" are available at every level of patronage. Please read "perk" descriptions carefully.

The Impact

By helping support Music Theatre Montreal and The Virgin Courtesan, you ensure that not only this exiting project grows and thrives, but you help ensure future original works such as this get off the ground. With your support, artists, writers, producers can focus more of their energy on the work at hand, knowing that the financial aspects, especially up front costs of mounting a production such as this, will not interfere in the realization of the production. With several of our creative and production team members being emerging artists, producers and technicians, The Virgin Courtesan is having an impact in giving experience and mentorship opportunities to artists, crew, and producers of the future.  Through your support you are playing an integral role in giving arts and culture education and musical theatre opportunities to emerging professionals in Montreal, as well as providing the chance to discover and explore live musical theatre experiences to the community at large.

For more information about Music Theatre Montreal and this production, please visit our website: www.musictheatremontreal.com for reviews, photographs, videos and news about both past and upcoming events.

Other Ways You Can Help

             • Be sure to come see The Virgin Courtesan, and help us spread the word

             • 'like' us on FaceBook at: http://www.facebook.com/Musictheatremontreal

             • Follow us on twitter at: www.twitter.com/MusicTheatreMtl

             • Use the Indiegogo Share tools to share this campaign with your networks!

 

Ticket Information

~General Seating to this concert is offered for a suggested donation of $12-$20.~
 
~Cash only please--at the door.~
~ Your financial consideration and generosity is greatly appreciated.~  

 

                                       Enjoy the show!

 

 

About the Playwright and Composer of The Virgin Courtesan

Frayne McCarthy

Frayne McCarthy is a bilingual performer whose stage roles have taken him throughout Europe and across Canada, very often in World Premiere productions of prestigious shows. Having watched and partaken in the original creative process so often, he has applied many of the lessons he’s learned to his own writing. Frayne has written for children’s theatre, collaborated with Daniel Boulerice on the musical AutoPortrait for the National Arts Centre of Canada, and now he is proud to be working with composer Blair Thomson, Music Theatre Montreal, and this exciting cast to bring you The Virgin Courtesan.

Blair Thomson

Blair studied piano from the age of three and began seriously composing as a young teenager at which time he completed his studies in piano and theory from the Royal Conservatory of Music. He graduated from York University in composition before studying ethnomusicology and philosophy of mind as a graduate student.  Before moving to Montréal in 1995, he was active as a composer, pianist and conductor in the Toronto contemporary music scene. Mr. Thomson has composed extensively for theatre, dance, opera, musical theatre, film and television. [The Virgin Courtesan, Frayne collaboration]

CAST

MARIO                        Dale Miller

GONDELIER                 Nicolas Vittorio Saavedra Fusinato

PIETRO                        Marc Francoeur

PRIEST/BISHOP            Pierre Lenoir

SEMINARIAN                 Kenny Wong

GUIDO                         Sylvain Millette

BRIANNA                      Catherine Savoie

NINA                            Caitlyn Milot

ADRIANNA                    Nicola Dawn

ARIELLE                       Noelle Hannibal      

SISTER THERESA/
HARLOT/COURTESAN     Lily Maclean               

NUN/HARLOT/
COURTESAN                   Coralie Heiler
    
NUN/HARLOT/
COURTESAN                   Ghislaine  Doté

NUN/HARLOT/
COURTESAN                   Caroline Gauthier

NUN/HARLOT/
COURTESAN                   Catherine Marmen

 

                                                        ~

 

Funds surpassing the needs of this particular production will go toward future MTM arts educational initiatives, including new works and main stage productions, and outreach workshops.  Donations can also be made directly on our website at www.musictheatremontreal.com.

                                                    Thank you!

story:
i am pamela wunderlich, a masters graduate of mills college, with over 30 years of professional experience as an experimental, expressionistic, modern choreographer. concerts i have produced include, "dancedada," the animal man of the moon does not yet have firm bones," "the glamour animal series," "and how: an autobiography," and "live girls: 50 beautiful ones, one ugly one."  i admire the work of the late german choreographer, pina bausch, & want to make a dance she would be proud to have living on in the modern dance & ballet lexicon. we will premier this 14-minute dance on february 1, 2013, at mills college in oakland, california, & i want to pay each of my 10 young dancers, half of whom are mills students, $200 each for their outstanding contributions as serious, professional dancers. dance artists deserve to be paid for all of the hard phsical work they contribute to contemporary dance literature that benefits all of us who cherish live performance.

REMEMBER!  TO LIVE IS TO DANCE...  any funds that you can afford to contribute will be used to pay the dancers.  this project will go forward if we do not reach our $2000 goal.

story:
CounterPULSE and the Blind Tiger Society present a world premiere by Bianca Cabrera:

Sunk in Sleep

AUG 17-19, FRI-SUN at 8pm, 2012

Sunk in Sleep is part daydream, part nightmare and a full kick of kinetic sensationalism. Unadulterated dance with unpredictable boundaries keeps the audience bouncing from peril to delight. A down the rabbit hole kind of exploit, Sunk in Sleep takes you straight into the belly of your own beast.

 

We need your help! 100% of the funds raised through IndieGoGo will go directly into the pockets of the contracted performers and creators of the work.  Keep Art Alive! Keep Artists Employed!

Before any grant money came in, Sunk In Sleep was accepted by CounterPULSE for immediate production, and we have been enthusiastically diving head first into our creative process.

All other productions costs are being covered by Bianca Cabrera’s bartending job in Oakland. While she can only sell so many cocktails between now and the show, you can help on IndieGoGo!

Many skillful and possessed collaborators have already donated large amounts of their professional time to Sunk in Sleep. By the end of the project, each dancer (Bianca Cabrera, Tanya Chianese, Kelli Galdes, Roche Janken, Mallory Markham and Samantha Stone) will have rehearsed 200+ hours, Ben Juodvalkis will have written, arranged and recorded an original musical score, and set designer Roel Q Seeber will have grinded, welded, hammered and erected an original sculpted metal set for Sunk in Sleep. Once again, 100% of the funds secured through IndieGoGo will go towards supporting these generous and talented artists. Our current finances (ahem, Bianca’s tip jar) are funneling towards obligatory aspects of the production, such as theater rental, rehearsal space, tactile materials, administration costs and labor, receptions, marketing and publicity, and technical staff.

Any amount you can give is not only unbelievable appreciated by all of us, but will certainly cause us to break out in hysterically happy song! (And dance, but that's a given.)

Can’t give on IndieGoGo?

You can still help! We get to keep 80% of our box office, so come to the show and bring 50 of your closest friends!

Live in Oakland? Visit Artistic Director, Bianca Cabrera at Luka’s Taproom and Lounge Tues – Thurs with 100 of your closest friends. Whatever she brings home, she puts in the Sunk in Sleep kitty!

Tell your friends about us! Like us on Facebook, follow us on Tumblr and Twitter.  If you receive our newsletter via email, forward them to people who will love us.  See our postcard in a coffee shop? Pick one up and put it in someone’s hand.

All other productions costs are being covered by Bianca Cabrera’s bartending job in Oakland. While she can only sell so many cocktails between now and the show, you can help on IndieGoGo!
Many skillful and possessed collaborators have already donated large amounts of their professional time to Sunk in Sleep. By the end of the project, each dancer (Bianca Cabrera, Tanya Chianese, Kelli Galdes, Roche Janken, Mallory Markham and Samantha Stone) will have rehearsed 200+ hours, Ben Juodvalkis will have written, arranged and recorded an original musical score, and set designer Roel Q Seeber will have grinded, welded, hammered and erected an original sculpted metal set for Sunk in Sleep. Once again, 100% of the funds secured through IndieGoGo will go towards supporting these generous and talented artists. Our current finances (ahem, Bianca’s tip jar) are funneling towards obligatory aspects of the production, such as theater rental, rehearsal space, tactile materials, administration costs and labor, receptions, marketing and publicity, and technical staff.
Any amount you can give is not only unbelievable appreciated by all of us, but will certainly cause us to break out in hysterically happy song! (And dance, but that's a given.)
Can’t give on IndieGoGo?
You can still help! We get to keep 80% of our box office, so come to the show and bring 50 of your closest friends!
Live in Oakland? Visit Artistic Director, Bianca Cabrera at Luka’s Taproom and Lounge Tues – Thurs with 100 of your closest friends. Whatever she brings home, she puts in the Sunk in Sleep kitty!
Tell your friends about us! Like us on Facebook, follow us on Tumblr and Twitter.  If you receive our newsletter via email, forward them to people who will love us.  See our postcard in a coffee shop? Pick one up and put it in someone’s hand.

story:
THIS FUNDRAISING PAGE IS NO LONGER ACTIVELY ACCEPTING DONATIONS, BUT WE ARE STILL RAISING MONEY FOR A SPRING 2013 PRODUCTION OF THIS PLAY.  TO CONTRIBUTE, PLEASE GO TO https://www.fracturedatlas.org/donate/2463.  

FEEL FREE TO CONTINUE TO BROWSE THROUGH MY SITE HERE, AS THERE ARE PLENLTY OF ENTERTAINING VIDEOS AND PHOTOS WHICH WILL INFORM YOU ABOUT OUR GOALS.    JUST CLICK ON THE "GALLERY" OR "UPDATES" BUTTONS ABOVE.  THANK YOU.  JOLIE

 

SUMMARY

This four-person play tells the story of two 50-something sisters, Elizabeth Borny and Quilly McGrath, who share an apartment in 1943 Harlem. The older sister, Elizabeth, in need of some rent relief, takes in a young male border from South Carolina named Husband Witherspoon.  Husband is a sweet, naive, mama’s boy who travels to Harlem to find his lost love, Lou Bessie. He is taken aback by Lou Bessie’s manipulative ways and turns to Elizabeth for comfort and companionship.  Even though Quilly vociferously disapproves of Elizabeth's growing attachment to Husband, Elizabeth allows her passion to overcome her good sense.

HISTORY OF PROJECT

In 2009, I starred as Quilly McGrath in a workshop production of this play.  It was a wonderful experience, and the play has never left the forefront of my mind.  Even now, not a month goes by without someone telling me how much they enjoyed it.   I feel I have unfinished business with THE OLD SETTLER.

THE PLAN

My goal is to mount a first-class production of the play in the fall of 2012, with the same fabulous director and cast.  It will take place in a 99-seat theater in Los Angeles, for a six to eight-week run (Thursdays through Sundays).  

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

Theater rental will be the prime expense (approximately one-third of the budget). There will be costs associated with our designers, (set, costume, lighting and sound), as well as the Producer, Stage Manager, Publicist, Director and cast.  I truly believe in paying people what they are worth; show business is all about building relationships.

Finally, there will be administrative costs (insurance, license fees, marketing, props, materials, and the ever popular "miscellaneous").  The budget will be between $35,000-$45,000; $15,000 of it has already been raised.

THE PERKS

We have 10 levels of perks for your contributions, each named after a PERSON, PLACE or THING associated with Harlem.  For example, a $25 donation is the COTTON CLUB, which garners your name listed in our commemorative program, and a 5.5 x 8.5 glossy postcard of our beautiful poster, designed by local artist Loretta Weeks.

The PERKS listing appears to the right of this column; please make sure you scroll to the bottom!

MY TRACK RECORD (Will this project be a success?)

I have been actively involved in the entertainment industry for over 30 years, as an actor, producer, writer, director and stand-up comic.  I have put shows together for audiences of 2,000, and audiences of 20.  I have raised close to $40,000 for various film and video projects.  But most importantly, I have a passion for this project and will see it to fruition.

If you wish to know more about me or my credits, I have linked several sites below under the heading "Also Find This Campaign On." 

Thank you, from the bottom of my heart.

story:
Less than 7 hours left! Please donate now to contribute to Mediterranean arts & culture!


Between the Seas: the Only Mediterranean Performing Arts Festival in North America 

July 21-27 at the Wild Project, East Village, NYC

Between the Seas was the dream of Aktina Stathaki, a Greek-born theatre artist, who saw the need for a platform for Mediterranean arts and culture in NYC. Now in its fourth year, the festival has built a vibrant, international community of artists, collaborators, and audiences. We continue envisioning a thriving Mediterranean community in NYC where artists can share ideas and projects and showcase the music, dance, theatre, and art that represents them and their cultures. This year Between the Seas will include World Premieres of some of the most cutting-edge, political, and extraordinary contemporary performances from across the region and will partner with some of the most compelling NYC-based artists and companies. 

All we need is 300 people to each donate $10!

As a small cultural arts organization showcasing political works, we rely on volunteer work, ticket sales, and individual donations to cover our costs and sustain our activities. Thanks to grants and institutional support, we are able to pay technical staff and artists to cover our programming. But we still have basic needs to meet. The $3000 will go towards paying half of our theatre rental at the Wild Project ($2000), hiring a publicist ($600), and printing our promotional flyers and festival programs ($400). Any remaining money will be used to advertise the festival through print and online platforms. Since we seek to engage an inclusive audience, our publicity must be comprehensive and accessible. Your $10 enables cross-cultural dialogue between some of the hottest artists from the most politically nuanced countries and the local members of your own community.

Your support matters -- any amount makes a huge difference.

What We Need & What You Get

We are almost at our mark, and we need you to bring it home. Depending on what you give, you may receive an exclusive behind-the-scenes Thank You Video from BTS staff & contributing artists, your name featured on our website and/or program, 1-2 complimentary show tickets, access to an exclusive Opening Night Reception, or an intimate meet-and-greet brunch with the artists. See perks for details.

The Impact

Between the Seas hosts artists from Israel, Palestine, Syria, Italy, Greece, Spain, Kosovo, Catalonia, Turkey, the US, and more. We are the only festival on this side of the hemisphere engaging such a diverse and vibrant crowd of all ages, religions, languages, cultures, and ethnicities. We bring critical Mediterranean artists to the US to increase awareness about the politics, identities, and visions of Mediterranean artists. We present brand new, World Premieres of contemporary theatre and dance that would otherwise never reach a NYC stage. And we give opportunities to NYC-based audiences and artists to exchange ideas in an international, peaceful setting.

In 2014 we're creating a compelling program that raises pressing questions about the region's politics through new drama and performance, interrogates the role of arts and artists in a time of crisis, and celebrates new interdisciplinary aesthetics. Some of the program's highlights are:

  • Hotel Mediterranee by Greek director Nadia Foskolou: an ensemble performance interweaving Chuck Mee's play Matisse's Self Portrait and S. Charalambopoulos' documentary Moralis (World Premiere)
  • What dreams May come by Turkish-German dancer and choreographer Nejla Yatkin: a preview of experimental new work exploring the East/West connection through multimedia movement, space, light, and shadow
  • Elsa Shock, performed by the Baletto Teatro di Sardegna under the artistic direction of Massimiliano Leoni: a dramatized dance paying homage to the Italian stylist Elsa Schiaparelli who revolutionized the history of fashion and costume (World premiere)
  • Shameful Occurrences, Disturbing Facts, Light And Darkness / The Sacred Way by Israeli performance artist Mica Dvir / the NYC-based UNGUARDED project: a double bill dealing with some of the most vexing issues currently in the region, including a critique of the Israeli settlements and an exploration of migrations across the Mediterranean (North American premiere/work in progress)

We will also be premiering the 4x4 project: NYC Meets the Med, a new initiative pairing four Mediterranean playwrights with four American directors. 

  • A Chance Encounter by Syrian playwright Mohammad al-Attar: a provocative play voicing the internal struggle of Syrian politics (North American premiere)
  • Against Progress, Against Democracy, Against Love by Catalan playwright Esteve Soler: a trilogy critiquing Western society through humor and horror (A North American/English premiere, supported by the Institut Ramon Llul)
  • The Price by Greek playwright Lena Kitsopoulou: a grotesque satire about the Greek political and financial crisis (North American premiere)
  • One Flew Over the Kosovo Theatre by Kosovar playwright and artistic director Jeton Neziraj: a comedic political parody about Kosovo's path to national independence. (North American premiere)

4x4 Directors: Tamilla Woodard, Ana Margineanu, Noelle Ghoussaini, and Doug Howe.


New program additions include queer Arab Palestinian performer & visual artist Elias Wakeem and world-renowned Israeli dancer Talia Beck.

In addition to outstanding performances, we are hosting panel discussions, talk backs, and social events that will bring our community together and share with audiences what the Mediterranean is about in a vibrant and joyful setting.

Please spread the word!

  • Like us on the BTS Facebook Page
  • Visit our BTS Webpage
  • Read our BTS Blog 
  • Check out our BTS Flicker
  • Watch our BTS Vimeo channel
  • Follow us on BTS Twitter

story:
What is ConverseNation?

On the heels of its sold-out Pick of the Fringe production, Traffick, Pones Inc. brings a new piece to Cincinnati audiences which investigates the dynamics of wealth and poverty in the Queen City. ConverseNation was presented at the CrisisArt Festival held in Italy during the month of August as a demonstration of the powerful effect art can have on social change. The work was incredibly well-received on this international platform, with audience members sharing how they “now question their own ideas of privilege,” and calling the work “a beautiful crescendo that invited me to play.”

Through technology and careful listening, Pones company members interviewed a range of people, recording as many interviews as possible and creating ConverseNation as a dance piece with a documentary video component. The promenade-style presentation of the work in Cincinnati is site-specific and uses both natural and constructed spaces, inviting audiences to begin at Washington Park and journey the less-traveled spaces of Over-the-Rhine, seeing multiple dance vignettes and stopping off in various indoor spaces, including First Lutheran Church on Race Street and the Art Academy of Cincinnati to view the documentary videos.

Pones Inc. provides artistic opportunities for community growth by creating engaging new ways for audiences to experience dance.

Founded in 2008, Pones Inc. has collaborated with over 200 artists and 100 art and service organizations. The company creates site-specific performances through a fusion of movement and dance with other art forms. Pones Inc. performers use their bodies to speak their minds and uses its signature pedestrian-inspired movement to spark collaboration, connection, and community.  Pones Inc. believes that art creates powerful change.


Your support...

Goes directly to covering the costs of sharing this special production with the Cincinnati community that helped create it.

These costs include: 

  • paying performers
  • venue sponsorships
  • props
  • costumes
  • printing
  • other miscellaneous costs

story:
About Our Project

After sold-out, smash hit runs of Little Wars, What Was Lost and Shades Of Blue, Steven Carl McCasland's plays return to NYC for a month-long festival. Steven's characters include a legendary jazz singer, an unforgettable playwright, a President, the world's most famous mystery writer and more. From plays featuring Agatha Christie and Gertrude Stein to Billie Holiday and Joe Glaser, Steven's plays have been called "riveting", "bravely imagined", "brilliant", "mesmerizing" and more.

For five years, Steven served as the Founding Artistic Director of Beautiful Soup Theater. Working as a one-man band to produce theatrical benefits for charities including The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, The USO, Safe Horizon Shelter and more, Beautiful Soup's productions have included the much-talked-about Moose Murders, the critically acclaimed American premiere of Lift and sold-out runs of Rags, A Doll's Life and more.

Thanks to generous donors and believers, Steven has been offered the opportunity of a lifetime: to present his works in a month-long festival in NYC at The Clarion Theatre (formerly The Richmond Shepard). But we can't do it without you! With your help, the festival will become a reality.

Now, Steven will turn his focus to bringing his characters to life with an extraordinary cast performing all five plays in repertory. Kristen Gehling will appear in all five productions, playing Margo Jones, Tallulah Bankhead, Rose Marie Kennedy and more. 

What We Need & What You Get

Without you, we can't make it happen. We need additional funds to cover the costs of rehearsal space, lighting and scenic rentals, costume pieces and payment for our cast and crew. 

  • Our goal is to raise an additional $12,000 to the funds we've already been gifted. These funds will go a long way in covering additional costs. 
  • Producing one play takes a great deal of fundraising. Producing five in repertory will be even harder. But utilizing a repertory cast, along with certain props and costume pieces for multiple productions will make them all go a very long way.
If we don't reach the goal listed above, that's okay! Every penny raised will help us present these five plays in repertory. If we do reach the goal, we'll have even more to spread around for each production - assisting with costumes, props, stipends and more!

The Impact

With your help, over a dozen actors will have the opportunity to present their craft in a month-long forum to directors, casting agents and talent scouts across the tri-state area. A young playwright will have the opportunity to share his works with producers and theatre organizations. Rose Marie Kennedy, Billie Holiday, Laurette Taylor and more will all be given another voice. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Get the word out! Share, e-mail, tweet, Tumblr and blog about the campaign. Don't just copy and paste the link. Write about it. Tell your friends why they should donate. Remember: One hundred $10 donations equal one thousand dollars.

story:
My name is Justin Lanouette. I have been a theatre student at Rosebud School of the Arts for the past four years and I really believe in the theatre and its power to change the world and heal people. I'm in love with the theatre, airplanes, and flying. The closest I get to flying is performing this play, Billy Bishop Goes to War.

This small campaign will help me fund the production of my final project at RSA: Billy Bishop Goes to War - a show I have been passionate about since I saw it seven years ago with a close friend. I knew I was going to produce it from the start of my training and despite doubt, I knew it was possible. I have gone mile and mile beyond to get this play between my fingers and I need your help to fully grasp it.

You can help create a piece of unforgettable theatre, allowing me to play my dream role, while aiding me in a very important step in my theatre career.

Your money helps pay personnel, and the costs of production such as costumes, posters, programs, props, lighting, haircuts and scripts.

Billy Bishop Goes to War is wonderfully entertaining show about a young, naive, accident-prone Canadian in WWI who ultimately achieves greatness. The story combines vivid storytelling with finely crafted piano underscoring and songs.

Even if you can't give personally, you can still create a buzz and encourage others to attend. Remember, everybody is welcome - admission is pay what you will. No payment required.

The show plays at the Akokiniskway Gallery, in Rosebud:

Friday July 21st - 11:17pm

Saturday July 22nd - 11:17pm

Sunday July 23rd - 7:17pm

Monday July 24th - 7:17pm

Here is a link to the event on Facebook.

 

https://www.facebook.com/events/438227006570009/

story:
Following on from the success of our 5 star reviewed sell-out production LARP, Barefaced Theatre, and Minty Fresh Productions bring you, the next hot ticket in town, Shadow Kingdoms.

Barefaced’s mission has been to bring fresh new work and fresh new talent to the London theatre scene. Our work is ambitious in how we tell our stories but always accessible. Above all our shows contain bucket loads of heart and soul. A mission and a vision that Minty Fresh Productions shares.

Previous Barefaced praise...we're not too shabby...

LARP – Bread & Roses Theatre, Clapham Fringe Festival

✭✭✭✭✭ "An hour-long tour de force of writing and acting, LARP is a show to remember." Public Reviews 

Mad Woman – Portobello Pop-up

✭✭✭✭☆“Barefaced Theatre is an exceedingly creative company that teems with imagination, intellect and realism.”  A Younger Theatre

Mad Women –✭✭✭✭☆ “Complex, creative and challenging” Backstage Pass

All Hidden – A Significant Role Rep season at the Portobello Pop-up

“Strong new work exploring the life of a strong historical woman.” One Stop Arts

About the core creative team...

The play, runner-up in the Mercury Playwriting Award, is written by Berri George a published playwright, who's part of the BBC Hot Talent List and BBC Drama Room. Directed by Adam Dattis an American director that’s worked in London for over a decade with some of the most exciting new British writing. Produced by Adwoa-Alexsis Mintah, a born and bred Londoner, who has a passion for new writing and new talent, which stems from her years as a theatre actress. The play stars Katie Warren professional actress and deviser whose worked in the West End and for some of London’s most innovative theatre-makers. Movement Director, James Berkery whose work has featured on ITV, MTV, Universal Music, VICE, Promo News, Paper Mag, 405 and David Reviews amongst many others. Outreach coordinator Steven Millar, whose working with us to enable that alongside our production we will be offering 3 free workshops to 16+ individuals both within the local community and surrounding areas. 

About Shadow Kingdoms

 “Hit everything from here to … Amersham – end of the line”. He said. So I did. Marked every available surface with my can. Four hours went by. Heart proper pounding.

Love it. Hate it. Train (graffiti) writing was prolific – an attractive but intoxicating mix of obsession, fear, and thrill-seeking. Set in the early 2000s, the play tells the story of an unlikely partnership forged between two strangers, who go by the Graff names, Mute and Nexstar. Both finding an escape from their troubled and isolated lives in the night-time cityscape playground of train yards and tube depots; spraying London colourful. Two people from very different worlds discovering a common language and learning to trust in humanity again.

  “Two things particularly resonate with me as a writer, putting the unexpected on stage and creating stories around people, which are overlooked or hidden away. So an unexplored subculture like train graffiti, on stage, felt undeniably palpable.” Berri George, playwright.

All set to an originally composed grime and electronic music soundtrack and infused with dynamic movement and choreography, we follow this Graff duo as they bomb their way through London;  always running away, but always trying to find a way in

"As soon as I read it, Shadow Kingdoms had me hooked straight away. The piece's landscape, the subject matter's topicality, and the driving rhythmic dialogue creates an undeniable pulse that exposes an opportunity to explore and explode theatrical convention. Bringing Shadow Kingdoms to life will be incredibly creatively challenging for all involved, but it's this challenge that theatrical imagination thrives.... directors like me wish for pieces like this to come along."  Adam Dattis, Director/Designer

We want to create a legacy with this show and maximum impact. Encouraging new audiences to the theatre, whilst being innovative with our approach. So we expect to invest a huge amount of hard work, blood (if required), sweat and tears but there’s one area we are lacking in...some well-needed starter funds... and this where you amazing people come in...

Support Us

As you can see there's a huge range of perks you can sign up for, starting as little as five pounds. And all the money raised will go directly towards costs for the show; creative wages, outreach workshops, props, set, costume, venue hire etc. So please help us reach our target and make this show the success it deserves to be. 

We really can't do it without you, so dig deep and let's get this show on!

Other ways to help...

If you are unable to contribute financially, all is not lost. It would be so helpful (and very much appreciated) if you could spread the word. Please share this campaign, and if you don’t already, follow us on social media. And keep up to date with all things #ShadowKingdoms

Twitter: https://twitter.com/barefaced_berri?lang=en-gb 

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/berribarefaced/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/199055198333/

story:
Two months ago I paid a non refundable deposit to go to clown school, because I knew that I just had to go. Not just for my own journey of taking myself less seriously, unravel my conditioning and follow my joy, but to help others do the same!

Clowning has really helped me to be more unashamedly expressive, take greater leaps of faith (like this one!), cultivate a beautiful relationship with my inner child and generally had my life enriched with the joy of play and authentic expression! I would love to share this with more people and with an increased toolkit of understanding and growth that I will receive from this one month intensive.

In the last few months I applied for loads of jobs and started a business (see below). I had full intention to get all the money together and be a mature responsible human. And then I found out that I have to have the full $$ paid up several weeks earlier than expected. Part of me was just like "I'll just let it go.. and do it some other time.." but another part of me believes that we should follow our excitement and that where there's a will and a joyful and passionate purpose, there's a way. 

And so I'm appealing to my broader community to help me live this dream. 

And what better crowdfunding rewards to offer than super discount photography as a celebratory launch of my new business, Biomi' Photography (www.biomiphoto.com), where I'm specializing in personal branding photography. In a nutshell, I get to the heart of your business and co-create amazing images that will help to appeal to your followers, clients and future clients. 

So it is with great joy that I am bumping my prices way down and creating some new offerings just for this campaign, to make some high quality business/personal branding shoots affordable to new business owners or people wanting some general awesomeness. 

I know we've all got sweet cameras on our phones (remember when they used to be called "cameraphones" haha) but if you want some images that show you as a professional, doing your thing, being the most authentic version of you then I can definitely help :)

*However if you're just in business for the money or if you don't have any regard for the planet or other people in some way shape or form please desist and find yourself another photographer. Not. Interested.*

If I don't meet the threshold then I'll admit defeat and shelf the clown school idea for another day! 

I have a lot of fun ideas about sharing clownful joy with peeps in refugee camps, creating clowny sex and environmental educational shows, combine it with other embodiment practices and create a new modality, do corporate team building workshops.. all the things! I know that I have more ideas than I can probably ever possibly actually do (alone anyway!) and a wide variety of interests so I don't want to make any promises BUT suffice to say that this area excites me greatly and these skills will go to good use, whatever form that takes.

story:
Short Summary

Hi guys! I've been having an amazing time starting my family and raising little PJ Critelli, but I'm finally ready to get back into creating art (and not human beings!). I have wanted to put on Bus Stop by William Inge for about 20 years or so. The role of Cherie is very personal to me. She came from nothing and wants desperately to make something of herself even though life didn't hand her much. The play is an ensemble piece with many different characters who end up stuck together in a snow storm outside of Kansas City at Grace's Diner and Bus Stop. Marilyn Monroe herself produced this as a movie when she started her own production company because she also felt strongly about the character. Though I made my start with Marilyn impersonations, you won't find me doing Marilyn here. I have my own Cherie that I want to share. :)

I've been lucky enough to find two friends in the business to help co-create this piece with me. Shelly Snellman, another mom-actor friend I met 8 years ago while doing The Rocky Horror Show, and Jeff Fitzpatrick who I met through a mutual friend who recently passed (Charley Morgan); they were writing partners. We'd love to have the proceeds from one night's performance go to the Cancer Research Institute in honor of our friend Charley. 

We're looking to raise $7000 which seems like a lot for a play but, after budgeting our expenses, this amount will actually only cover the absolute necessities - play rights, venue fees, costumes, set building and labor, publicity, and printing, not to mention the rates for a professional cast and crew! We aren't looking to make money on this production, just to be able to put it up and keep ticket prices low! We actually will need more than this but will count ourselves lucky if we reach this goal!

To this end, we have gathered autographed materials from famous friends and other contributors to create a Celebrity Rummage Sale for you! Please remember that Christmas is coming! We have a ton of different items for different fans of almost anything. Please take a look through and see if there's anything you'd like for yourself or for a friend! 

If you've read this far, you're probably already a friend (HI FRIEND THANK YOU FOR BEING HERE!), so we know you'd love to help! Even if you don't find a perk suitable for you, or perhaps you can't afford to help financially, you could still help us out incredibly by sharing on your FB, Twitter, and  other social networks! We only have a little over a month to try and raise our funds so PLEASE share and re-share! Thank you for helping us create and supporting the arts!

story:
“At a local level in time people think things are fine, then things rapidly spiral out of control until they become unstoppable, and we wreak massive destruction on ourselves.” Tobias Stone 

Where will we be in 3 years? If the present is anything to go by, what awaits us isn’t cozy. 

Interweaving two story lines, 'Sleepwalkers' explores what happens when the fears and uncertainties of an entire community are ignored: when no viable option is provided by those in charge, who is left to take to the reigns? 

Meet the cast

The Production  

Berlin, 1929: Marta and Greta struggle to keep their cafe open. As Greta seeks refuge from daily uncertainties and angst in Berlin’s thriving jazz club scene, Marta is finding comfort in a seductive movement promising to restore the economy and save her cafe. 

Swindon, 2020: Nathan, in a similar fate, is desperate to rescue his cafe and ultimately survive. He becomes one of many rallying behind an ambitious young political party. His employee Jade meanwhile, only wants to flirt, drink and have fun; as long as her family can return back home to the UK soon, everything will be fine.

Despite living almost 100 years apart, the characters have all too many things in common. In one way or another, they are all sleepwalking. Going through the motions, deprived and disorientated, anything to ignore the fact that the times are ruled by fear and uncertainty. No one ever sees it coming. No one ever wants to believe it until it is actually happening.

Mirroring today's political landscape, 'Sleepwalkers' explores perspectives and opinions, often dismissed as 'uninformed' in liberal politics.

Created by two women, 'Sleepwalkers' is a dynamic production which is set against the sound of jazz music. A timely show, fun as well as relevant, that explores the actions and decisions that have inspired present Britain.

Who we are 

We - Flora Thomson and Jenny Kassner - are ThinkTwiceTheatre - a new writing theatre company exploring alternative perspectives; challenging what shapes our societal conventions and conformities and reflecting the humanity behind social and historical movements.

We are tired of exploring and hearing from the same old liberal voices. Alienating and dismissing entire social groups has led to the precarious political and societal situation we are in today. We need to start a dialogue and engage with people whose opinions we don't share, not despite our different life experiences but because of them. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need you to help us get the show to the Edinburgh Fringe. The Fringe is one of the country's best platforms for young companies to establish themselves as part of the UK theatre landscape. 

We have secured our venue, registered our show, cast our performers, now we need your support to help us pay for

  • Venue hire
  • Transport and accommodation for our cast 
  • Marketing materials (flyers/posters) 

For your kind support we can offer perks such as free tickets to our Edinburgh show, special mentions in our programmes and social media,  personalised thank you messages from Flora and Jenny, a copy of the play text and an exclusive VIP dinner with the cast and creatives behind the project! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us financially, please share this campaign with your networks!

And do give us a like on Facebook: 

https://www.facebook.com/ThinkTwiceTheatre/

And follow us on Twitter: 

http://@ThinkTwiceTh

Your support means the world to us.

story:
The Remembering Happens

I am a dancer and choreographer passionate about process and research.  When I make a dance I rely on time with dancers in a studio to shift and shape the ideas we are working with. For "The Remembering Happens" I have worked with three unique dancers: Daniela Antelo, Miranda Tadlock and jhon r. stronks. For the past 3 months we have engaged in a movement conversation shapeshifting the dance as we go. This type of process takes a great deal rehearsal time, but it allows the movement to be affected by each individual and fills the work with rich textures, tones and thoughts.  

It is important to me to compensate the people I work with because I know they are giving up time that could be dedicated to other work or to spending time with family and friends.  This is where I need your help. Your contribution will help me support the people who have given so much to this dance and to dance in general.

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $1500 through this campaign specifically to pay the dancers for their time. This amount covers 3 months of rehearsals and 2 performances.  (I will be looking to other funding sources to cover additional costs such as costumes and set.)

With this project I have been fortunate to have the cost of the rehearsal space and the performance venue covered by a space grant through Rice University.  While this has significantly reduced the cost of making the dance, there are many other expenses associated with making a dance performance.  The most important to me is dancer payment because the creativity, sweat, and love that Daniela, Miranda and jhon have contributed to the piece have made it a work of art that I could not have made on my own.  

Brian Buck designed a stunning set for this piece.  It is made up of strands of keys which sound like wind chimes when they move.   Anyone who donates $250 or more to the campaign will receive a mini wind chime made out of keys from the set. 

The Impact

"The Remembering Happens" holds a special place in my heart.  It is an exploration into memory and nostalgia.  The process has been vulnerable for me because through it I have attempted to shift both the content that I work with and the way in which I work with that content.  

I found a group of dancers that are highly skilled in performance and in improvisation.  Together we have made something that is a little wild, sometimes sad, and that conjures up the past while being reactive to the present moment.  I believe it is important to challenge ourselves to see beyond what we know.  Your support contributes to the research and development of new ideas and will help us take this work from rehearsal to performance.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially to this piece, you can support us by being present at one of the performances. More than anything we would love to share this piece with you and hear your thoughts and impressions.

You can find more information at  http://lryuill1.wixsite.com/loriyuilldance/upco...

Thank you!

story:
Cancer affects the majority of people at one point in their life.  A serious subject yes, but The Fourth Dog is a one hour comedy about breast cancer, marital breakdown, family baggage and grieving – what could be funnier?

Weddings bring the whole family together, and that’s when the problems start...  

It’s The Big Day and the Burney clan have assembled – including skeletons from the cupboard.  The bride is pregnant, the groom is unsure, the mother is stressed, and the aunt is in disgrace.  The grandparents haven’t stopped bickering for sixty years and don’t see why today should be any exception.  And the icing on the cake?  A couple of dead ancestors have turned up!  

What does it mean to be part of a family?  How does our heredity influence the way we love and hate, live and die?

Each show has a 20 minute Q&A with representatives from charities supporting Breast Cancer care. Audience members will also have the opportunity to browse 'after thought tables' to gain more information from a spectrum of pertinent experts from wig-makers to nutritionists to nipple tattoists, after performances on 4 / 6 / 7 July.

Amy and Gaye are passionate that theatre is for all and believe by highlighting health and social care issues within their productions, that it is an exciting way to entertain and educate. For each production Human Story Theatre partners with local communities and groups relevant to the issue being explored in the play. Professionals/members of these groups then come to lead post-show discussions with the aim of sign-posting the audience to their local services.

This show focuses on breast cancer and the BRCA 1 gene which is important to us because many people and their families/friends are affected by cancer in some shape or form. But also, the play is about family and we believe the play explores aspects of life and relationships that everyone can to relate to.

By supporting the show, you will be helping us to raise awareness of breast cancer and the local services available. We have partnered with Maggie’s Centre Oxford at The Churchill Hospital and Against Breast Cancer, Abingdon. Through our post-show Q&As with guest speakers we will be signposting the audience to the various relevant local support services. Through our more informal 'after thought tables' arena, we hope to enable people to get more of a chance to meet each other, talk about the play and then gain information and support systems for themselves and their families.

We have partial funding in place for the show from The Lottery Awards for All and The Arts Council England. However, high quality professional theatre (with a cast of six!) is expensive and we still need a further £5,500 to make sure we can afford to put the show on properly. This funding goes towards actors, director, producer and writer’s fees; marketing; venue hire etc. general running costs to put on a show.  Wherever possible we have a 'pay what you can' policy to ensure the production is accessible to everyone. Failing that, we have negotiated deals with theatre venues to keep the tickets at the lowest possible price. 

We have a few perks that we hope you will enjoy.  What ever you can donate, we are extremely grateful.  We hope to reach our goal, but if we don't we will still put the show on, although will have to give some more of our work/time in kind.

The Fourth Dog is a show everyone should see as it really highlights the family interactions and challenges that breast cancer can bring to a family unit. Not to mention it is a comedy! Having had success with Connie’s Colander (about Dementia) and Flat 73 (about loneliness and working with the Samaritans), it has showed us there is a need for more new plays with a contemporary theme at heart, which are thought-provoking and provide a forum for discussion and social interaction after each performance.

There is a risk of not getting funded, but this won't stop us! We believe there is a very clear need for accessible theatre exploring health and social care issues which is both entertaining and informative.  We have a professional team behind us with many years of experience within their fields to ensure that we can succeed.

We know times are tough so what ever you can donate is most gratefully appreciated.  IF you can't donate then the next most important thing is to spread the word.  We will ensure there are links through facebook, twitter and the web etc. but if you know anyone and can simply spread the message by talking to people or even putting up a poster in your local shop, then please do get in touch, we would love to hear from you.

Thank you so much for your support.

story:
Short Summary

We are so grateful to Dixon Place for the chance to get this play on its feet for the first time!

The Bastard: Two brothers await the arrival of their long lost older but probably hypothetical sister at their mother’s or father’s or possibly a stranger’s funeral. When the sister is no longer lost or hypothetical, the brothers are confronted with a conflicting account of who their parents were, and the sister is forced to face two men who resemble their father a bit too much for her liking.

Cast: Rob Hille, Monica Jones, Robby Ramos

Performance: July 1 @ 7:30pm

Venue:

Dixon Place

161A Chrystie St

New York, NY 10002

 

What We Need

Our budget is $2,000. The money will go to provide a modest stipend to the creative team as well as pay for rehearsal space. We don't need much to do this right, so every little bit can make a big difference!

 

The Impact

Support doesn't just go toward this one performance. Your contribution will help us hone this challenging piece and see how it can work for future productions. In addition, you are making it just a little easier for our actors to do the work they do.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate, we would love for you to come to the show and support us and Dixon Place with your presence. Bring a friend, buy a drink at the bar, and support Dixon Place's mission to promote emerging theatre artists.
