story:
Salamat to ALL of our Ba-e Makiling sponsors!! We have extended our Ba-e Makiling Crowdfunding Campaign to Monday, OCT 10, 11:59PM.

As of September 20th, our reward perks have slightly changed, in replace of Ba-e Makiling show tickets, for our funders who donate September 20th to October 10th, $50+ will receive Ba-e Makiling t-shirt(s).

- Please note perks displayed on the right side of the screen will not show the changes made, but we will confirm via email to remind you of your rewards. -

Inspired by the Philippine myth of Mariang Makiling, the creators of the new work Ba-e Makiling, fiercely reclaim the true essence of our rich indigenous Pilipino culture and identity.The deity is commonly referred to as Mariang or Maria a likely Hispanicization of her name during the colonial era and thankfully succeeded in hiding her stories from the destructive wrath of the Catholic friars. Ba-e Makiling is purely a work of fiction. It’s a re-imagination of Philippine culture before European contact from the perspective of contemporary Pilipino artists in the diaspora, Told in a courageous contemporary voice, the artists blur the boundaries of time,  artistic genres, spirit from the corporeal to tell a story relevant  and urgently needed in our current times.

In the tropical region of Laguna, Philippines a shape shifting deity transforms herself into a wild animal that is chased and cornered by a hunter. The animal attacks, injuring the hunter who loses consciousness. As he awakens, a woman of eternal youthful beauty, radiant brown skin, with black hair cascading to the forest floor, dressed in mist-like white clothing heals the hunter. In the process he falls in love with her. Fearing for his life, his clan forcefully conducts a ritual to drive the spirit who had possessed him. Creators of Ba-e Makiling hope to present a different perspective of this story and transform it as a metaphor for the restoration of the indigenous self that’s been forcibly denied.

To be performed by eleven dancers, the choreography for Ba-e Makiling is informed by Philippine dance master Loyola’s experience as a principal dancer of Bayanihan Dance Company and his life-long dedication to Philippine dance.  For Ba-e, Jay investigates the possible origins of rural dances by deconstructing the movements, informed by his deep knowledge of indigenous and traditional Filipino dance. Florante Aguilar’s original music score is primarily driven by percussion instruments of gongs, drums and indigenous xylophones.

Director Alleluia Panis drew inspiration for the work’s title from stories passed onto her from her father about his hometown of Los Baños, Laguna, “He would always say Laguna de Bai or Laguna de Ba-e.” The diwata is said to bathe in the waters of Laguna de Bay (Ba-e) in Tagalog Lawa Ng Bae, the largest lake in the Philippines at the foot of Mount Makiling. Hence the title of the piece takes on roots of the classic Tagalog ‘bae’ meaning lady.

Eleven dancers have committed multiple hours on a weekly basis rehearsing from one studio to the next  throughout San Francisco including The Annex, LINES Dance Center, Bayanihan Community Center and finally Bindlestiff Studio. Composer Florante has dedicated hours to completing the original score. Media/Tech go-to Wilfred Galila has taken hundreds of photographs and video footage used throughout production, costume designer June Arellano has logged long hours with his Philippine artisans to create radiant costumes featured in the show, visual artist Kristian Kabuay created various drafts of the Ba-e Makiling baybayin script, and we have brought on brilliant visual artist Cece Carpio to design and paint the  astonishing tropical universe of Ba-e Makiling.

Be a part of this phenomenal new work, support the production and make a tax-deductible donation today! 

Raised funds will allow us to increase fees for artists and designers, who are dedicated to making this innovative project come to life.

Support Ba-e Makiling! Help us create a dynamic experience that we hope empowers us to throw away the deplorable mantle of colonization and embrace the wisdom of our indigenous core!

For over 30 years Kularts, the nation’s premier presenter of contemporary and tribal Pilipino arts organization has presented over 2,000 artists to over one million audiences in the Bay Area, across the US and internationally. Ba-e Makiling is third in a series of commissioned works choreographed by Jay Loyola based on the elements of air, water, and earth. The first “Palau’an Bird Call – Huni ng Tandikan” (2012, element: air), then “Maség, Typhoon” (2014, element: water) and this September, 2016, element: earth. This is the second collaboration with Florante Aguilar as composer.

Each and every individual involved in the making of Ba-e Makiling informs the work in tremendous ways. Since its inception two year ago, the work has been a truly collaborative bayanihan effort.  

Be a funder bayanihan style! Help carry this extraordinary group of creators!

In appreciation we have gifts for all levels of support.

Salamat at Mabuhay!!

Kularts presents the world premiere of Ba-e Makiling

Weekend I:

FRI SEPT 9, 7:30 PM | SAT SEPT 10, Matinee – 2:30 PM & 7:30 PM | SUN SEPT 11, Matinee – 2:30 PM

Weekend II:

FRI Sept 16, 7:30 PM | SAT SEPT 17, Matinee – 2:30 PM & 7:30 PM | SUN SEPT 18, Matinee – 2:30 PM

Bindlestiff Studio

185 - 6th Street San Francisco, CA

Advance Online Tickets: http://ba-emakiling.bpt.me/

Advance: $18, at the door: $22

The full-length 50 minute dance theater piece will be performed by eleven dancers: Isa Musni, Jonathan Mercado, Danielle Cruz Galvez, Frances Sedayao, Ronald Inocencio, June Arellano, Stephanie Herrera, Darren Garza, Eden Alcomendas,  Alysia Beltran and Dennison Gallardo to an original score inspired by the Philippine traditional musical genre of percussion gongs,  chants,  drums and flute by Florante Aguilar, creator of the award-winning documentary, Harana: The Search for the Lost Art of Serenade, two weekends at Bindlestiff Studio in the South of Market (SoMa).

For more information about the characters, story and Ba-e Makiling production visit: http://kularts.org/wp/kularts-presents/works-by-jay-loyola/bae-makiling/

*DISCLAIMER: Ticket rewards are only available to funders who participate in our Indiegogo campaign: Wed Aug 24 to Thurs Sept 15, 2016.*

*NEW UPDATE: All funders as of Sept 20 to Oct 10 will receive Ba-e Makiling t-shirts in replace of Ba-e Makiling show tickets.*

Ba-e Makiling is a $35,000 dollar project. We are asking for your tax deductible contribution to help raise the $10,000 dollars we need to match awarded grant from the  National Endowment for the Arts and the San Francisco Arts Commission.

Funds from you will be used for increased artists and designers’ fees

ADDITIONAL REWARD NOTES: 

1) Reward tiers including tote bag(s) will add a $2 shipping fee for each bag.

2) Tote bags & T-Shirts will be shipped by December 1, 2016.

If you have any additional questions please contact: info@kularts.org

Our reward tier levels are named after Philippine indigenous trees! Here's some fun facts about the trees that inspired us:

Bamboo: Tree of Life 

Coconut: Tree of Life 

Pili: Highly nutritious nut. It’s essential oil is used in manufacturing of fragrances and perfume

Lanete: wood used cabinets, wood carving, and musical instruments. Leaves and bark used for indigenous medicine

Yakal: used for high grade construction for its durability and strength

Kamagong: edible fruit; beautiful grained black hard wood used for furniture and music instruments

Magkono: dubbed ‘iron wood’ and can lasts for hundreds of years without decay

Narra: hardwood, termite resistant, leaves used in folk medicine, edible flowers & leaves, the national tree of the Philippines

Founded in 1985, Kularts is the premier presenter of contemporary and tribal Pilipino art works in the United States. We are a non-profit arts organization based in San Francisco, California. 

Founded in 1985, Kularts is the premier presenter of contemporary and tribal Pilipino arts in the United States. We are a non-profit arts organization based in San Francisco, California. Kularts presents and produce tribal and contemporary Pilipino art works.

Our mission is to inform and expand the understanding of American Pilipino culture and preserve the spirit and integrity of ancient Pilipino art forms. We produce innovative artistic works; foster mentorship among emerging and established artists; facilitate local and international collaborations; design and implement educational outreach programs and lead cultural tours to the Philippines.

Jay Loyola, Choreographer:

Master Artist of Philippine Dance has created over 50 Pilipino folk dance works performed in Asia, Europe, and the United States. Loyola traveled the world as a principal dancer for the prestigious Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company; a protégé of Philippine National Artist in Dance Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula. He was adopted into the Tagbanua tribe. Loyola established the all-indigenous Palawan Dance Theater. He migrated to the US in 2006 and became Dance Director of SF’s LIKHA Pilipino Folk Ensemble 2007-08, creating major works Sembà and Kadayawan with Rudy Soriano. Barangay Dance Co commissioned him to choreograph Pakidwa (2010) and People of the Current (2011). Loyola has received grant awards from the Hewlett Foundation, Zellerbach Family Foundation, San Francisco Arts Foundation, Creative Work Fund and the National Endowment for the Arts. Kularts commissioned Loyola to create Huni (2012) and Maség (2014). Loyola is a professor of Philippine Dance and Culture at University of San Francisco and the founding Artistic Director of the American Center of Philippine Arts. Ba-e Makiling is the third time Kularts is commissioning Loyola as the master artist in dance and choreography.

Florante Aguilar, Composer:

Composer and Lyricist, is a leading proponent of Philippine harana and guitar music in the US today. Aguilar grew up in Cavite where he learned to play the octavina in a rondalla group. He trained as a classical musician at the University of the Philippines College of Music. With a scholarship he studied at the Manhattan School of Music with Sharon Isbin. He later toured with the Buffalo Guitar Quartet and recorded New Music for Four Guitars (New World 384-2). He received his Bachelor of Music Degree at the SF Conservatory of Music (1996) under David Tanenbaum. In 2012, Aguilar joined director Benito Bautista to create the film Harana. It won awards at (2012) Hawaiian International Film Festival, (2013) SF CAAMFest and (2013) Pac Arts Movement in San Diego. He has completed Kularts commissions: Lalawigan (2009) and Aswang (2013) and was the composer for Maség (2014). He is one of the lead artists in Fandango-Pandanggo, multidisciplinary performance exploring musical connections between the Philippines, Mexico, Cuba and Spain through new compositions, world premiere May 2016. Ba-e Makiling is the second project Aguilar joins Kularts and Loyola as composer.

Alleluia Panis, Director:

Kularts Artistic & Executive Director, is the driving force behind Kularts and respected elder artist in the US and the Philippines. She is at home in both contemporary and tribal arts. One of the founding members of Kularts, Panis has served as the Director since its inception in 1985. She has created 15 full-length dance theater works since 1980. As an individual artist, she has received grant awards from the Rockefeller Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts, New Langton Arts, the SFAC-Individual Artist, Creative Work Fund, and The Gerbode Foundation. Her work has been performed on main stages in the United States, Europe, and Asia. She was the managing director for ODC Theater (1995-97) and for Brava Theater Center (1998-2001). Panis annually returns to the Philippines for study and research. She’s a board member of API Cultural Center and Yerba Buena Events.

Master Artist of Philippine Dance
has created over 50 Pilipino folk dance works performed in Asia, Europe, and
the United States. Loyola traveled the world as a principal dancer for the
prestigious Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company; a protégé of
Philippine National Artist in Dance Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula. He was adopted into
the Tagbanua tribe. Loyola established the all-indigenous Palawan Dance
Theater. He migrated to the US in 2006 and became Dance Director of SF’s LIKHA
Pilipino Folk Ensemble 2007-08, creating major works Sembà and Kadayawan with
Rudy Soriano. Barangay Dance Co commissioned him to choreograph Pakidwa (2010)
and People of the Current (2011). Loyola has received grant awards from the
Hewlett Foundation, Zellerbach Family Foundation, San Francisco Arts
Foundation, Creative Work Fund and the National Endowment for the Arts. Kularts
commissioned Loyola to create Huni (2012) and Maség (2014). Loyola is a
professor of Philippine Dance and Culture at University of San Francisco and
the founding Artistic Director of the American Center of Philippine Arts. Ba-e
Makiling is the third time Kularts is commissioning Loyola as the master artist
in dance and choreography.
Florante Aguilar, Composer:
Composer and Lyricist, is a
leading proponent of Philippine harana and guitar music in the US today.
Aguilar grew up in Cavite where he learned to play the octavina in a rondalla
group. He trained as a classical musician at the University of the Philippines
College of Music. With a scholarship he studied at the Manhattan School of
Music with Sharon Isbin. He later toured with the Buffalo Guitar Quartet and
recorded New Music for Four Guitars (New World 384-2). He received his Bachelor
of Music Degree at the SF Conservatory of Music (1996) under David Tanenbaum.
In 2012, Aguilar joined director Benito Bautista to create the film Harana. It
won awards at (2012) Hawaiian International Film Festival, (2013) SF CAAMFest
and (2013) Pac Arts Movement in San Diego. He has completed Kularts
commissions: Lalawigan (2009) and Aswang (2013) and was the composer for Maség
(2014). He is one of the lead artists in Fandango-Pandanggo, multidisciplinary
performance exploring musical connections between the Philippines, Mexico, Cuba
and Spain through new compositions, world premiere May 2016. Ba-e Makiling is
the second project Aguilar joins Kularts and Loyola as composer.
Alleluia Panis, Director:

Kularts Artistic &
Executive Director, is the driving force behind Kularts and respected elder
artist in the US and the Philippines. She is at home in both contemporary and
tribal arts. One of the founding members of Kularts, Panis has served as the
Director since its inception in 1985. She has created 15 full-length dance
theater works since 1980. As an individual artist, she has received grant
awards from the Rockefeller Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts,
New Langton Arts, the SFAC-Individual Artist, Creative Work Fund, and The
Gerbode Foundation. Her work has been performed on main stages in the United
States, Europe, and Asia. She was the managing director for ODC Theater
(1995-97) and for Brava Theater Center (1998-2001). Panis annually returns to
the Philippines for study and research. She’s a board member of API Cultural
Center and Yerba Buena Events.

story:
About Skipping Stones Theatre

We are a small theatre collective, formed by people who all started in the same place, but started hopping to new places to learn and explore. We're based in the Greater Toronto Area, but have an international perspective, acquired through study in North America, Europe, and Asia.

Art commonly offers insight to someone else's experience, but in rare moments art will allow us to better understand ourselves. We could all use a bit of help with understanding who we are - the most important step towards becoming the best version of ourselves. 

https://www.skippingstonestheatre.com/

About Coriolanus

One of Shakespeare's less frequently performed plays, this ancient Roman thriller pits a star general against the common people of the very city he fights for. Without any clear way to reconcile his disdain for the citizens with his love for the country, Caius Martius Coriolanus finds himself driven into the embrace of his sworn enemy.

Our production focuses on the ramifications of blind nationalism, and the delusions of identity we use to justify our actions. Set on the Eastern Front of World War One, this show explores the disillusionment of civility, akin to that seen during the era of the Great War. #NationalismGoneWild

The Impact

Why $2,154?

As a company, we have two goals:

1) To tell our stories with integrity.

2) To PAY our artists.

The scope of this project is far greater than we've ever undertaken. As our current budget is based on a profit-share model, covering our overhead costs will allow us to financially support our independent artists. We make a concerted effort to keep our production costs low through the classic tactic of "Reduce. Reuse. Recycle."

 Venue rental for Coriolanus will be approximately $1000. The remaining will contribute to sets, costumes, props, rehearsal spaces, administrative costs and marketing. The more of these physical costs we can cover before ticket sales, the more able we are to provide our artists with a respectable salary. Below is a more specified breakdown of where our crowdfunding campaign will be going:

Performance rental: $924

Rehearsal halls: $290

Marketing: $225

Costume, Set & Props: $515

Admin: $50

Photographer: $150

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that there are always numerous projects looking for help, so anything you can do to support these projects is HIGHLY appreciated. We will do everything we can artistically to earn your support, but as we are not above bribery, check out our YUMMY PERKS 'cause they're wicked awesome.

Want to further help us out? Spread the word:  Either by word of mouth and/or social media. You can share our crowdfunding page via Facebook and Twitter. We'll love you for it!!!

Thanks, and Thanks, and Ever Thanks.

We thank you greatly in advance and look forward to bringing you William Shakespeare's CORIOLANUS This November 1-4 at Kensington Hall, Toronto!

Much love,

Skipping Stones Theatre

story:
Invitados a La Habana / Invited to Havana

     Somos un grupo de teatro independiente que viene trabajando desde 1999 de manera totalmente autogestionada, sin apoyo de ninguna institución. Hacemos obras propias y originales de creación colectiva y hemos creado ya diez obras. En esta ocasión hemos sido invitados para representar al Perú en la edición número 16 del Festival Internacional de Teatro de La Habana. Iremos con la última versión de nuestra obra más reciente: "Los Ladrones", cuya primera versión se estrenó en agosto del año pasado.

  We are an independent theatre group that works since its foundation in 1999 without any official support. We make our own original devised plays and have created ten plays to date. We have been invited to the 16th Havana International Theatre Festival. We’d go with the last version of our newest play: “The Thieves”, whose first version opened August 2014.

CUER2: https://www.facebook.com/CUER2

Fondos para poder asistir / Funds to attend

     Esta campaña es para recaudar los fondos que nos permitan asistir al festival. Como ya es bien sabido, grupos de teatro contemporáneo como el nuestro, que crean el arte y la cultura de hoy, no tienen cabida en las políticas gubernamentales de nuestro país, que por ejemplo, es uno de los pocos en Sudamérica que carece de un Festival Internacional de Teatro organizado por instituciones oficiales, como sí ocurre en Colombia, Chile, Brasil y Argentina. Cuba, por otro lado, es un país reconocido por su gran apoyo al desarrollo espiritual y cultural de su gente, por lo cual este festival es una plataforma que nos permitirá mostrar nuestro trabajo a representantes del teatro del más alto nivel, entre quienes se encuentra el reconocido director teatral inglés Peter Brook, quien celebrará sus noventa años de vida en este evento.

  This campaign is to collect the funds that would allow us to attend the Festival. It’s well known that contemporary theatre groups like ours, which create today’s art and culture, don’t have a place in our country’s policies, being Peru one of the few in South America which doesn’t have an International Theatre Festival, as opposed to Colombia, Chile, Brazil and Argentina. On the other hand, Cuba is well known for the support given to the spiritual and cultural development of its people, which is why this festival will allow us to show our work to representatives of the highest level, like the renowned English theatre director Peter Brook, who will be celebrating his 90th birthday in this event.

Qué significa el festival / The meaning of the Festival

     El mayor logro de un artista es poder compartir su arte con el público y poder confrontar sus propuestas con otros artistas de diferentes contextos. Este festival permitirá no sólo que se conozca nuestro trabajo a nivel internacional, sino también que aprendamos sobre lo que se está haciendo en otros lugares. Es un evento importantísimo al que debemos tratar de asistir para poder darle a nuestro trabajo el valor que se merece.

     Sin embargo, si bien hasta ahora no hemos dejado que lo económico nos impida lograr nuestros sueños y dedicarnos con todas nuestras fuerzas al arte que nos apasiona, la realidad es que dar este gran paso cuesta mucho dinero, sin el cual no podremos llevar la obra a Cuba, y por eso iniciamos esta campaña, que estamos seguros será exitosa gracias al apoyo de todos ustedes, que saben que a los sueños no se les puede dejar morir, y menos cuando gozan de tan buena salud.

  An artist’s greatest achievement is to be able to share their work with audiences and confront their proposals with other artists from different contexts. This Festival will let us show our work at an international level and learn about what is being done in other places. We should attend this very important event to give our work the value it deserves.

  However, even if until now we haven’t allowed economic issues to prevent us from achieving our dreams and dedicate ourselves to the art we love, the reality is that taking this big step costs a lot of money, without which we won’t be able to take our play to Cuba, and that is why we started this campaign, which will surely be successful thanks to your support, because you know that you can’t let dreams die, least of all when they’re in such good shape.

Juntos podemos / Together we can

     Concretamente, necesitamos $4500 para los pasajes y estadía. Somos cinco integrantes: Roberto (director), Kiara (asistente de dirección), Roly (actor), Milagros (actriz) y Felipe (actor). Los pasajes cuestan alrededor de $800 cada uno, y estamos calculando unos $100 por persona para una estadía de los diez días que dura el festival. Cada aporte será bienvenido para sumar hacia el fondo que nos permita lograr esta meta, ya que el grupo está conformado en su mayoría por jóvenes que están terminando sus estudios y quieren sentir que vale la pena seguir dedicándose con el mismo compromiso a una de las artes más antiguas de la humanidad.

     Estamos muy contentos con la última versión de esta obra en particular y estamos seguros de que con ella vamos a causar una gran impresión en el evento, daremos de qué hablar y fortaleceremos el interés por el teatro peruano contemporáneo. Es una obra acerca de dos ladrones que entran en una casa a realizar las órdenes que han recibido. Parte de la pregunta por la relación entre la ley y su ejecución, y se desarrolla en un juego de fragmentos, indicios y desplazamientos. Muchos de ustedes ya la han visto y les podemos asegurar que esta versión está aún mejor. El festival será la plataforma que nos permita establecer las redes para que CUER2 por fin tenga una mayor presencia entre los colectivos más interesantes del teatro contemporáneo.

  Concretely, we need $4500 for travel and lodging. We are five members: Roberto (director), Kiara (assistant director), Roly (actor), Milagros (actress) and Felipe (actor). The plane tickets cost around $800 each, and we are calculating approximately $100 per person to stay the ten days that the festival lasts. Each donation will be most welcome to add to the fund that will let us achieve this goal, since the group is formed mostly by young artists who are finishing their higher education and want to feel that it’s worthwhile to keep their commitment to one of mankind’s most ancient arts.

  We are very proud of the last version of this particular play and are sure that with it we are going to give a great impression in the event, and will strengthen the interest for contemporary Peruvian theatre. It is a play about two thieves entering a house to fulfill the orders they have received. It addresses the issue of the law and its execution, and engages in a game of fragments, pointers and displacements. Many of you have already seen the play and we can assure you that this version is even better. The Festival will be the platform which will let us establish the networks for CUER2 to have at last a greater presence amongst the most interesting contemporary theatre groups.

Cómo apoyarnos/How to support

     Si son de los que alguna vez han dicho "Me gusta el teatro.", esta es su oportunidad de demostrarlo. El apoyo que todos y cada uno de ustedes nos pueda brindar, por más pequeño que sea, a través de sus donaciones por medio de esta página, será recibido de todo corazón y sumará a una causa que nos permita seguir creyendo en lo que hacemos. Por ello también es fundamental su ayuda en la difusión de esta campaña, incluso si no pudieran donar, para que todos aquellos que quieran y puedan colaborar se sumen a esta iniciativa. Pueden usar las herramientas de esta página a través de Facebook, Twitter, etc. Estaremos eternamente agradecidos.

  If you have ever said “I like Theatre.”, then this is your chance to prove it. The support, big or small, that each and every one of you can give us with your donations through this page, will be warmly received and will add up to a cause that will let us keep believing in what we do. That’s why, even if you can’t donate, your help in spreading the word is fundamental, so that all of those who want and can collaborate can join in this campaign. You can use this site’s tools through Facebook, Twitter, etc. We will be forever grateful.

story:
"With dinner theater action and peanut gallery voyeurism, Ken Roht and a fabulous service crew dish up a sublime franchise benchmark."Los Angeles Times 

The initial iteration of Orange Star Dinner Show enjoyed a three-month, sold-out run in Los Angeles, at the Evidence Room Theater. Director/choreographer Ken Roht and co-composer/arranger John Ballinger have created many whimsical-surrealist, music theater spectacles together, and Orange Star Dinner Show, a dinner theater spectacle, is an audience favorite!

The unlikely plot for this country musical farce focuses on Mama and her grown-up kids. Mama's crazed obsession with the famed ladies vocal trio, The Andrew Sisters, forced her to raise her infant son, Green Clover, as a girl, so that Green and her younger sister, Orange Star, could form the foundation of the next great sister trio. However, Mama's third child, Yellow Moon, was born a boy, and all of Mama's hopes were dashed. Orange Star, the sane, middle child and Mama's favorite, picked up the pieces of Mama's shattered dreams, grew into a formidable (read: pathological) caretaker, and finally into the queen of her own Wyoming dinner theater, Orange Star Dinner Show. On this night, Green Clover is finally over it!  She resentfully sabotages Orange's dinner show and reveals the big secret to all. She's a he! The rest of the family, with big secrets of their own, attempt to keep up appearances as they reel from the drama. After all, the dinner show must go on!

With your donation, we will engage in a two week workshop, with ten awesome performers and a core team of progressive music, video and sound designers, that will create a presentation of the entire musical. This presentation will be designed to garner the support of investors who will help to turn Orange Star Dinner Show into an international, franchise show for the whole family to enjoy.  

We need your help to take our big, first steps!


Our Team:

Ken Roht is a theater and film artist in Los Angeles.
His most recent project, Perfect Cowboy, an Alternative
Family film, received its World Premiere at Outfest Film
Festival, with Ken as one of the "5 in Focus" writer/directors to watch. Ken is a recipient of the Audrey Skirball-Kenis TIME grant. Miss Julie(n), Roht's
music theater adaptation of Strindberg's classic, was produced at the MorYork Gallery in Los Angeles. Ken adapted, directed and choreographed Duke Ellington's
Queenie Pie, for Long Beach Opera and Chicago Opera Theater. As a Department of Cultural Affairs COLA grant recipient, Ken’s opera, Permissible Union, premiered at
L.A. Grand Performance. Ken is the creator of the wildly successful 99c Only Holiday Spectacles; eight unique, music theater pieces from 2002 to 2011. As a director/choreographer, Ken has worked at Bard Music Festival and in the Spiegeltent in New York; Theatre @ Boston Court, Largo at the Coronet, Warner Grand Theater, Getty Villa, Evidence Room and Playwrights Arena in Los Angeles. As a choreographer, Mark Taper Forum (for Moises Kaufman), New York City Opera, New York Philharmonic (for Michael Counts), Playwrights Horizons, Oregon Shakespeare Festival (seven seasons) Center Theater Group, La Jolla Playhouse, Yale Rep, Walt Disney Company, and for experimental auteur Reza Abdoh for seven years.

John Ballinger is a Los Angeles based composer, arranger and multi-faceted instrumentalist. His music and sound design highlights: Joan Rivers: a Work in Progress by a life in Progress, Coney Island Christmas, Death of the Author at the Geffen Playhouse; The Projectionist, Kirk Douglas Theater; Midsummer Night's Dream, The Borrowers, Fast Company, South Coast Rep; Echo's Hammer, 1001, The Gov't Inspector , Boston Court: Ken Roht's 99c Holiday spectacles (six seasons) As a performer/instrumentalist: Rufus Wainwright's Poses national tour; first national tour of Dancing with the Stars

Kevin Cunningham is founder of Wet Electrics and serves as its Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Cunningham serves as Executive Artistic Director of 3-Legged Dog Media and Theatre Group. He also serves as Chief Executive Officer of Shape of Time, Inc. Kevin has been instrumental in driving the direction and growth of 3-Legged Dog and its products since its inception, effectively advocating Production Designer’s goals, securing initial financing for it and developing its advisory board and staff. He has directed, produced and designed shows at numerous venues, including Signature Theatre, Ontological Theater and Lincoln Center. Mr. Cunningham is an associate professor at the School for Visual Arts Computer Arts Department and a project director at New York University Center for Advanced Technology.

Michael Counts is a theatrical designer and stage director, visual artist, and media and entertainment entrepreneur focusing on creating large-scale immersive installations, theatrical productions and innovative media and entertainment experiences, often in unconventional spaces, for the last 20 years. As one of the early pioneers of immersive theater he has been called a “visionary” and a“mad genius” by the New York Times and “one of the most fertile imaginations working in New York City today” by Time Out New York Magazine.

Two of Michael’s recent productions (Moses in Egypt with New York City Opera and Philharmonic 360 with the New York Philharmonic) were listed on the New York Times Top 10 Lists for 2011. His 2014 brand launch for Michael Kors in Shanghai will be remounted in Tokyo in 2015 and in Dubai and Seoul, Korea in 2016. His recent work on the Walking Dead Escape, an immersive experience extension of the TV, comic book and video game franchise, was called “the high point of the 2014 San Diego Comic Con” by Oculus VR CEO, Brendan Iribe.

Upcoming productions include: a 60 foot tall projection mapped permanent video installation at the Lake Nona Town Center in Orlando, Florida; The Anne Geddes Experience – an immersive theatrical exhibition of Anne Geddes’ photographic works over the last 20; the Ouroboros Trilogy, an Opera production that will complete the Pulitzer Prize winning Madame White Snake with the addition of two new operas Naga and Gilgamesh, in 2016; Permadeath, by librettist/producer Cerise Jacobs, which will be the first fully staged video game opera that will launch at Pax East in 2017.

Sharon Counts is an actor, director and producer. She is currently directing and co-writing Calloway’s Salon, a monthly cabaret show at Three's Brewing. Last winter, Sharon was in Miami where she directed a show for the National Young Arts Foundation. This past summer, Sharon directed a one-man show in the 2014 NYC Fringe Festival called Fearless that won a "Best Of Solo Show " Fringe Award. Also this past summer, Sharon co- produced and performed in Play/Date, an immersive theatrical experience at Fat Baby hailed by Time Out New York as "The next level of immersive theater." Recently, Sharon directed Jim Silverstein's Will by Isidore Elias for the Fresh Produce'd Festival. Sharon has worked extensively in arts management with such organizations as GAle GAtes et al. and Blue Man Group. This summer Sharon will head to the Williamstown Theatre Festival to teach a master class and to begin developing a new immersive production that will launch in summer 2016.

Emily Sophia Knapp is a New York City producer currently working on non- profit productions with Tilted Field and Caborca Theatre and on commercial projects with Green Curtain Productions. Broadway: Associate Director, All The Way (Tony Award: Best Play, Best Actor). Regional: 7 seasons at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. Also Brooklyn Academy of Music, Berkeley Rep, Goodman, Guthrie, McCarter, Wuzhen Theatre Festival (China). 2012 OSF Artistic Office Fellow.
story_txt:
"With dinner theater action and peanut gallery voyeurism, Ken Roht and a fabulous service crew dish up a sublime franchise benchmark."Los Angeles Times The initial iteration of Orange Star Dinner Show enjoyed a three-month, sold-out run in Los Angeles, at the Evidence Room Theater. Director/choreographer Ken Roht and co-composer/arranger John Ballinger have created many whimsical-surrealist, music theater spectacles together, and Orange Star Dinner Show, a dinner theater spectacle, is an audience favorite!The unlikely plot for this country musical farce focuses on Mama and her grown-up kids. Mama's crazed obsession with the famed ladies vocal trio, The Andrew Sisters, forced her to raise her infant son, Green Clover, as a girl, so that Green and her younger sister, Orange Star, could form the foundation of the next great sister trio. However, Mama's third child, Yellow Moon, was born a boy, and all of Mama's hopes were dashed. Orange Star, the sane, middle child and Mama's favorite, picked up the pieces of Mama's shattered dreams, grew into a formidable (read: pathological) caretaker, and finally into the queen of her own Wyoming dinner theater, Orange Star Dinner Show. On this night, Green Clover is finally over it!  She resentfully sabotages Orange's dinner show and reveals the big secret to all. She's a he! The rest of the family, with big secrets of their own, attempt to keep up appearances as they reel from the drama. After all, the dinner show must go on!With your donation, we will engage in a two week workshop, with ten awesome performers and a core team of progressive music, video and sound designers, that will create a presentation of the entire musical. This presentation will be designed to garner the support of investors who will help to turn Orange Star Dinner Show into an international, franchise show for the whole family to enjoy.  We need your help to take our big, first steps!Our Team:
Ken
Roht is a theater and film artist in Los
Angeles.
His most recent project, Perfect Cowboy, an Alternative
Family film, received its World Premiere at Outfest Film
Festival, with Ken as one of the "5 in Focus" writer/directors to watch. Ken is a recipient of the Audrey Skirball-Kenis TIME grant. Miss Julie(n), Roht's
music theater adaptation of Strindberg's classic, was produced at the MorYork Gallery in Los Angeles. Ken adapted, directed and choreographed Duke Ellington's
Queenie Pie, for Long Beach Opera and Chicago Opera Theater. As a Department of Cultural Affairs COLA grant recipient, Ken’s opera, Permissible Union, premiered at
L.A. Grand Performance. Ken is the creator of the wildly successful 99c Only
Holiday Spectacles; eight unique, music theater pieces from 2002 to 2011. As a
director/choreographer, Ken has worked at Bard Music Festival and in the
Spiegeltent in New York; Theatre @ Boston Court, Largo at the Coronet, Warner
Grand Theater, Getty Villa, Evidence Room and Playwrights Arena in Los Angeles.
As a choreographer, Mark Taper Forum (for Moises Kaufman), New York City Opera,
New York Philharmonic (for Michael Counts), Playwrights Horizons, Oregon
Shakespeare Festival (seven seasons) Center Theater Group, La Jolla Playhouse,
Yale Rep, Walt Disney Company, and for experimental auteur Reza Abdoh for seven
years. 

John
 Ballinger is a Los Angeles based composer, arranger and multi-faceted 
instrumentalist. His music and sound design highlights: Joan Rivers: a Work in
Progress by a life in Progress, Coney Island Christmas, Death of the Author at
the Geffen Playhouse; The Projectionist, Kirk Douglas Theater; Midsummer
Night's Dream, The Borrowers, Fast Company, South Coast Rep; Echo's
Hammer, 1001, The Gov't Inspector , Boston Court: Ken Roht's 99c Holiday
spectacles (six seasons) As a performer/instrumentalist: Rufus Wainwright's
Poses national tour; first national tour of Dancing with the Stars Kevin
Cunningham is founder of Wet Electrics and serves
as its Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Cunningham serves as Executive Artistic
Director of 3-Legged Dog Media and Theatre Group. He also serves as Chief
Executive Officer of Shape of Time, Inc. Kevin has been instrumental in driving
the direction and growth of 3-Legged Dog and its products since its inception,
effectively advocating Production Designer’s goals, securing initial financing
for it and developing its advisory board and staff. He has directed, produced
and designed shows at numerous venues, including Signature Theatre, Ontological
Theater and Lincoln Center. Mr. Cunningham is an associate professor at the
School for Visual Arts Computer Arts Department and a project director at New
York University Center for Advanced Technology.



Michael Counts is
a theatrical designer and stage director, visual artist, and media and
entertainment entrepreneur focusing on creating large-scale immersive
installations, theatrical productions and innovative media and entertainment
experiences, often in unconventional spaces, for the last 20 years. As one of
the early pioneers of immersive theater he has been called a “visionary” and
a“mad genius” by the New York Times and “one of the most fertile imaginations
working in New York City today” by Time Out New York Magazine. 
Two of Michael’s recent productions (Moses in Egypt with New

Michael Kors in Shanghai will be remounted in Tokyo in 2015 and in Dubai and
Seoul, Korea in 2016. His recent work on the Walking Dead Escape, an immersive
experience extension of the TV, comic book and video game franchise, was called

Iribe.

addition of two new operas Naga and Gilgamesh, in 2016; Permadeath, by

Counts is an actor, director and producer. She is currently directing and co-writing Calloway’s Salon, a monthly

show for the National Young Arts Foundation. This past summer, Sharon directed

story:
Short Summary

Zombie Joe's Underground Theatre Group Proudly Presents The World Premiere of Ramon Sanchez's musical vampire love story.  Anthony and Roxanna's bond of eternal love is challenged by their adventurous lust for human flesh and Roxanna's drive for redemption.  Directed by Denise Devin and Produced by Zombie Joe.

4 weekends only, Fridays and Saturdays at 8:30pm, ZJU Theatre Group, 4850 Lankershim Blvd., North Hollywood, CA, 91601. Opens Friday, September 4, 2015, closes Saturday, September 26, 2015.

ZJU Theatre Group, in its ever-present need to expand it's theatrical boundaries, approached Los Angeles-based songwriter and playwright Ramon Sanchez last Christmas to further develop his passionate love story, and ZJU’s Lead-Director Denise Devin is excited to bring Ramon’s vampiric-musical to life at ZJU.  Zombie Joe’s Underground has a long history of supporting original work, from inside the group as well as outside the company, and their established, edgy, and experimental theatre in the NOHO Arts District of North Hollywood proves the perfect home for "The Red Moon”.


What We Need & What You Get

Why we need to raise $600.00 for this show:

We are producing a brand new musical, and it’s a vampire musical – mystical, otherworldly, with characters who have special powers. We would like to build in some “extras” that go outside a normal Zombie Joe show budget to truly bring this show to life, and add even more fun for the audience:

Special items:

  • Magical box – to be built by our carpenter to allow for someone to magically appear and disappear
  • Vampire killing knives that need to be tempered for safety
  • Expensive fangs the actors can wear throughout the show – with spares
  • Costumes/jackets that can hide “tricks for magic”
  • Costumes/masks for demons
  • Blood for the run of the show
  • Special show lights with gels
  • Pay for the actors – we would love to be able to give them a small financial remuneration at the end of the show, for going the extra mile. We love our actors.
What you get: Tickets to the show! Eternal, virtual Vampire Kisses, our undead love! See these great perks in the Perk section.

And if we don't reach our full goal, we have decided the actors come first, then blood, then knives and fangs, then the magical tricks. Please help us, we want Ramon's new play to get the best from us.

Who are we:
Ramon Sanchez, an exciting new Los Angeles based playwright/songwriter, has been writing music since he majored in theatre arts at San Jose State University and minored in music. After graduating, he wrote scripts for a variety of projects, including radio dramas and independent films. These include writing and performing music for "Much Ado About Nothing", Shakespeare by the Sea, San Pedro, California, writing, directing and starring in the independent film "Imelda and Gunter", which received a screening at the Filipino International Film Festival in Los Angeles, and the play "Energy Man", performed at the New York Fringe Festival in association with Hope Theatre, Inc., New York, New York.

He first staged "Vampires of the Red Moon" (pre-cursor to The Red Moon), as a concert reading at the Academy for New Musical Theatre, North Hollywood, California. Denise Devin, director, first met Ramon, in a writer's group they both belonged to, and Ramon started coming out to shows at Zombie Joe's, as an avid fan. And a working relationship began. Denise read the script, and knew it would be right for ZJU to produce.

Denise Devin, lead director at Zombie Joes Underground Theatre Group (ZJU), has been directing at ZJU for 15 years. She has directed at least 50 shows there, from one-acts, to adapted productions of Shakespeare, to musicals, to the edgy experimental. Many of her shows have won local awards, and critical acclaim, and have become part of the ongoing ZJU repertoire. In addition, she has co-written and directed 10 musical children's shows, which have been produced in New York as well as Los Angeles.

Zombie Joes, 4850 Lankershim Blvd., NoHo, CA, 91601, has been in existence for 22 years, and in its current NoHo location for 15 years. Founded by Zombie Joe, and Josh T Ryan, its mission was to present original, cutting edge, experimental theatre to the Los Angeles public, at completely affordable prices, and in a one hour format. They added Denise Devin to the founding member roster 15 years ago, when creating the space at 4850 Lankershim. Over its history, it has won many local awards, produced in New York, and become a staple among LA Theater audiences.  In addition to its regular cutting edge programming, ZJU has become noted for its original horror shows, most especially for its signature horror show: "Urban Death", which has been re-produced many times over the last 10 year, in New York and internationally, as well as LA.


Cast- the cast features many tried and true ZJU artists as well as people new to the company:
Jason Britt
Lara Lihiya
Nicole A Craig
Paul Carpenter
Steven Alloway
Jackee Bianchi
Mariale Chiribao


The Impact

ZJU has a proven track record of supporting new theatre artists: playwrights, new directors, actors, lighting design, music and more. New projects are risky, they are not always perfect, as we are developing talents, not producing the "already done." But art needs risk, needs new blood. New artists need a place to see their work realized with full production values, not just staged readings, or workshops.

This play is special. And Zombie Joes believes in it. Director Denise Devin,  lead director at Zombie Joes, believes in it, and Ramon Sanchez, playwright, believes in it. We have a committed cast and crew. We are looking for some extra help on this one as it needs extra production value.

Risks & Challenges

We are going to produce this play. We are in production, and ZJU has never cancelled a show in its entire 22 year history. But each show represents challenges. We are committed to keeping our prices low, well below the common theatre ticket in LA, but this means we must sell more tickets. New plays represent more box office risk, than our more established programming, but we are also committed to supporting new artists. This extra budget helps ensure we keep our standards high, our ticket prices low, and our actors happy.

Other Ways You Can Help

Giving financially can be tough. But you can help us in other ways. Spread the word, spread the love. Come see the show. Put it out on Facebook, twitter, email, text, and Yelp! These are all wonderful ways to help!

story:
What is Uncle Vanya About?

In this production of Uncle Vanya we are bringing it into the present. In our immersive, modern adaptation, we are telling the story of a hard working young woman (Sonya) and her family as they live in a home that is a shadow of it's former glory.

Why Are We Telling This Story Today? 

Besides Chekhov's omniscient awareness of environmental activism, property vs home, and familial politics, this time-transcendent story is relevant to today's ethics regarding work. It's easy to get lost in the hustle and bustle of the city. Striving to be part of something bigger is something that a lot of present day New Yorkers have in common. Although this story was written in the 19th century, the sentiment of finding purpose through working towards something greater is very present today, despite us sometimes getting lost in the cityscape. Sometimes it's about getting back to our country roots, and that's what this play does.

What Are We Paying For?

COMPENSATION

We at Outlet Ensemble believe firmly in compensating artists for their ingenuity, time, and hard work. Often, artists are asked to work for free, or for "exposure", and while we are a new and humbly situated company, we feel strongly that artists provide a service and should be valued as best as they can be. As such, we are making sure our actors/creative team/crew receive stipends for their commitment. Your donations support this principle and help us pay our team.

THE VENUE

Because we want to have the play set in as close to an actual home environment as possible, a setting where the audience can physically walk through each room watching the play unfold, we are going to have a venue that will be big enough to set this up in. You can help us transform a space into a home. 

ADVERTISING
The most important thing in putting on a show is having people see it! Your donations will help us ensure that people know about our production of Uncle Vanya.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate financially, we completely understand; you can help us by SPREADING THE WORD! Use the Indiegogo share tools to post about this campaign on Facebook, Twitter or any other social media app you choose!

story:
Rancher Althea Wilson's best friend is murdered in cold blood. Thirsty for vengeance, she embarks on the wildest quest in the West.

Lady Injustice is told through the eyes of a troupe of eccentric cowpoke actors who take us on a journey from Wild West America all the way to Victorian London.

Through absurdist comedy the play explores toxic masculinity, female friendship, overcoming grief, and the dangers of living for revenge.

There are lots of ways to help us share this story!
- Come see the play yourself! Bring a friend! Or five!
- Donate to our Indiegogo campaign
- Post about us on social media. We're on Facebook @Lady Injustice
- Spread the word as far as you can
- Reach out to us if you'd like to do more but don't know where to start

We're endlessly grateful for your support, and hope to see you at the Whitmore-Lindley in North Hollywood for our two weekend run March 1st-10th!

story:
KARAR DANCE COMPANY is a modern and contemporary dance company comprised of Artistic Director and choreographer, Kara Robertson, and six permanent performing artists.  We currently operate as a project-based dance company with future plans of becoming a permanent dance force in the Richmond community.  Five of us are Virginia Commonwealth University graduates and five are also native Richmonders.  Some of us have performed and shown choreography in New York City, D.C., Las Vegas, Israel, and Italy.  We are comprised of teachers, business owners, and medical assistants and we are all under the age of 28.  

RVA's dance scene continues to grow and we feel that our company can offer the community with a new and unique perspective on contemporary, modern dance.  We believe in pure abstraction. What that means is, our work is not literal; the movement tells the story and it is up to the audience to interpret it.  We want our viewers to feel something; we want them to link their life to that of the world living on stage.  We've been very busy in the studio over the past four months and are excited to show what we have created.

By donating, you are not only assisting us in producing our very first performance as a company but you are also helping us advance Richmond.  We want to provide the same caliber dance that New York City, Washington, D.C., Chicago, and L.A. offers their cities.  We want to connect people and to inspire them.  Help us in making Richmond, Virginia and hub for the dance arts.

Your gift will support the payment of dancers, costumes, lighting design, theater staff, promotional materials, and videography.  We can not make this happen without your support!  No donation is too small and if you are unable to make a contribution, please spread the word and don't forget to attend our performance April 28 and 29, 2017 at The Grace Street Theater in downtown Richmond.

Ticket's become available April 7th and are $10/$5 for students.  You may obtain tickets by visiting showclix.com or visiting the Grace Street Theater Box Office Monday-Friday 12-4 pm at 934 West Grace Street or calling at (804) 828-2020.
story_txt: KARAR DANCE COMPANY is a modern and contemporary dance company comprised of Artistic Director and choreographer, Kara Robertson, and six permanent performing artists.  We currently operate as a project-based dance company with future plans of becoming a permanent dance force in the Richmond community.  Five of us are Virginia Commonwealth University graduates and five are also native Richmonders.  Some of us have performed and shown choreography in New York City, D.C., Las Vegas, Israel, and Italy.  We are comprised of teachers, business owners, and medical assistants and we are all under the age of 28.  RVA's dance scene continues to grow and we feel that our company can offer the community with a new and unique perspective on contemporary, modern dance.  We believe in pure abstraction. What that means is, our work is not literal; the movement tells the story and it is up to the audience to interpret it.  We want our viewers to feel something; we want them to link their life to that of the world living on stage.  We've been very busy in the studio over the past four months and are excited to show what we have created.By donating, you are not only assisting us in producing our very first performance as a company but you are also helping us advance Richmond.  We want to provide the same caliber dance that New York City, Washington, D.C., Chicago, and L.A. offers their cities.  We want to connect people and to inspire them.  Help us in making Richmond, Virginia and hub for the dance arts.Your gift will support the payment of dancers, costumes, lighting design, theater staff, promotional materials, and videography.  We can not make this happen without your support!  No donation is too small and if you are unable to make a contribution, please spread the word and don't forget to attend our performance April 28 and 29, 2017 at The Grace Street Theater in downtown Richmond.Ticket's become available April 7th and are $10/$5 for students.  You may obtain tickets by visiting showclix.com or visiting the Grace Street Theater Box Office Monday-Friday 12-4 pm at 934 West Grace Street or calling at (804) 828-2020.

story:
Bunny by Jack Thorne

  • We are Fabricate Theatre and we are staging our first ever production!  Led by founding Artistic Director Catherine Lamb our mission is to create work for exceptionally talented artists in the industry, providing them with a professional platform to showcase their work and kick start their careers.    
  • Bunny by Jack Thorne is of vital importance; as our flagship production this will launch our new and exciting theatre company's 2017 programme.  A tale for our times,  Bunny explores a young girls struggle to be comfortable in her own skin and exist within a modern world which lacks intimacy and connection; her awkwardness and need to define people according to their race and culture has never been more relevant or relatable.
  • In a world of Trump and Brexit the question must be asked: what effect is our current political climate of divisive rhetoric and disconnection doing to the minds of young people growing up today? 
  • Your kind donation will be the start of a theatre company whose sole mission is to employ hard working and wonderfully talented creatives.  On and off stage artists alike will be given a professional platform to showcase their work.  We will strive to create and stage exciting and perceptive productions that challenge and ask questions of our audiences.

What We Need & What You Get!

  • We need £5000 to make this production a reality.  The money will pay for all aspects of production; theatre hire, sound design, set design, lighting design, PR, marketing and advertising.  

Project Materials: 7%

PR and Marketing: 30%

Performance space: 30% (theatre hire and rehearsal space)

Creative Fees: 26% (pays our designers; lighting, sound and set)

Performance Rights: 7%

  • In order to get our first production off the ground and employ all these brilliant theatre makers, actress Catherine Lamb, up and coming director Lucy Curtis and first time producer Sophia Nicholson are committing to the project unpaid.  
  • We have a bunch of enticing and unique perks for your generous contributions including: social media shout outs, programme mentions, invites to dress rehearsal, free tickets, one-to-one audition technique classes, one-to-one monologue selection classes, the opportunity to be as assistant director for the day with our wonderful director Lucy Curtis and even (for a truly amazing donation) recognition as associate producer!

What we want to achieve...

  • We want to present an unflinching, honest, intimate, vibrant and relatable story, told from the prospective of a young girl struggling to find her place in an abrupt, threatening and overwhelmingly ever changing world.  
  • We believe theatre should be fun and entertaining but should also reflect our society and the problems and struggles within it.  We will invite young audiences and hold Q and A sessions afterwards, connecting our audience to the world of the play.  We want to create a safe space for young people to come and experience a piece of theatre that reflects their, worries, desires and insecurities. 

Who are we?

Our Bunny creative team is led by Director - Lucy Curtis, Actor/producer - Catherine Lamb and Producer - Sophia Nicholson.  

We are three young women at the start of our careers collaborating on a project we all feel passionately about.  

Lucy is the Artistic Director of Changing Face, a multi-national, multi-lingual theatre company.  Recent credits include:  Where Will We Live? (Southwark Playhouse), It Is So Ordered (Park Theatre/Pleasance Theatre), The Divided Laing (Arcola), Dare to Dream (Arcola). The company are currently supported by Black Theatre Live and the Old Vic Lab.  Lucy trained at the Young Vic.

Catherine Lamb's recent credits include; The Taming of the Shrew (Arts Theatre West End), The National Joke (The Stephen Joseph Theatre), Somewhere in England (Theatre Clwyd), The Crown (Netflix) and Cucumber (Channel 4).  

Sophia is an agent at ‘The London Voice Boutique’ representing a wealth of talent across the board.  This is her first venture into producing. 

Risks & Challenges

  • We have already achieved a lot and have gone a really long way to making this production happen.  We have a wonderful production team assembled and poised for action, and we have secured a three week run at The White Bear Theatre in Kennington. We have secured a fabulous PR team who are right behind this project.  We have overcome many obstacles and challenges already and all we need now is a little help (ok quite a lot!) with the purse strings!
  • This project is not without risk.  You can help to make this production a reality and launch this new theatre company with a fantastic show.  Any contribution helps!
  • We have all individually made strong starts to our careers within this industry and possess the skills and qualities needed to make a success of this project.  We are loyal, driven, passionate and hardworking.  We won't let you down!  

Thank you so much for reading our page. We can't wait for you to see Bunny. 

   

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate but love the sound of this, no worries, you can help anyway! 

  • If you like the sound of our campaign please pass on the link to friends and family, make some social media noise and we will be so grateful.
  • Also, come along to the show, you can help make this production a success simply by seeing it!
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
"One should learn even from one's own enemies" -Ovid, Metamorphoses

Project Nongenue was founded in April 2017 with an inaugural performance of JULIUS CAESAR featuring a cast entirely of women. We revisited MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING that winter and brought Euripides' TROJAN WOMEN to the Hollywood Fringe Festival for a Best of the Fringe extended run. It's all been leading to THE TRAGEDY OF MEDUSA.

The story of Medusa has been told many times throughout millennia, but the shadow of sexual violence central to the myth's storyline remains largely unexplored. As we've been taught it, Medusa is a beautiful priestess of Athena who, after a visitation from Poseidon, is turned into the snake-haired monster we know as a punishment for breaking her vow of chastity and desecrating a temple. After turning many men to stone, Medusa is finally slain by the Hero Perseus.

As we've embarked on this production, we've found the story leaves us with more questions than answers. Why is it so difficult for us to look the Medusa myth in the eyes? In this new adaptation, Project Nongenue looks to interrogate the nature of monstrosity, the ramifications of sexual violence on partnerships and communities, and the way myth continues to shape our understandings of these things today.

As part of the Company Creation Festival at Son of Semele Theater, we've had a team of incredibly talented artists collaborate to make this production out of nothing. All of your contributions are directly responsible for making this show what it will be.

"The gods help those who dare." -Ovid, Metamorphoses

We need at least $1,500 from this fundraising campaign. Project Nongenue is not receiving any revenue from ticket sales for this Festival, but as always we are dedicated to compensating all of the actors and creative professionals who are working tirelessly to bring this piece to life. All funds raised in this campaign will go directly to our actors and creative professionals who are giving their time and energy to this amazing project.

Of course, as our way of saying "Thank You," we're offering some great perks to our generous donors! The cast and crew have many talents, and we love sharing those talents with you!

"Everything changes, nothing perishes" -Ovid, Metamorphoses

We've learned so much and gained so much insight in our past three projects, which reinterpreted ancient and classic texts for a modern audience. With MEDUSA, we're applying what we've learned to tell a story that's been ignored by the storytellers of ages past. All of our previous successes were made possible by donors like you, and we need your help to continue exploring these untapped springs to uncover these untold stories.

"Be patient and tough; one day this pain will be useful to you." -Ovid, Metamorphoses

The challenges presented in staging THE TRAGEDY OF MEDUSA are a little different from our previous hurdles. Theater fees, insurance, rights, and other worries have been taken care of — so now all we have to do is write the play! Using the nuanced, powerful script penned by our founder Olivia Buntaine, our crew of actors has done some really stunning work, each one leaving their own unique mark on this loving patchwork. There are moments of laughter and levity, despair and horror, betrayal and forgiveness. We've risen to this challenge to create a very personal, relatable entry in the history of stories about myth and monsters.

"No god may undo what another god has done." -Ovid, Metamorphoses

Can't contribute financially? Totally cool! We've all been there. You can still help us out! Use those Indiegogo share tools to spread this campaign far and wide! Make a post about it! Tell your friends! Come to one of our shows in January and February 2019! We love all of it, and all of you.

story:
Telling the stories that too often go untold.

Founded in 2013, Theatre Prometheus is a small not-for-profit group dedicated to exploring and promoting diverse, woman-focused narratives here in Washington, DC. We believe in the power of local theater and are committed to providing opportunities to local artists, creating productions both by and for the communities we live in.

We tell the stories that too often go untold and we reach audiences too often overlooked by larger companies. From an unflinching one-woman take on Joan of Arc to our recent all-woman production of Macbeth and our upcoming queer Cymbeline, we are dedicated to producing work that that highlights marginalized narratives.  

This summer, we’re bringing Naomi Iizuka’s Good Kids to the Capital Fringe Festival. The play, loosely based on the events of the Steubenville rape case, addresses sexual assault, rape culture, and growing up in an increasingly digital world.

Our production of Good Kids will prompt difficult but essential conversations -- ones we hope will contribute to greater respect and understanding within our local communities.

But in order to present this play and continue our work in the long term, we need to raise $5,000 by July 31. These funds will help us finish paying off all costs related to Good Kids, and will go towards future productions and the overall growth of Theatre Prometheus.


Supporting local artists, serving local audiences.

Theatre Prometheus is a small, not-for-profit group with limited funds, and your support goes a long way. Even just a few dollars is a huge help to us -- so we hope you consider donating, and sharing this Indiegogo page, today.

None of our leadership takes a salary: 100% of your donation will go to the Company.

Donate now, and help us pay our actors, technicians, and artists.

Help us rent rehearsal spaces, perform in theaters, build sets and design costumes; help us create whole worlds on the stage, worlds that resonate with audiences frequently overlooked by larger companies.

Help us tell the stories that too often go untold.

Help us bring the fire.

Theatre Prometheus is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Theatre Prometheus must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


Bringing our best to the stories that matter. 

We may be a small theatre company, but we have a wealth of experience, training, and passion.

  • Our team members have worked with the Shakespeare Theatre Company, the Folger Shakespeare Library, Underground Railway Theatre, and the St. Petersburg State Theatre Arts Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia.

  • In 2015, we brought The Second Coming of Joan of Arc to the Capital Fringe Festival.  Fringe loved our work so much that they've given us choice show times, and a great location, for our 2016 production of Good Kids.
  • All of us are based locally here in Washington, DC: we are part of, and truly devoted to, the communities that our theatre serves.

Working with you.

Even if you can't donate money, you can still make a difference at Theatre Prometheus -- just email us at theatreprometheus (at) gmail (dot) com. We'd love to chat about:

  • volunteer opportunities
  • in-kind donations
  • collaborative efforts

Another great way to support us is to share this campaign with your friends.  Spread the word, and bring the fire.

story:
Hello all, 

Polina Ionina is an innovative young theater maker who recently developed a new piece in Vermont with her crew from New York. I, Will Hand, am acting in and producing the piece, and am excited for this indiegogo campaign.

Gratitude

Our troupe in Vermont was supplied with food from farmers, ranchers and store owners from Caledonia County. Elsewhere this would be an in-kind donations to be reciprocated with a social media share and some space in the playbill. Instead, the people exercised their radical conviviality. Our final play was a product of the place's ability to foster, nurture, and create. Our Theater was not created by individuals or institutions. It wasn't a commercial exchange. It was a gift the entire place gave to itself.

We are duty-bound to continue that sense of communal integrity. From this place of radical conviviality we can create politically and socially conscious theater that works apart from the inert, absurd and ineffective theater-making institutions of the day.

We have a play that we need to mount. It has been created in exigency and is coming hell-for-leather into this world, but we need to turn out to our wider community to make it happen.

We are looking for $4,444 for this campaign.

$2,400 will go toward paying our team

$1,000 will cover our nominal production costs in New York. (We do it guerilla, ya’ll.)

$1,040 will help recoup production expenses from Vermont.

$4 will buy me a cold brew coffee which I will share with Polina, and which we sorely need after making the indiegogo thing in this New York swamp weather.


Here's our story thus far. 

Working Collectively

Our process in Vermont was an engrossing journey into unbelievably demanding text and the constant need for the company to supporting each other. It was a thoroughly committed rehearsal process that threw us all into the wall with its demands. It at times felt crazy-making, dangerous, inspired, and elating, like playing with an experimental drug. All in all, it was a good trip. There’s much to report.

Surfing Veggie Farm - A sense of Place

In our first hour in the Northeast Kingdom Polina and I stopped at a farmer’s market in Hardwick and met the town. I instantly realized that farmers know how to listen to people.  Loui, of Surfing Veggie, has spent the past 40 years listening to the land. He’d left his career in NYC as a tour manager for rock bands,  met his gal Annie, started a family, and farmed organic carrots. Now his land is dotted with mini-vans that are host to chickens. Every few days, he picks up the portable fencing, gets the hens in their mobile-coups, and takes the girls to a fresh spot where they can peck with impunity. Fed on ancient grains, they lay the biggest eggs, and when he walks within a hundred feet, they run up with giddy expectation.

When we met Loui, Polina and I knew we had made some special friends. Loui later confessed that he felt he’d met members of his tribe, an appellation we proudly bear. We would spend our days off often at Surfin’ Veggie Farm, and eventually we even gathered as many folks from the town out there as we could with the local Back Road BBQ food truck and put on a show. 

One day, as we at Loui's for lunch, he told us how much he appreciated our being here. “We obviously don’t get a lot of culture around here.” Itamar was looking out the window at the farm, the chicken vans, the rolling hay fields, the garden Annie keeps that's resplendent with blueberries, their comically fat horse Peanut noshing in her corral. Itamar leapt to attention and said “I think, actually, Loui, this is all culture. All we’re trying to do in New York is our best to bring a little bit of this to New York City.” True ‘nuff.

Our time there was well spent. We spent two weeks wildly and radically exploring the text. We were all strangers to each other before coming up and at times it felt like performing open heart surgery it was so intense and intimate. The second two weeks had been much breezier, the third week we laid the foundation for our New York production, and the final week we created what we'd put on for the community.


The Walden Play

We knew we wanted the material to be different for the folks in Walden, VT than what we brought to New York. We wanted families to be able to come, and what we had for New York was too volatile for the farm kid friends we’d made. Vermont is no stranger to avant-garde theater, especially ones that use the sense of place to explore the work. We knew, like the great Bread and Puppet Theater of Vermont, that this performance would start with the field it was being performed on.

Instead of trying to create theater in a field, Polina was using a field to create theater. The actors revolved slowly around the audience like the dials on a clock. Watching, you took in the whole landscape as the play's four characters absurdly strove to make the impermanent permanent. Finally, as darkness falls on the play's last surviving character, the audience was in complete darkness. It was a day before the new moon, the sun had long set, and the stars were the only thing visible to complement Itamar's final monologue. It was sweeping in scope and wielded poetically the commanding scope of the landscape. It would not have been created had Polina not been inspired by the 'culture' of the place.

Polina has a subtle ability to listen to her environs, her actors, and her self. This place of listening enables her to experiment with form, layers of consciousness, and the holistic creative capacity of her actors.

We will soon begin working with the much acclaimed London-based composer Laura Jayne Bowler, to bring the piece into yet another dimension.

Help us get where we need to go. 

Yours ever, ever, ever,

William Hand

Theater Maker

It was a gift the entire place gave to itself.We are duty-bound to continue that sense of communal integrity. From this place of radical conviviality we can create politically and socially conscious theater that works apart from the inert, absurd and ineffective theater-making institutions of the day.We have a play that we need to mount. It has been created in exigency and is coming hell-for-leather into this world, but we need to turn out to our wider community to make it happen.We are looking for $4,444 for this campaign.$2,400 will go toward paying our team$1,000 will cover our nominal production costs in New York. (We do it guerilla, ya’ll.)$1,040 will help recoup production expenses from Vermont.$4 will buy me a cold brew coffee which I will share with Polina, and which we sorely need after making the indiegogo thing in this New York swamp weather.Here's our story thus far. Working CollectivelyOur process in Vermont was an engrossing journey into unbelievably demanding text and the constant need for the company to supporting each other. It was a thoroughly committed rehearsal process that threw us all into the wall with its demands. It at times felt crazy-making, dangerous, inspired, and elating, like playing with an experimental drug. All in all, it was a good trip. There’s much to report.Surfing Veggie Farm - A sense of Place
In our first hour in the Northeast Kingdom Polina and I stopped at a farmer’s market in Hardwick and met the town. I instantly realized that farmers know how to listen to people.  Loui, of Surfing Veggie, has spent the past 40 years listening to the land. He’d left his career in NYC as a tour manager for rock bands,  met his gal Annie, started a family, and farmed organic carrots. Now his land is dotted with mini-vans that are host to chickens. Every few days, he picks up the portable fencing, gets the hens in their mobile-coups, and takes the girls to a fresh spot where they can peck with impunity. Fed on ancient grains, they lay the biggest eggs, and when he walks within a hundred feet, they run up with giddy expectation.


When we met Loui, Polina and I knew we had made some special friends. Loui later confessed that he felt he’d met members of his tribe, an appellation we proudly bear. We would spend our days off often at Surfin’ Veggie Farm, and eventually we even gathered as many folks from the town out there as we could with the local Back Road BBQ food truck and put on a show. 


One day, as we at Loui's for lunch, he told us how much he appreciated our being here. “We obviously don’t get a lot of culture around here.” Itamar was looking out the window at the farm, the chicken vans, the rolling hay fields, the garden Annie keeps that's resplendent with blueberries, their comically fat horse Peanut noshing in her corral. Itamar leapt to attention and said “I think, actually, Loui, this is all culture. All we’re trying to do in New York is our best to bring a little bit of this to New York City.” True ‘nuff.



Our time there was well spent. We spent two weeks wildly and radically exploring the text. We were all strangers to each other before coming up and at times it felt like performing open heart surgery it was so intense and intimate. The second two weeks had been much breezier, the third week we laid the foundation for our New York production, and the final week we created what we'd put on for the community.

The Walden Play
We knew we wanted the material to be different for the folks in Walden, VT than what we brought to New York. We wanted families to be able to come, and what we had for New York was too volatile for the farm kid friends we’d made. Vermont is no stranger to avant-garde theater, especially ones that use the sense of place to explore the work. We knew, like the great Bread and Puppet Theater of Vermont, that this performance would start with the field it was being performed on.


Instead of trying to create theater in a field, Polina was using a field to create theater. The actors revolved slowly around the audience like the dials on a clock. Watching, you took in the whole landscape as the play's four characters absurdly strove to make the impermanent permanent. Finally, as darkness falls on the play's last surviving character, the audience was in complete darkness. It was a day before the new moon, the sun had long set, and the stars were the only thing visible to complement Itamar's final monologue. It was sweeping in scope and wielded poetically the commanding scope of the landscape. It would not have been created had Polina not been inspired by the 'culture' of the place. 


Polina has a subtle ability to listen to her environs, her actors, and her self. This place of listening enables her to experiment with form, layers of consciousness, and the holistic creative capacity of her actors.
We will soon begin working with the much acclaimed London-based composer Laura Jayne Bowler, to bring the piece into yet another dimension. 
Help us get where we need to go. 
Yours ever, ever, ever,
William Hand
Theater Maker

story:
About DANCE GRAND MOULTRIE

 

Dance Grand Moultrie is a new ballet and contemporary dance company led by choreographer Darrell Grand Moultrie. Dance Grand Moultrie will see its NYC debut this summer as part of City Parks Foundation’s SummerStage Dance series on July 15 & 16 at Central Park SummerStage/Mainstage!

 

Darrell hails from Harlem, NYC and has been making quite the name for himself as a frequently commissioned choreographer since graduating from Juilliard.  Working in the genres of contemporary ballet and modern dance, he has been commissioned to create original works by esteemed companies as the Atlanta Ballet, Ailey 2, Dance Theatre of Harlem, Colorado Ballet, BalletMet Columbus and the Cincinnati Ballet.  He has garnered great reviews, where such words as “smash hit,” brilliant invention,” “angular gestures with classical vocabulary,” “handsome patterns,” “imaginatively arranged,” and Moultrie’s conceptualization of movement and space far surpasses his age,” are all used when describing Darrell’s choreographic works.

 

The formation of Dance Grand Moultrie is the realization of all of Darrell's work. After 10 years of creating well received works for other organizations, this Company is dedicated to the mission of pushing classical ballet and modern dance forms to new limits and introducing dance to audiences that might not otherwise have access to live performance.  Through collaborations with dancers from multiple backgrounds and genres, Moultrie will create inspired works that provoke, enlighten, and stress the boundaries of classical and modern dance technique.

 

Your Support is Needed!

With your support Darrell will be able to see his vision of Dance Grand Moultrie come to life.  Funds will help offset administrative costs such as artist travel, set production, promotion efforts, studio time, and other general needs of the company.
