story:
Your Tickets Will Be Waiting For You at Our Circus Ticket Kiosk - Any Night You Want to Come, Throughout October.

 

What is The Circus of Fear 3D?

This isn't just ANY haunted house, it's Colorado’s first and only 3D Scary Clown Haunted Fun House! Created by over 25 volunteer artists in Boulder, The Circus of Fear masterfully showcases vivid 3D holographic murals and live performances that illustrate the chilling tale of a traveling circus waylaid by a mysterious horror. Guests are equipped with 3D glasses to navigate The Circus of Fear through a thrilling maze of artistry and scare-your-pants-off entertainment.

 

Ringmaster Cano conceived and built The Circus of Fear as a backyard haunt in October 2010, with the help of a large troupe of dedicated friends. The public response was overwhelmingly positive, with hundreds of trembling and breathless visitors clamoring for “More!!” as they brought their friends and families back for consecutive nights. The Circus again met acclaim when they took their production to Apogaea, a Colorado arts festival. Receiving positive feedback from visitors and Circus volunteers alike, Ringmaster Cano was encouraged to take it to the next level. This ramp up of production involves building and painting more scarifying props and 3D murals, enlisting more performers, significantly more marketing, AND (not the least of which) a REALLY BIG CIRCUS TENT -- all so that we can create an even bigger and better show to now reach 1,000s of people.

 

And that’s where we need your help -- to bring this awesome show to life. Taking The Circus of Fear production to the next level requires significant funds. Buy your tickets RIGHT NOW, through this IndieGoGo campaign, and not only will you be receiving great discounts, you will be giving Ringmaster Cano the much-appreciated support he needs to build this uniquely creative and extra-spooky circus.


Your tickets will be waiting for you at our Will-Call, any night that you want to come! Check our website for our nights of operation and more details about The Circus of Fear.  (**Note that the free game of black light golf at Fat Cats Family Fun Center has been changed to the Lazer Maze**)

 

The Circus of Fear production will be raising its big top this October 1st, in a new high-visibility location next to the Fat Cats Family Fun Center in Westminster, at Highway 36 and 104th Avenue.


And if all this isn’t enough to knock your clown shoes off -- spooky fire spinners, in addition to jugglers, stilt-walkers and other circus performers will be entertaining the crowds each night at The Circus of Fear, this Halloween season.

 

 

A Special Note About Community Service and Impact

Because community service and youth mentorship are two important values to The Circus of Fear 3D team, some special events and charity drives are being planned, such as: blood and food drives; youth program charity proceeds night; as well as a press conference organized for youth journalists, providing the opportunity to meet the creators of The Circus of Fear 3D, observe some behind-the-scenes production, and receive special VIP passes for opening night. Stay tuned to our Facebook page for details.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you work for a company that looks for fun and affordable employee events?

Consider introducing our advance ticket sales campaign to your HR department. Companies can buy unlimited numbers of our Scare Packs, which for only $60 offer all of the following:

  • VIP Admission for 4 people gets you all to the front of the line!
  • 4 rounds of bowling and 4 rounds of the Lazer Maze at Fat Cats Family Fun Center
  • 4 $10 Dave & Busters game cards
  • 1 group photo with an actor (digital download, which is viewable in 3D with Circus of Fear take-home glasses)


Do you live far away and still want to support us? You can put your tickets in a friend's name, or, if you like, we can donate them to one of our charity organizations.


Help us get the word out and share our advance discount sales campaign with all your friends and networks!

story:
Hubris Productions Season 6 – A Season of Envy

Hubris productions huh?  What the heck kinda name is that?

The name Hubris Productions has often been fodder for the critical reviewers in Chicago and we think it’s time to live up to the snarky-ness of our name! We have a new mission and a new value statement to better reflect our outlook on theater and life in Chicago.  So just who do we think we are? We're a scrappy group of seriously snarky, proudly immature semi-grown-ups.  We’re certainly not as arrogant as our name suggests, but let’s face it – what performer isn’t guilty of the sin of Hubris?

Amazingly, Hubris Productions has for the past five seasons been able to support itself by keeping an incredibly frugal budget, maximizing every ticket-sale dollar, and retaining the good graces of a few loyal donors.  We have yet to rely upon grants or large fundraising dollars to reach our seasonal goals.  Not only have we been uber-self-sufficient, but we put our hard earned dollars where our big fat mouths are by partnering with a local not-for-profit every year, and handing over a percentage of everything we bring in, spreading the word about their organization, and helping out with soup kitchens, clothing drives, bike-a-thons…you name it, we’re all over it, and we encourage our audience to do likewise.  This year we’re partnering with Care for Real, a neighborhood food pantry here in Chicago. 

But now we want to grow our productions, our company, and our audience reach.  We also want to expand our cabaret division and continue to give back to the community that gives so much to us.  But we’ve hit the proverbial glass ceiling with our current resources.  And to really make our sixth season the absolute best season Hubris has produced, we need your help.  We aim to raise at least $3,500.00 to help pay for royalties and rent for our pre-published productions, and reserve fees for our original work.

But what’s all this dough going to fund anyway?  What is it, exactly, that we’re gonna do with your hard-earned money?

We’re gonna fund our sixth season, that’s what. 

This season we’re continuing our exploration of the seven deadly sins and turning our theatrics toward envy.  We began our season with House of Yes by Wendy McLeod, a dark comedy gem that finds an obsessed sister none too happy when her twin brother brings home not just any woman, but a fiancé.  Next we’re producing Butley by Simon Gray.  Dissipated, boozing, terminal cynic and always jealous university professor Ben Butley is facing both the break-up of his marriage and the dissolution of a long time affair with Joey…on the same day.  Finally, just in time for the elections, we revive the Chicago Fringe darling Annee Pocalypse!  It’s the very near future and the world is in zombie-filled, wing-nut-run, post-apocalyptic chaos.  Now with MORE CAMP!  

That’s all fine and dandy, but we wanna know who you REALLY are.  What do you stand for?  At its core, what is Hubris Productions?

Well, put simply…

Hubris Productions presents life reflected in a black box. We move you to think, to act, to give a damn and be proud of it.  And we make...                                                                                                      theater you should like.

story:
Liked what you saw on stage?  Want to take it home with you?

We don't believe in something for nothing.  So, in exchange for a donation, you can take some of the custom art from Phineas home with you at the end of our run.  Check out our offers on the sidebar to your right--photos of the items can be found by clicking on the GALLERY tab above.  

See something in the show that you liked that's not on here?  Drop us a line: papermoonrep@gmail.com.

Our Story

We're Paper Moon Repertory, a 501(c)3 non-profit with a mission of bringing inventive stories with exceptional visuals to Austin stages.  Despite budget limitations, we believe that actors deserve pay in addition to props, scenery and costumes that live up to the level of their performances.  Elbow grease and creativity can stretch a budget a long way to achieve this (in addition to producing original, royalty-free work), but rent, design fees, supplies, and marketing are unavoidable costs no matter how creative one might be.


As fate (and the IRS) would have it, Paper Moon received it's non-profit status just after the application deadline for arts funding in Austin this year, and the space was booked prior to this happenstance.  So, Phineas has been funded entirely by Dave & Rachel Meissner's personal earnings, the proceeds from The Dark Monday Fair, and from performance fees for their children's play that they performed earlier this year in schools.  Regardless of this, Paper Moon believes in compensation for designers, actors, crew and dramaturgs, and all of the aforementioned theatre artists are receiving pay for this production before a dime goes towards reimbursement to the Meissners for production costs.  

The Impact

A show of this scale cannot support itself in ticket sales alone, even with the best cost-saving measures in place.  The only way to cut costs is to not pay those involved or to scrap the visuals.  And neither of those are options that work with our mission.  So, finding funding is critical in order to continue producing.

Where Does the Money Go?

Ticket sales have started kicking in, and all of those funds have been allocated to rent and designer fees.  All proceeds from Thursday shows are going directly to cast and crew, without any portion going towards other production costs.  Future ticket sales, again, are going towards rent.  So, your money goes towards materials for the costumes that were built and found, the vintage props, the supply budget for the set, print materials for posters/postcards/business cards/programs (Rachel created all graphics for free), rehearsal space rental costs, online ticketing service fees, and equipment rentals (ladders, trailers, lights), to start. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If it's not in the budget to purchase or contribute, your best contribution would be to help spread the word about our campaign and our show's run.  Share it all on Facebook or Twitter.  Ticket sales certainly help, and you can purchase tickets to our show at www.PhineasAnd4.com.

story:
Brazillia R. Kreep aka The Kreep

“[The Kreep is]…a Gothic poet and illustrator in the tradition of Edward Gorey.”
-Rob Elder, Chicago Tribune

Presented by the Black Pearl Cabaret, AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP, book, music, and lyrics by Gothic poet and illustrator Brazillia R. Kreep, will play 8 pm, October 25-27, 2012 at the Undertown in Port Townsend, WA.

A deliciously dark blend of the Kreep’s original music, poetry, and artwork, the "Kreep" show, Produced by R O'Donnell and Holly Stone-Cabe, Assoc. Prod by Mara Lathrop, and directed by Amanda Steurer, will include readings from his book Kreeplets along with anecdotes about his life. With a special appearance by Alanna Dailey as Parthenia Goste, Aidan McClave as cellist Kreepy Krawler, and Jason Altimarino as Jack Frost, AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP promises to be a Halloween treat for the entire brood.

Black Pearl Cabaret is a professional troupe of actors, variety artists, and musicians. We perform only original works of a Gothic and macabre nature. We are based in the Victorian seaport of Port Townsend, WA.. 

AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP
A Haunting Musical Cabaret

book, music, and lyrics by
Brazillia R. Kreep

with
R O'Donnell as The Kreep
Jason Altimarino as Jack Frost
Alanna Dailey as Parthenia Goste
Aidan McClave as Kreepy Krawler
Holly Stone-Cabe as Ms. Autumn
 
directed by
Amanda Steurer

Artistic Director/Producer
R O'Donnell

Co-Producer
Holly Stone-Cabe

Assoc. Producer
Mara Lathrop

What We Need & What You Get

Support artist compensation by closing the gap between production costs and a reasonable ticket price. The money you donate here goes directly to paying the playwright, director, actors and designers. Show your support & get great perks by donating to this ground breaking new production. PLUS! Help us move THE KREEP. A successful first outing is just the start ...we're planning to tour this production to Seattle, San Francisco, Chicago, New York and internationally to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, London, Paris, Rome and Zagreb. For starters.

You can get everything from your name in the program for a measly 10 buck donation to our special 6K benefit package which includes a free bus ticket to Port Townsend from anywhere in the United States, where you'll be whisked away in a Victorian horse drawn hearse for an entire evening in the company of THE KREEP. 

The Impact

Our mission is to bring original productions of a gothic and macabre nature to the world! Everybody has got to start someplace and there's no better place than an authentic Victorian seaport like Port Townsend and no better production than AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute cold hard cash to our campaign, there are many ways you can help make AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP a theatrical event with legs and a future.

Please help spread the word about our campaign. Tell your friends, relatives, co-workers, and the people in line with while you're getting your next three lattes. 

Volunteer to usher and see a performance for free by contacting us at blackpearlcabaret@gmail.com (subject to availability).
 
Join our Mailing List at blackpearlcabaret@gmail.com
 
Join our Facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/BlackPearlCabaret
 
Join The Kreep's Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/thekreep 
 
Read our blog: http://blackpearlcabaret.wordpress.com
 
Come to Port Townsend to see AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP 8 pm October 26 - 28, 2012 (2 pm Matinée on the 28th) at The Undertown, 211 Taylor St. in beautiful, Victorian Port Townsend, WA, just 2 hours from Seattle!
story_txt:
Brazillia R. Kreep aka The Kreep
“[The Kreep is]…a Gothic poet and illustrator in the tradition of Edward Gorey.”-Rob Elder, Chicago Tribune
Presented by the Black Pearl Cabaret, AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP, book, music, and lyrics by Gothic poet and illustrator Brazillia R. Kreep, will play 8 pm, October 25-27, 2012 at the Undertown in Port Townsend, WA.
A deliciously dark blend of the Kreep’s original music, poetry, and artwork, the "Kreep" show, Produced by R O'Donnell and Holly Stone-Cabe, Assoc. Prod by Mara Lathrop, and directed by Amanda Steurer, will include readings from his book Kreeplets along with anecdotes about his life. With a special appearance by Alanna Dailey as Parthenia Goste, Aidan McClave as cellist Kreepy Krawler, and Jason Altimarino as Jack Frost, AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP promises to be a Halloween treat for the entire brood.
Black Pearl Cabaret is a professional troupe of actors, variety artists, and musicians. We perform only original works of a Gothic and macabre nature. We are based in the Victorian seaport of Port Townsend, WA.. 
AN EVENING WITH THE KREEPA Haunting Musical Cabaretbook, music, and lyrics byBrazillia R. Kreep
with
R O'Donnell as The Kreep
Jason Altimarino as Jack Frost
Alanna Dailey as Parthenia Goste
Aidan McClave as Kreepy Krawler
Holly Stone-Cabe as Ms. Autumn
 
directed by
Amanda SteurerArtistic Director/ProducerR O'DonnellCo-ProducerHolly Stone-CabeAssoc. ProducerMara Lathrop


What We Need & What You Get
Support artist compensation by closing the gap between production costs and a reasonable ticket price. The money you donate here goes directly to paying the playwright, director, actors and designers. Show your support & get great perks by donating to this ground breaking new production. PLUS! Help us move THE KREEP. A successful first outing is just the start ...we're planning to tour this production to Seattle, San Francisco, Chicago, New York and internationally to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, London, Paris, Rome and Zagreb. For starters.
You can get everything from your name in the program for a measly 10 buck donation to our special 6K benefit package which includes a free bus ticket to Port Townsend from anywhere in the United States, where you'll be whisked away in a Victorian horse drawn hearse for an entire evening in the company of THE KREEP. 


The Impact
Our mission is to bring original productions of a gothic and macabre nature to the world! Everybody has got to start someplace and there's no better place than an authentic Victorian seaport like Port Townsend and no better production than AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP!


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute cold hard cash to our campaign, there are many ways you can help make AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP a theatrical event with legs and a future.

Please help spread the word about our campaign. Tell your friends, relatives, co-workers, and the people in line with while you're getting your next three lattes. Volunteer to usher and see a performance for free by contacting us at blackpearlcabaret@gmail.com (subject to availability).
 
Join our Mailing List at blackpearlcabaret@gmail.com

 
Join our Facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/BlackPearlCabaret

 
Join The Kreep's Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/thekreep 
 
Read our blog: http://blackpearlcabaret.wordpress.com

 
Come to Port Townsend to see AN EVENING WITH THE KREEP 8 pm October 26 - 28, 2012 (2 pm Matinée on the 28th) at The Undertown, 211 Taylor St. in beautiful, Victorian Port Townsend, WA, just 2 hours from Seattle!

story:
Our Story:

â€œReal repertory...there's nothing better - for actors, for the theatre, for the audience...thereâ€™s nothing more MARVELOUS. To perform in two plays on alternate nights, while rehearsing a third. To bring back the play that people loved last year, to test the brand-new play against the great plays of the world...â€

â€œIn resident theatres...the rotating-rep system has largely disappeared...It is, for my money, the only way actors can ever season themselves to greatness, and the optimal way for both actors and audiences to learn what greatness is.â€  --Michael Feingold, Village Voice, 12/25/07 & 02/07/03 

Lenny Leibowitz and Amy Estes founded Marvell Repertory Theatre with the intention of giving New York theatre actors and audiences the kind of full-immersion theatre experience that only rotating rep can provide. We are drawn to plays and musicals of integrity, power, and beauty.  We thrill to see actors and audiences stretch their creative muscles as they grapple with great works in vibrant counterpoint.  As New York's flagship repertory company, we strive to embody an international standard of excellence by creating first-rate professional theatre experiences that refresh the spirit, stimulate the mind, and quicken the heart.

 

 

The Impact:

The company made a splash with its 2011 debut season, which included critically-acclaimed productions of THE DYBBUK, BLOOD WEDDING, NORA, and IN THE SHADOW OF THE GLEN.  Our second season is devoted to works that have been burned, banned, caused riots, or landed their casts in jail.  We have already received rave reviews from major New York press.  The New York Post raved, "Drama a Marvell to Behold!"  Curtain Up cheered, "The best Threepenny I have ever seen!"  Time Out named us a "Best Bet" and The Edge New York City praised our company as "one of the most collectively talented casts currently performing on a midtown stage."  In addition to our current productions of THE THREEPENNY OPERA and PROFESSOR BERNHARDI, our 2012 season includes SPRING'S AWAKENING, GOD OF VENGEANCE, Eugene O'Neill's recently rediscovered masterpiece, EXORCISM, and the world premiere of a steamy thriller, NIGHT GAMES.

 

The Need:

As a new company, Marvell Rep is not yet eligible for many foundation grants or government funding sources.  We are completely reliant on ticket sales -- which only cover 30% of our current budget -- and contributions from individuals like you to help us grow into the major repertory company that New York, the greatest theatre city in the world, so richly deserves.  To ensure that we can continue to bring you these critically-acclaimed productions, please give generously.  Every dollar of your support will be used for hiring the actors, designers, and technicians whose talent and skill make us MARVELL.  These fees total almost $100,000 for 2012; our goal is to raise 10% of our annual need through this IndieGoGo campaign!

story:
Our Story

I am An Sean Fields, a playwright and author.  In The Virgin Mary Monologues I share my soul and experiences in ministry by baptizing traditional monologues with an honest look inside the hearts of some of Gods wounded, bruised, hurt, strong, courageous, discouraged and wise women. These testimonies speak of the unshakable love, forgiveness and redemptive power of God as the women take their rightful place as Gods’ leading ladies.


As I went through many storms in my life, I didn't understand why.  I was downsized for the third time, almost lost my house to foreclosure, my car was repossessed and I was bankrupt.  For the most part, it wasn't the people that I went to church with who kept me going but those outside of the four walls who made sure my pockets didn't go empty. I now know that my pain was for every single mother who's back has ever been up against the wall.  The Virgin Mary Monologues is for you and every woman who's felt lonely, disappointed and vulnerable.  Here's to you!


The Virgin Mary Monologues will make you laugh, cry and feel the hearts of these women but most importantly you'll see yourself.


This play is not just for women but also for the man who loves his woman.

The Impact

The Virgin Mary Monologues are a collection of 20 monologues filled with distinction, power, love, hope and determination! From the virgin who refuse to end up like her pregnant unwed sister, to the widow clinging to the memories of her husband, to the woman who has to flee love when it becomes abusive. The Virgin Mary Monologues has a story to tell about the things that make women laugh, and the pain that causes them to cry in the dark. 


For this reason, I am committed to empowering and encouraging women through the arts. The Virgin Mary Monologues is about the lives of women, staring women, directed and written by a woman.


What We Need & What You Get

I have been producing this play on my own for a year now and we have such an awesome response after wards each time but with many competing plays you have to stand out to attract an audience and the production has to be on point.  I'm often scrambling for equipment that if purchased would be an asset to the production.  Also, venue/space is an issue.  Therefore, I need your assistance for the following:

Followspot Light- $300

Wireless lavalier mic system - $500

Complete PA System - $900

Rental space fees for 3 performances in New Jersey - $1500


For your support and generosity, your name will be acknowledged in all performance programs.  I thank you in advance for sowing into this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

I would love to have a female band for the play pro bono, along with anyone else who would love to volunteer to work as a stage manager and production crew.


YES, we'd love your help to get the word out!  How thoughtful!  Please share our page with everyone you know by using the handy "share" buttons provided.

story:
Our Story

Who Turned Out the Lights? originated in the small town of Rose in Upstate New York.  Founded by Lorelei Canne and Jennifer Teska, the company was created to help bring theatre into a small community.  In 2011, the decision was made to move the company from Upstate to New York City to continue its work.  With time and the move, our goals have also shifted.  We are now seeking to provide an outlet for performers working on the tight budget and crazy schedule that is life in New York City.  Our productions include both shows already in existence as well as those of our own creation, with a focus on contemporary musical theatre.  

Coming up is I Love You Because, a modern-day musical retelling of Jane Austenâ€™s classic Pride and Prejudice February 17th â€“ 19th in the Bridge Theatre, located at Shetler Studios, 244 W 54th St, New York, NY.  We choose this show as a good opportunity to feature 6 talented actors in a story that is both funny and poignant with a fantastic score.


The Impact

We are raising money to help pay for the expenses of putting on a show in New York City.  These include, but are not limited to, the rights to produce the show, the space to rehearse in, the theatre to perform in, sets, costumes, props, and, of course, the people who are involved in the production.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise at least $600 in order to pay for the up front costs.  Any support you can give us will be greatly appreciated.  We're on a tight time-line so get your donations in today!  To show our appreciation, we are offering the following rewards that range from a personal thank you on the shows website to a fused-glass pendant designed by the companies Artist-in-Residence, d. dargan teska.  For images of her pendants, check out our gallery!  And for all levels of donation, you get that warm-fuzzy feeling of good karma.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, and, of course, come see our show, February 17th - 19th!

story:
My name is Samantha, and I am a 16 year old student from Louisville, KY wishing to pursue a career in theatre. I hoped that this summer I would do something important, something that would help me develop as a performer and a person, something that would allow me to expand my potential and learn all I could about my craft.

I am raising money that will go towards the tuition, boarding, and all other fees of the program. I would love more than anything to go to Northwestern’s program this summer, but I need your help! Without your help I may not be able to attend. Please help me follow my dreams and donate to my cause. Anything that you can donate would be greatly appreciated. Thank you for all of your support!

.:ACCEPTANCE LETTER:.

Dear Samantha,

Congratulations! You are a Northwestern University cherub!!! You have been selected to attend the National High School Institute in the Theatre Arts Division. This privilege comes to you as a result of your academic record, recommendations, as well as your personal thoughts and achievements. Your selection places you in the elite ranks of an extraordinarily competitive group, which has been accepted for admission.

Sincerely,

Barbara Reeder
Administrative Director

story:
Our Story

Hello! We're the Greater Hartford Academy of the Arts Dance Department Seniors. We are trying to raise money for our trip to the National High School Dance Festival in Philadelphia this March. We love to dance and can't wait for the festival. Every penny donated would get us one step closer to attending this priceless dance event.


The Impact

Coming from across Connecticut, diverse cultural backgrounds and  districts, we have united to accomplish a common goal that is relative to our love of dance. As future leaders of the world, we have taken responsibility in being proactive in our efforts to create this experience for ourselves as well as laying down a foundation for our peers to follow. Contributing to our trip to Philadelphia will reward us for our hard work and motivate us to do more.


What We Need & What You Get

We've been working hard since September to raise funds for our trip! 

UPDATE: 

We recently received a very generous donation that covers the final amount of money we needed for this experience. Any contribution, big or small, will now go toward the Greater Hartford Academy dance department, our school, and our senior concert. Depending on your generosity, you will receive a personalized gift(s) ranging from a mention in our concert program to a slideshow of the appreciative dancers. 


Other Ways You Can Help

To help us out even more, you can simply forward this link to any other supporters interested in our cause. We thank you in advance for your time, support and donations.


To learn more about the Greater Hartford Academy of the Arts and all the exciting projects and performances going on there, please visit http://www.crec.org/magnetschools/schools/artsa....

story:
Our Story

A virulent new strain of SARS erupts in rural Alabama.  It can ignite a pandemic so the area is quickly placed under military quarantine.  Four scientists are selected to spearhead the race to find a vaccine, but their personal lives are on the verge of cracking.


Wax Wings is a new play by Matthew Maguire, directed by Michael Kimmel.


Wax Wings opens Wednesday May 25 at The Wild Project in NYC.

195 E. 3rd St, between Avenue A & B, New York, NY 10009

Wednesday through Saturday, May 25-June 11 at 8PM


Matthew Maguire is a co-artistic director of Creation Production Company--with which he has produced over fifty new works--and the Director of Fordham University's Theatre Program.  He is a proud alumnus of New Dramatists and the NYU Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program.  His plays include Phaedra, and Abandon, and the creation with Philip Glass and Molissa Fenley of A Descent Into the Maelström for Australia's Adelaide Festival, among many others.  His most recently published book (NoPassport Press, 2009) is Matthew Maguire: Three Plays, which includes The Tower, Luscious Music, and The Desert.  His awards include an OBIE for Acting and an OBIE for Directing.


For more: www.creationproduction.org


Michael Kimmel is the creator/adaptor of The Last Goodbye, a musical adaptation of Romeo and Juliet with the music of Jeff Buckley.  The Last Goodbye premiered as a part of The Williamstown Festival's 2010 season in Massachusetts.  TLG was virtually sold out months in advance, and, critically acclaimed, became the highest grossing production to ever grace Williamstown's Nikos Theatre.


Cast

Sofya Makarova, microbiologist: Coleen Werthmann

Alina Maria Santos, biochemist: Amirh Vann

Leda Ventriano, molecular epidemiologist: Eliza Baldi

David Rowlands, molecular epidemiologist: Jack Marshall


Set and Light Design: Ben Kato

Costume Design: Christina Bullard

Assistant Director: Sarah Esmi


The Impact

Wax Wings was commissioned by the Emory College Center for Creativity & Arts funded by the University-wide Creativity & the Arts Strategic Initiative, the Playwriting Center of Theatre Emory and the Creative Writing Program.


Emory's intention was to bring Matthew Maguire as a playwright to Emory to attend a conference on the science of Evolution, and to commission him to respond with a play about the science.  The second stage of the process was to invite Maguire back to Emory's Brave New Works Festival to workshop the first draft.  Further development was done in readings at New Dramatists.  Then Maguire created a solo from the four characters and performed it at the invitation of Jeffrey Jones for Little Theatre at Dixon Place. 


The production is supported by New York State Council on the Arts, foundations, and individuals, but there remains a substantial gap between the necessary production budget and the funds on hands.  Your contribution will literally pay the actors.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $4,000 to meet the payroll gap for the artists, the actors, and the technicians. 

Contributors will get program acknowledgment and an invitation to an opening night cast party.




Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
Our Story

We're making an original theater work about what happened when German playwright and provocateur Bertolt Brecht turned up in Santa Monica in 1941, a refugee from Nazi Germany. It was a time when the FBI kept meticulous files on German war exiles in Los Angelesâ€”people like Peter Lorre and Thomas Mann and Brecht himself. A time when beloved artists like Paul Robeson and Jerome Robbins were called on to testify about their political beliefs in front of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee. A time when civil liberties were threatened by blacklists, and people of integrity were forced to grapple with the true cost of living up to their principles.


Not unlike today, you might say.


Part cabaret and part courtroom, Galileo in America is nominally set in the 1940s. But in the surreal time-space of the piece, Brecht meets both a character from one of his own plays and the FBI agents who had him under surveillance as a suspected communist. 


During his exile in California, Brecht worked on a new production of a play he had written about Galileo's struggle with the Catholic Church. The noted film actor Charles Laughton helps him with the translation and takes on the role of Galileo himself. Meanwhile, Brecht and his friends are being dogged by FBI agents, while Brecht is having trouble with Galileo's daughter Virginia, who is unhappy with her depiction in Brecht's play. Then, at the very end of this troubled period, Brecht has his own reckoning with authority when he is called to testify before the infamous House Un-American Activities Committee.


The Show

It all comes together in late February 2012, when Galileo in America will have its world premiere at the Contemporary Art Center at the University of California, Irvine. The show dates are February 23-25 and March 1-3, 2012, and you can buy tickets online (and don't forget you can get free tickets with donations of $100 and up). It will be the first full production in the new Experimental Media Production Lab, and we think it's going to be an exciting, provocative piece. But to get there from here, we need your help.


Who We Are

Galileo in America originated in a workshop organized by graduates of the Columbia University Theater Program who wanted to create a piece that spoke to their reality as working artists in Hollywood as well as Americans living in doubtful times. The development process  included staged readings of the work-in-progress in October 2004 at the Goethe Institute, Los Angeles, and the Villa Aurora, Pacific Palisades. We are grateful to all those who attended the workshops and readings and offered their insights on the project. 


Since the project's inception, writer and visual artist Antoinette LaFarge and director Robert Allen have been primarily responsible for its continued evolution. Over the past decade, they have jointly created a number of politically inspired, media-savvy performance works, including Hangmen Also Die (2010), Playing the Rapture (2008), Demotic (2006, 2004), The Roman Forum Project (2003), Virtual Live (2002), and The Roman Forum (2000). 


But the upcoming production of Galileo in America rests greatly on the talents of the rest of the team they've assembled:

  • Philip White (composer)
  • Melody Brocious (costume design)
  • Ian Garrett (lighting design)
  • Sam Breen (Brecht)
  • Toussaint Jean-Louis (Galileo/Laughton)
  • Kristina Kahveciyan (Virginia)
  • Christopher Rivas (FBI Agent 1)
  • Tasha Tormey (Clown 1)
  • Jay Wallace (Clown 2)
  • Ashley Henley (stage manager)


What We Need & What You Get

Galileo in America has been a labor of love for most of the people involved up to this point. The early development stages have been partly supported by individual donors, and we're grateful to them for demonstrating their belief in the project. The university is providing us with space and tech support, but there's a limit to what it can do in this time of fiscal austerity. We've been able to raise $7,300 of our total needs for the upcoming production, but that leaves us $6,400 short of our goal of being able to provide all of the following:

  • professional honorariums for our designers and collaborators
  • high-quality costume construction
  • high-quality set construction
  • high-quality video documentation

Our primary goal is to be able to pay our people. We'll make do with smaller sets and simpler costumes if need be.

In gratitude for your help, we're offering a range of perks, from signed show posters and show tickets to a very special limited edition photobook of the performances.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass the word to all your friends. And of course: come see our shows!
story_txt:
Our Story


We're making an original theater work about what happened when German playwright and provocateur Bertolt Brecht turned up in Santa Monica in 1941, a refugee from Nazi Germany. It was a time when the FBI kept
meticulous files on German war exiles in Los Angelesâ€”people like Peter Lorre
and Thomas Mann and Brecht himself. A time when beloved artists like Paul Robeson and
Jerome Robbins were called on to testify about their political beliefs in front
of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee. A time when civil liberties were
 threatened by blacklists, and people of integrity
were forced to grapple with the true cost of living up to their principles.

Not unlike today, you might say.

 Part cabaret and part courtroom, Galileo in America is nominally set in the 1940s. But in the surreal time-space of the piece, Brecht meets both a 
character from one of his own plays and the FBI agents who had him under
 surveillance as a suspected communist. 

During
 his exile in California, Brecht worked on a new production of a play he 
had written about Galileo's struggle with the Catholic Church. The noted
 film actor Charles Laughton helps him with the translation and takes on
 the role of Galileo himself. Meanwhile, Brecht and his friends are 
being dogged by FBI agents, while Brecht is having trouble with 
Galileo's daughter Virginia, who is unhappy with her depiction in 
Brecht's play. Then, at the very end of this troubled period, Brecht has
 his own reckoning with authority when he is called to testify before 
the infamous House Un-American Activities Committee.

It all comes together in late February 2012, when Galileo in America will have its world premiere

Ian Garrett (lighting design)
Sam Breen (Brecht)
Toussaint Jean-Louis (Galileo/Laughton)
Kristina Kahveciyan (Virginia)
Christopher Rivas (FBI Agent 1)
Tasha Tormey (Clown 1)
Jay Wallace (Clown 2)
Ashley Henley (stage manager)

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
October 12th Fringe Benefit Cancelled

A Letter from PHX:fringe Interim Board Chair Liz Warren:

Dear PHX:fringe Supporter,
 
It's with regret that I write to inform you that we must cancel the Fringe Benefit scheduled for this Friday, October 12, 2012.  We raised only slightly more than 20% of our target, representing less than half of the cost of producing the event, and cannot risk going more deeply in debt than we already are. 
 
We understand that many of you contributed to this indiegogo campaign with the expectation of attending the Fringe Benefit. We know that others contributed in order to support the work of the PHX:fringe more generally. Either way, you are due a full refund and we will return your contribution.  
 
We would be deeply grateful, however, if you would allow us to retain your donation. Your gift will help us meet our existing obligations to the artists who have invested their time and talent in the PHX:fringe Festival.  Your donation would be 100% tax deductible.

Over the next few months we will be taking a good hard look at the festival and its future.  The board members are committed to providing opportunities for independent performance art in Phoenix.
 
We sincerely thank you for your support. We look forward to seeing you at a future PHX: fringe Festival event.
 
Liz Warren
Interim-Chair
PHX:fringe Board
 

About PHX:fringe

PHX:fringe festival was founded in 2008 by a group of artists and producers with a shared vision for the importance of small-venue, live performance in downtown Phoenix, AZ.

PHX:fringe strives to be the link between artist and audience. We create structure and space for emerging and established artists to make great work and share it with the community.  

In our first five years, PHX:fringe has hosted five multi-venue theatre festivals featuring local, national, and international performing artists. We've engaged thousands of audience members and collaborated with performance venues across the downtown Phoenix area. PHX:fringe was named Best Theatre Festival by the 2011 Phoenix New Times Best in Phoenix Awards.

Finding our Edge: The NEW PHX:fringe

Now, five years in, we’re at a crossroads. In order for PHX:fringe to continue, we need to grow into a truly sustainable arts organization. We are re-thinking everything about the festival, about what PHX:fringe is and should be in the Phoenix community. We're finding our new edge of experimentation, of great art, of pushing the limits, of creating an inclusive, high-quality, totally crazy theatre and performance festival. 

PHX: fringe is undergoing a significant shift in vision and organizational structure over the next year. We are: 

  • Moving the festival from March to October.
  • Developing programming that creates space for exciting performative artistry year-round in Phoenix through a series of performance events that take place outside the festival calendar. (Stay tuned for our first project in January 2013!)
  • Building PHX:fringe into a sustainable arts organization that truly supports and creates space for artists to make great work. 
  • Envisioning and implementing a strategic plan that makes PHX:fringe accessible to artists and audiences across our community and beyond.
  • Debuting a BRAND NEW, totally re-imagined, PHX:fringe festival in October 2013. 

HERE'S WHERE YOU COME IN:

  • We need to raise $5,000 to launch the NEW PHX:fringe.

  • We have from NOW until October 12th to raise this money.

  • We're ending the campaign with a GIANT Kickoff party to launch us into our new future.

The Fringe Benefit: Playing on the Edge

Friday October 12th 2012 from 8pm-11pm at Children's Museum of Phoenix

This adults only play-themed party celebrates our new commitment to playing the edge of live performance. The event will feature: 

  • Live performances by amazing local artists including musicians, theatre artists, dance artists, DJs, spoken word artists, and more! 
  • A multi-media scavenger hunt with prizes
  • Adult beverages
  • Delicious (and daring) food 
  • All varieties of edgy fun and games at the Children's museum. At night. With no children.

By supporting our funding campaign with a donation of $20 or more, YOU get entry to The Fringe Benefit: Playing on the Edge!!

AND

Your donation is tax deductible, minus the value of your reward.

Thank you for supporting the NEW EDGE of PHX:fringe.

We're excited to play with you on October 12th!

story:
Western Ballet Needs Your Help

Help Mountain View, California’s Ballet Company; Western Ballet bring its new full-length ballet Snow White to life.

Our mission: Ballet for Everyone, is our passion

Founded in 1976, Western Ballet makes the performing art of classical ballet accessible to the general public. A non-profit institution, not funded by any grant, Western Ballet has a complete youth program for children and pre-professional teenagers, including scholarships for underprivileged children, and the most affordable largest selection of adult classes in the San Francisco Peninsula and South Bay. Since 2007 Western Ballet’s path, philosophy and methodology have been defined from the experiences of Artistic Director Alexi Zubiria’s distinguished career as a principal dancer and a guest artist with some of the most renowned ballet companies in Europe, the USA and South America.  

Community Outreach:

1. Scholarships offered to low-income talent. Last year only, we gave away $19,000 in tuition scholarships.

2. We take a mini versions of our productions to the local libraries for free.

3. We take our productions to retirement communities to give mobility-challenged an opportunity to entertain.

Other ways to help us at Western Ballet: We understand if you are unable to contribute monetarily.  You can still help us by coming to see the show, sharing the link to this page with friends on your Facebook/Twitter accounts, by sending a personal email to your friends and family with a link to this page and/or visiting our Western Ballet Facebook page and liking us to stay informed about future productions.

https://www.facebook.com/WesternBallet?ref=hl

Reaching our goal: We will use every cent donated by you to the put on a show to the best quality and ability we are capable of. Hopefully with your generosity we can cover our production costs and put on a fantastic show. We thank you with deep and humble gratitude for helping us achieve our goal.

story:
Short Summary

 

Hello Everyone,

    If you know me, then you know that my dream is to go to LA and pursue my acting career. Today, September 17, I went for an audition for the company ONE ON ONE to go on their LA Trip to meet over 20 different casting directors, agents, and managers. When I initially signed up I thought the entire trip would be covered if I paid a certain amount. When I was done pouring my heart out through my monologue, the man said "I need to be in LA because I have a 'presence'"; unfortunately this trip cost $2000, hotel and airfare included, money I do not have at this time. I've always been told that I should never back away from my dreams, no matter what the cost may be. I am determined to get to LA and if I can find people who support me through it all, it would make a world of differences. Please, if you know someone who would like to support in ANY WAY POSSIBLE every bit helps!!!   I need to reach my goal by October 6th, only 2 weeks away.


If you know anyone who lives in LA or works for an airline to lessen the cost that would help!!

 

Lawnyae Marie

story:
Laugh Out Proud Chicago Comedy Festival

Jacob Welch (Artistic Director and Founder) is a Chicago based gay improviser and actor. During his time in Chicago, he's spent over five years studying, performing and producing comedy at such institutions as The Second City, The Annoyance and Stage773. Jacob is ecstatic to bring Chicago it is very first LGBTQ comedy festival and to raise money to give back to the LGBTQ community.

Laugh Out Proud Chicago is the very first LGBTQ comedy festival of it is kind combining the local talents of the Improv, Sketch and Stand-up community with that of the LGBTQ community.  Over the span of 2 nights, the festival offers over 10 hours of comedic entertainment in a newly renovated 4 stage theatre complex.  Laugh Out Proud Chicago is working in conjunction with Season of Concern.

Season of Concern is a charitable organization founded by Chicago’s theater artists to provide care for those in the theater community afflicted with AIDS-related illnesses.  Season of Concern has raised tens of thousands of dollars from generous artists and theater patrons to benefit hundreds of actors, directors, designers, technicians and playwrights who are experiencing health-related complications and emergencies.

http://www.seasonofconcern.org/

Through this campaign, contributors will make all the difference by allowing us to cover all expenses associated with producing the festival.  Afterwards, 100% of the proceeds (ticket sales, private donations and raffle money) will be donated back into the LGBTQ community via Season of Concern.

Every dollar donated is a big help to us!  Every donation, no matter the size will receive recognition from us on our social media page.  Donating higher amounts will also grant you individual tickets as well as nightly or full festival passes to grant access to all shows throughout the weekend.

Artistic Director Jacob Welch will be available throughout the entire festival to give out big gay hugs to anyone who donates at least 1$ to the campaign.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially to our campaign, but there are still ways you can help!  Please visit out Facebook page to “Like” and “Share.”  Word of mouth is a strong tool used to help us spread the word about this fabulous event.  We are also always looking for volunteers to help us make this event run as smooth as possible.  If you have a talent, skill or just some free time to donate, email us and tell us about it at Laughoutproudchicago@gmail.com.

www.Facebook.com/LaughOutProudChicago

story:
About us and 88: Hachi Hachi

We are UNIT SOUZOU, Portland's newest professional taiko company. With over 20 years of professional experience, company founders Michelle Fujii and Toru Watanabe are relentless innovators known for their fusion of taiko and Japanese folk dance.  

Intricately weaving taiko, dance and theatre, 88: Hachi Hachi is a bold new theatrical work investigating the space that exists between two people. A duet, Michelle and Toru face each other through a rhythmic journey uncovering their entwined lineages and personal stories. 88: Hachi Hachi will premiere October 2, 3 and 4 in Portland, OR. The show is directed by Susan Banyas. Other contributors include choregrapher Eric Nordstrom, lighting designer Jeff Forbes and all around cheerleader Toni Tabora-Roberts.

88: Hachi Hachi is Unit Souzou's first original production. Help us get this story to the stage. Become one of our 88 friends at $33! Among other meanings, the number 88 is considered auspicious. And with your support, we know we will count ourselves lucky. Be one of our 88 friends and we will shower you with gratitude and an exciting, innovative taiko theatre show.

It takes a village to make art!

We love to create this work, but we can't do it without community support. Ticket sales cover just a portion of our costs. Our Indiegogo campaign goal is to enlist 88 friends at $33 each, a cash goal of just over $2,900.

Here are some of the cold hard costs to produce 88 Hachi Hachi:

  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Performance space rental
  • Artistic and technical crew
  • Graphic design
  • Marketing materials, incl. website, posters and postcards
  • Advertising
  • Publicity

Though Unit Souzou is new, the team behind this production are all professionals who will not only ensure that this production comes to fruition, but that it will be artistically relevant and groundbreaking.

Other ways to support UNIT SOUZOU

Can't contribute at this time? Here are other ways to help:

  • Buy a ticket and come to the show
  • Bring a friend to the show
  • Share this campaign with your social networks
  • Bloggers: write about us!
  • Take a Unit Souzou taiko class
Thank you!

story:
Mo's Journey - What's This All About?

Hello, and welcome to our shameless fundraiser for In Celebration of Mo.
Thanks for coming, have we told you your shirt is FLAWLESS?

Well it is.

Also did you cut your hair?

I don’t know, it just looks gorgeous, maybe you styled it differently? Whatever, the point is that you’re perfect, it’s not a big deal, I’m just saying.

Now that we’ve brought the blatant flattery section of this crowd funding initiative to a close, let’s get down to brass tax. In Celebration of Mo is Dale Neuringer’s first full length-ish play, being brought to life at the Wandsworth Fringe as a result of a talented team and also the incessant cries of her rabid fan base. Featuring the talented stylings of many an actor and the equally talented stylings of only one producer and one director, ICOM is guaranteed to be a fun filled ride through issues of gay identity, the suffocating ties of family, and what it means to be your own person. Doesn’t that sound FASCINATING? Of course it does.

The difficulty lies in the fact that one cannot create art in a void, and we like to pay people for their time, and also buy stuff to make this performance more than a bunch of good-looking people standing on a stage miming for their lives. We want perfection, and perfection takes money. Your money. We know it’s gauche to discuss finances but goddammit this is important alright?!  We need 2,000 pounds to make this gorgeous machine go, and we’re relying on you to help. We’re just a boy, standing in front of a girl, asking you to fund us.

Ze Budget

So, where's all that money going to?

  • Honorariums (£100 each to 5 cast members, playwright, director, producer, production stage manager & publicity/video designer) - £1,000
  • Public Liability Insurance - £150
  • Costumes & Props - £150
  • Production related costs - £50
  • Poster/Flyer printing - £125
  • Social Media Marketing - £100
  • Festival related Registration Fees - £85
  • Contingency - £100
  • Indiegogo charges (5%+3%+£0.30) - £176 (projected)
  • Future Festival Registration Fee - £64 (projected, dependent on indiegogo charges)

As you can see from our budget, we want to be transparent with you. All donations and contributions will be fiercely rewarded with the incentives you see on your right, and each pound will be used to get this piece on the stage, and to reimburse our team for their efforts. All jokes aside, we believe that making diverse, challenging work is important, and all of your generosity will be directly responsible for that belief coming to fruition.  Help us help you help the world, by getting In Celebration of Mo funded and out there. We love you, thanks for reading, your help is genuinely appreciated.

In Celebration of Mo will be staged at the 31-seater The Cat's Back as part of Fragility Takeover at the Wandsworth Fringe. There will be 2 shows - 19th May at 1030pm & 22nd May at 3pm.

XOXO,

The Team at In Celebration of Mo

PS: If you have found yourself titillated by the air of chic mystery that surrounds our team and production, follow us on Twitter at @celebrating_mo and also on Facebook to get updates on our rehearsals, team bios, and so much more (ok, not THAT much more).

story:
Short Summary

The backstage area in the Theatre Baton Rouge Studio is in need of some significant improvement.  This spaces houses The Young Actor's Program, Casts from TBR productions, children during TBR productions and classes given at the theater.  

It is used for:

changing clothes

Putting on makeup and hair

A lounge area during the productions

Vocal warm up area for musicals

storage for props, set pieces and lighting materials

snacks and refreshement

It is currently dark, with black walls and torn drapes and is constantly in a state of flux due to its multiple uses


What We Need & What You Get

We need your donation to purchase the materials and pay for the labor for the major construction portions of this renovation!

Every donor will be recognized in a framed commemorative poster!

The Impact

While it will still serve multiple purposes, it will be outfitted so that the least change is required to the space to make it functional for each purpose

We will be painting over the black walls the entire space a very cheerful blue!

We are adding a large enclosed storage area for props, set pieces and lighting!

We are adding 5 new private changing rooms!

We are adding dressing tables with mirrors for applying makeup and hair styling!

We are improving the "kitchen" area with a new bottle-less water cooler and countertops!

We are obtaining and covering hip furniture for the green room area of the room!

We will be cleaning the ceiling grid and replacing the ceiling tiles!

All lighting will be repaired or replaced

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with as many others as you can....

story:
Short Summary


WHAT IS THOSE THAT CAN'T ABOUT?

As the name suggests the play deals with the effects that bad teachers can have on students (Although the play is set on a performing arts course the themes are relevant to other courses and educational institutes). Also dealt with is the issue of students who have no interest in learning, interference by politicians who care more about targets, teachers covering their own back's instead of doing what is really right for the student and dealing with the concept of employing teachers with no experience and setting them against those who have.


SYNOPSIS

We follow Ben as he enters his second year of college, he grab's two girlfriends, desperately trying to keep this quite despite his naive and very clingy girlfriend mentioning their relationship to everyone she sees, and with the introduction of a new and young teacher he believes he can finally get the education he signed up for. All too soon it becomes apparent that this new teacher is actually too young for the job, loves his authority far too much and doesn't really know what he is talking about (I think many of us have been there). As the course progresses his begins having questions, which neither his teacher or the head of the department can answer, as well as getting even more frustrated by the attitudes and cover your own back syndrome adopted by both teachers. Now unsure if he is any good as an actor and not hitting the grades he thought he could get (poor guy assumed an acting course would be practical instead of theory based), he also has to put up with many of the students who do not want to learn, either there just for a laugh or want to go into jobs unrelated to the course. He hangs around with his two friends, one who enjoys provoking arguments with the teachers and other students and the other who has been bought so low down in her confidence that she can barely get up in the morning. Before the end both  Ben and his antagonist have to face the truth, is Ben as good as he thinks he is or is his new teacher simply not up to the task?

More info can be found at www.thosethatcant.com.

ABOUT ME

I am an actor/writer based in Maidstone. Aside from the college where the play is based on I received some real education by taking classes at places such as Central, the actors centre and several other institutes. I am also planning on attending Drama Studio London this year to further my professional training. I began my own writing about two years ago, I have created my own production company called 'Maidstone productions' and have a feature film which was self funded titled 'environmental enforcement', more information about this can be found at www.environmentalenforcement.org.

WHY WRITE THE PLAY

Many 'teachers' have simply went from university straight into a teaching job with little or no real experience, they are utterly unprepared to take on even a small class let alone full time positions where they claim to be professionals. As a result many teachers are lethal to a society, leaving students heads full of inaccurate information and having no skill set for their chosen career paths. Students are sent out into the world with a qualification that is not worth anything and as such have to settle on poorly paid dead end jobs and abandon their career prospects. Not only is the impact devastating on young peoples lives, as such it has impacted our society, but also gives bad reputations to the truly remarkable teachers that are out there.

The impact on people is overwhelming, and it is something that society and the government has yet to really address, we are of course familiar with the saying that is the title of this play, yet how long has this saying been around and what has really been done? When I was at college we were told to always write two pages of A4 for a CV, include personal statement every qualification you ever had, well we all all know what goes into one, yet an actors CV is a single side of A4. We were taught that we had to spend a fortune on keeping our head shots up to date, but in fact all we had to do was sign with model mayhem and get all the ones we want for free, it is also worth noting that out of my entire year group I am the only one pursuing acting as each and everyone else had either been put off by the teachers or simply couldn't handle life in the real world with that kind of education, and lets be fair who can blame them. The impact that these people have on society is immeasurable, it is something that can not be understated and it is so severe it has to be dealt with.


WHAT WILL YOU DO WITH MY MONEY?

So after reading all of that I'm sure you must be wanting to know what I will be spending your hard earn't money on, there are of course several factors with regards to financing a theatre performance. Payment of the cast and crew and also for securing the theatre for performance, hire of a venue to rehearse, set and props. Covering people's travel cost's is something else that need's to be addressed. Also flyers, posters and other publicity for the show will need to be printed.

There are various rewards that I can offer people for their support, including my previous feature film, invite to one of the performances, and a whole load of other goodies that I can offer.


WHAT DO YOU HOPE TO ACCOMPLISH?

I hope that any of the teachers that this is aimed at will stop and think and truly question their own ability and ask if they are really suited for the job.

The main aim of this is to stir things up and cause a debate, I am not claiming that I can single handedly recreate the education system for the better, but with your help this play will stand a legitimate chance of getting any one who sees it thinking and talking about the themes dealt with.

story:
What Does Children’s Theatre Network Mean for the Community?

Children’s Theatre Network is a part of Performance Network Theatre, a leading theatre in Southeastern Michigan since 1981.

The addition of sound equipment will help CTN reach more children to provide:

  • Original shows that entertain while educating and providing positive life lessons, performed at Performance Network Theatre, area schools and community centers

  • After school classes at elementary schools that encourage literacy and healthy self-expression

  • Theatre workshops, teaching students creativity, problem-solving, and self-confidence

  • "Get in the Game," an innovative program which utilize theatre workshops and performances to combat high school dropout rates at high risk high schools

  • Jobs for local actors, instructors, playwrights, and directors who are passionate about positively influencing kids

Where Your Donations Will Go

All donations will be used toward the purchase of sound equipment for the Children’s Theatre Network’s touring programs and shows.

  • $20 buys a cable (need: 5)

  • $50 buys a case for transporting the equipment (need: 2)

  • $80 buys a microphone stand (need: 2)

  • $200 buys a mixer (need: 1)

  • $460 buys a wireless microphone (need: 4)

  • $800 buys a speaker (need: 2)

Check out our donation perks, which provide a variety of opportunities for family fun and lasting memories! Gifts are tax-deductible and every amount counts!

How You Can Help

Your generous donations help our cause. Each dollar puts us closer to having this important equipment on hand and in schools!

You can also help us spread the word in a number of ways!

- Share this link:

  • www.igg.me/at/letourvoicesbeheard

- Tweet about this campaign (a couple suggestions provided below):

  • Inaudible Ichabod: A man on a mission. A mission to be heard: igg.me/at/letourvoicesbeheard #ChildrensTheatreNetwork

  • Educating through performance. Creating possibilities. Let their voices be heard:  igg.me/at/letourvoicesbeheard  #ChildrensTheatreNetwork

- We welcome volunteers! Call the theatre at (734)663-0681 to sign up.

Thank You!!...

for your interest in Children’s Theatre Network. We are proud of the work that we do in our community and we appreciate your support!

story:
Why Science and the Theater?

There seems to be a thirst in our culture for understanding the complex and interesting world that modern science is uncovering.  At the same time, there seems to be a thirst in the theatre community for depth in the material that is explored on stage. 

Indra’s Net Theater will be exploring this new territory by putting on professional plays about the findings of modern science.  Doing this in Berkeley seems like a natural fit.  We cannot do this without your help.  Production expenses are about $25,000.  The non-profit theater typically gets no more than 50% of total expenses from ticket sales.  In order to launch this theater company we need your support. 

Science and the theater have a potentially powerful collaboration.  Theater, because it is an essentially physical experience has the ability to explore challenging ideas (like quantum physics and the nature of life) in a way that is not purely intellectual, but is, instead, experiential.  This allows for the ideas to be absorbed physically in the theater, leading to a whole new way of understanding and incorporating these ideas into our lives.  Both the audience and the actors experience both science and the theater in a new way.

Hi.  I’m Bruce Coughran and I am the founding Artistic Director of Indra’s Net Theater, a theater company headquartered in Berkeley that focuses on plays about science and the big questions. 

Berkeley is an area rich in both theater and scientific exploration.  Although we have an active and vibrant theater community here, we saw a desire for plays that really explore the big questions. 

I have formed a team of people who are passionate about the prospect of exploring science through the medium of theater.  We will start in 2013, with Michael Frayn’s fascinating play ‘Copenhagen’.  Copenhagen takes as its focus, a 1941 meeting between Nils Bohr and Werner Heisenberg in occupied Denmark.  This play explores both Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle and the uncertainty of the human condition,  the ethical responsibility of the scientist, the dawn of the nuclear age and the trauma that was World War II.  But it also looks at what we can know, or what can be known.  What are the bonds that bring us together as people, and what can science ultimately know.

We will then look on to plays that explore mathematics, memory, chemistry, the nature of life and consciousness, and modern physics.  We will use the best of plays that have already been written, as well as developing new plays, and new theatrical explorations, including ensemble-generated pieces.  Through this we hope to create a rich and multi-layered exploration of the complexities of modern science and thought, in a way that Theater is uniquely able to do.


Here is what your donations will cover for our first show Copenhagen.  (We are already working on our second show, and those expenses will come soon.)

Theater rental  - $9,600

Artists Fees - $5,600

Insurance - $500

Set/Costumes/Props - $1,050

Light/Sound/Piano Rental - $1,150

Designers Fees (Lights/Sound/Set) - $2,000

Running Crew - $1,800

Publicity - $1,200

Graphics/printing - $200

Advertising - $600

Royalties  - $2,400

story:
The Half-Brothers Mendelssohn

Theo Mendelssohn wants three things: to make a name for himself as a brilliant physicist; to bring his father Joseph back to life; and to win the love of Margaret Herbert. He believes he can achieve all three by building a time machine. Theo returns to 1908 to prevent his mother's departure, a traumatic event he blames for Joseph's failing health. Not coincidentally, this will also prevent Joseph's remarriage and the birth of Theo's half-brother and romantic rival Nicholas.

Troubles ensue when Nicholas and the hapless gardener Angelus accidentally accompany Theo to the past. Nicholas does not take kindly to being wiped out of existence. Angelus has eyes only for Theo's mother. As the consequences of their actions unfold into calamitous futures, the half-brothers jump to various pasts and presents, trying desperately to return to a life they recognize.

That's the world premiere play Strange Tree is opening in a month. And yes, that means we get to build a time machine.


*Elizabeth Bagby (Playwright)

Thrisa Hodits (Director)

Cast:

*Cory Aiello (Rev. Herbert)

Audrey Flegel (Margaret)

Andy Hager (Angelus)

*Kate Nawrocki (Alice)

*Stuart Ritter (Theo)

Brandon Ruiter (Nicholas)

*Jenifer Henry Starewich (Henrietta)

Joseph Stearns (Joseph)

Ed Rutherford (understudy)

^Karen Shimmin (understudy)

Design and Production Team:

*Delia Baseman (Costume Designer)

Becky Bishop (Stage Manager)

^Tyler Core (Photographer)

Ben Dawson (Technical Director)

^Michael Huey (Music and Sound Designer)

Becca Jeffords (Lighting Designer)

^Phineas X. Jones (Poster Illustrator/Designer)

John E. Kelly (Master Electrician)

*Kate Nawrocki (Set Designer)

*Rebecca Phend (Production Manager)

David Rosenberg (Press Liaison)

*Emily Schwartz (Set Designer, Photographer)

*Strange Tree company member.

^Strange Tree artistic associate. 

We'd love to be able to share some rhapsodic press quotes, but we can't, because this thing is brand spanking new. No critic will see it for another month. In fact, at this point it's a safe bet you know more about the show than do at least 90% of Chicago's theater critics. Congratulations! Well done!

We CAN tell you that Chicago Public Radio called Strange Tree one of the most imaginative companies in town, and that in 2011 we produced two of the three plays that received Jeff nominations for Best New Work. We can tell you that most of our cast and designers have been working together for years. We can tell you that Ms. Bagby wrote this script specifically for Strange Tree, with its performers and aesthetic in mind. We can tell you that we're producing this piece in the lovely, intimate space at Signal Ensemble Theatre, where we put up last year's Funeral Wedding: The Alvin Play. We like those odds.

What We Need & What You Get

The Half-Brothers Mendelssohn, like most of our shows, is going to cost just under $25,000. Including rent, PR, and stipends for all the contributing artists and designers. We want to raise a tenth of that with this campaign.

Our Indiegogo supporters get show tickets, limited-edition merch, public thanks, hang-out time with the Trees, all the fun of masquerading as mathematicians, and our undying gratitude. Plus, you'll get to be a part of a show the world has never seen before. And you're helping to build a time machine! How often do you get to do that?

A word about logistics: Giving $75 or more entitles you to see the show in its first two weeks (June 20-23 and June 27-30). Optional dates include opening night, with its post-show party. But tickets for opening night go fast, and we can't guarantee that they'll be available for long. If you want to come to opening night, that's great—but please, either donate early, or reserve your tickets separately through the link below.

Other Ways You Can Help

Buy a ticket to our show! Bring friends. (Groups of four or more get a discount of $5 off every ticket! Bring a fifth buddy, and he's pretty much getting in free. Seriously, the math checks out.)

Come to our special event, The Night of No Regrets, on July 17! In addition to a performance of the show, you'll get a time-travel-themed costume party, refreshments, live music, handmade crafts, a personal tour of the set, and a chance to feed your own unfortunate memory into Theo's regret-erasing machine.

Join our intrepid team of volunteers! Put up posters, distribute postcards, decorate the lobby, paint the set, or contribute some other skill. Whatever you can do, we probably need it in some capacity. Contact Scott Cupper, our volunteer coordinator, to learn more.

Join our small but equally intrepid board! If you're ready to use your expertise in finance, graphic design, or management to help the world become a more theatrical, adventurous place, we would love to have you on board. (Get it? Eh?) Bonus: we have snacks at pretty much every meeting. Good ones. Like, homemade pie good. At Strange Tree, our playwrights do double and triple duty, so email Elizabeth Bagby, who's also our board liaison, if you're interested.

Give us your old bicycle! Or any other old gadget that might be a part of a time machine assembled on a low budget in 1929. Talk to our production manager, Rebecca Phend. Or just leave your junk in the alley outside the theater and steal away silently.*

*Please don't actually do that. We'd like to be able to say thank you.
story_txt:
The Half-Brothers Mendelssohn
Theo Mendelssohn wants three things: to make a name for himself as a brilliant physicist; to bring his father Joseph back to life; and to win the love of Margaret Herbert. He believes he can achieve all three by building a time machine. Theo returns to 1908 to prevent his mother's departure, a traumatic event he blames for Joseph's failing health. Not coincidentally, this will also prevent Joseph's remarriage and the birth of Theo's half-brother and romantic rival Nicholas. 
Troubles ensue when Nicholas and the hapless gardener Angelus accidentally accompany Theo to the past. Nicholas does not take kindly to being wiped out of existence. Angelus has eyes only for Theo's mother. As the consequences of their actions unfold into calamitous futures, the half-brothers jump to various pasts and presents, trying desperately to return to a life they recognize.
That's the world premiere play Strange Tree is opening in a month. And yes, that means we get to build a time machine.
*Elizabeth Bagby (Playwright)
Thrisa Hodits (Director)
Cast:
*Cory Aiello (Rev. Herbert)
Audrey Flegel (Margaret)
Andy Hager (Angelus)
*Kate Nawrocki (Alice)
*Stuart Ritter (Theo)
Brandon Ruiter (Nicholas)
*Jenifer Henry Starewich (Henrietta)
Joseph Stearns (Joseph)
Ed Rutherford (understudy)
^Karen Shimmin (understudy)
Design and Production Team:
*Delia Baseman (Costume Designer)
Becky Bishop (Stage Manager)
^Tyler Core (Photographer)
Ben Dawson (Technical Director)
^Michael Huey (Music and Sound Designer)
Becca Jeffords (Lighting Designer)
^Phineas X. Jones (Poster Illustrator/Designer)
John E. Kelly (Master Electrician)
*Kate Nawrocki (Set Designer)
*Rebecca Phend (Production Manager)
David Rosenberg (Press Liaison)
*Emily Schwartz (Set Designer, Photographer)
*Strange Tree company member.
^Strange Tree artistic associate. 
We'd love to be able to share some rhapsodic press quotes, but we can't, because this thing is brand spanking new. No critic will see it for another month. In fact, at this point it's a safe bet you know more about the show than do at least 90% of Chicago's theater critics. Congratulations! Well done!
We CAN tell you that Chicago Public Radio called Strange Tree one of the most imaginative companies in town, and that in 2011 we produced two of the three plays that received Jeff nominations for Best New Work. We can tell you that most of our cast and designers have been working together for years. We can tell you that Ms. Bagby wrote this script specifically for Strange Tree, with its performers and aesthetic in mind. We can tell you that we're producing this piece in the lovely, intimate space at Signal Ensemble Theatre, where we put up last year's Funeral Wedding: The Alvin Play. We like those odds.

Our Indiegogo supporters get show tickets, limited-edition merch, public thanks, hang-out time with the Trees, all the fun of masquerading as mathematicians, and our undying gratitude. But tickets for opening night go fast, and we can't guarantee that they'll be available for long. If you want to come to opening night, that's great—but please, either donate early, or reserve your tickets separately through the link below.

If you're ready to use your expertise in finance, graphic design, or management to help the world become a more theatrical, adventurous place, we would love to have you on board. (Get it? Eh?) story:
WHAT'S HAPPENING HERE?

DONOVAN & CALDERÓN present their newest work, 18 1/2 Minutes at JACK in Brooklyn August 22nd - 25th, 2013.  Tickets are on sale now and available HERE.

18 1/2 Minutes is a multi-media theater piece by DONOVAN & CALDERÓN that explores the historical, technological and political circumstances around the mysterious 18 1/2 minute gap in the Nixon tapes and broader questions of time, silence, and erasure intrinsic to one of the most famous political scandals in modern U.S. political history.

At the center of the 1972 Watergate scandal, brought on and exacerbated by an extensive archive of surveillance audio tapes installed to record President Nixon's conversations in the White House, lies an 18 1/2 minute gap. 18 1/2 Minutes is staged as a conversation between two unlikely acquaintances as they ponder, dissect, investigate, and act out the meaning and implications around the taping system and the infamous gap that ultimately led to Nixon’s resignation. It begins as a retelling of events, but soon expands into a contemplation of recording and erasure, control and paranoia. Hidden microphones pick up the performers seemingly innocuous conversations and are played back and distorted. Cameras record surveillance footage and archival footage of Nixon floats by as if in a dream. Recycling the actual audio recording of the erased section of tape, the last 18 1/2 minutes of the piece exist as a video-sound-movement installation where the performers fall into the gap and enter a surreal world of repetitive gesture and motif, multiple video projections, digital cloning, and an immersive sound score. 

WHY WE NEED HELP

DONOVAN & CALDERÓN were fortunate enough to be Artists-In-Residence at Stanford University once again this past year to create and premiere 18 1/2 Minutes.  While there we worked with an amazing team of west coast designers including video artist Jeremiah Barber, sound designer Derek Phillips, and set designer Angrette McCloskey.

Since our December premiere we've been working hard all year to bring our exciting new work to New York.  We're being presented by JACK.  We've raised funds.  We've scraped together our pennies.  

We're so close! 

But we need your help to make this happen.  Your contributions will go directly towards the cost of bringing our incredible team of west coast designers to New York this summer.

Please help to close this small gap and make this performance possible.  

WHO WE ARE

Sean Donovan (American theater and dance artist) and Sebastián Calderón Bentin (Panamanian theater artist and performance scholar) have been in collaboration for 10 years making original performance.  Starting from an interdisciplinary and international perspective DONOVAN & CALDERÓN draws on the surreal, the banal and the everyday to create new theater work that responds to present social issues. We create performances that address particular social, political and historical questions while exploring the techniques and qualities of theater as a medium.

Our work has been seen at The Incubator Arts Project, Galapagos Art Space, The International Theater Festival of Panama, The Brooklyn Arts Exchange, Stanford University and New York University.

While DONOVAN & CALDERÓN are longtime collaborators committed to creating original performance as artistic partners, we also make work with many other prestigious artists and companies such as the Builders Association, Jane Comfort and Company, Faye Driscoll, Witness Relocation, Every House Has a Door, Jennie Marytai Liu, John Jesurun, and others.
