story:
WHAT WE DO:

Gritty City Rep (GCR) works with Oakland youth, aged 14-20, for a full school year, to produce high quality professional theatre.  Participation in our company is COMPLETELY FREE, so young people who traditionally can't access serious, long term, rigorous programs like ours can participate! We produce two shows each year:  a modern in the fall, and Shakespeare in the spring. Most of our performers start out with little or no theatrical experience. By the time they have worked with GCR for a year, they have developed as actors, their confidence is through the roof, they have a strong, supportive community, and they have set and achieved rigorous, long-term goals. In our video, GCR youth performers tell you more about why their experience with GCR has been so amazing!

WHY WE NEED HELP:

We have been renting different storage, rehearsal and performance spaces for the last year and a half. There are very few theatrical venues in Oakland, and virtually none that are small and affordable. We ended up performing our first show in Berkeley, and our second in a part of Oakland where our performers and audience members did not always feel safe.

Now, GCR has the honor of being offered a spot as a resident theatre company at the FLIGHT DECK, which means helping to design and build this brand new theatre complex in downtown Oakland. 

We are the only youth group to be included, with three other professional adult theatre companies, which is an incredible opportunity.  The plans for this space include a large rehearsal room, a 100-seat black box theatre, an office space, and storage for costume, props, and set pieces - everything theatre companies need all in one!

For $20,400, we get to help design and build out the Flight Deck this summer, and then rehearse and perform there for the next year!  Not only does this project benefit GCR, but also all of Oakland, as we are helping to create an amazing new performing arts space where multiple companies will hold shows and events.

We have raised half of the money we need, including a grant we recently received from the Alameda ArtsFund, but are looking for help with the other half!  Please help us create and move into our permanent home! Our commitment to serve under-served youth in Oakland by making our company 100% free to performers and their families means fund-raising is a challenge.  Raising $10,000 with this campaign will make it possible for Gritty City Rep to help create this safe, beautiful, professional space and make it our new home.

I CAN'T AFFORD IT, BUT I STILL WANT TO HELP - CAN I?

You can help get Gritty City Rep into the Flight Deck by passing this page along to anyone you think might be interested. Even if they can't help, they might know someone else who can.

PLEASE SHARE THESE LINKS:

OUR WEBSITE:  www.grittycityrep.org

OUR FACEBOOK:  https://www.facebook.com/GrittyCityRep

WHAT DO I GET?

Help us out and we would LOVE to hook you up!!  Here are some of the fabulous rewards you get - as if good karma and the satisfaction of supporting Oakland youth and the arts weren't enough!

$10+ gets you a huge shout out and thank you on facebook!

$25+ gets you listed on our website AND in our 2013-14 playbills as a funder!

$50+ gets you the soundtrack to either of our 2012-2013 productions!

$100+ gets you two tickets to our next show in December 2013!

$500+ gets you a GCR t-shirt!

$1000+ gets you a GCR t-shirt, soundtracks of our last two productions, Anon(ymous) and The Tempest, AND 2 tickets to our next show in December 2013!

QUESTIONS?

Feel free to ask the project creator directly if the above info doesn't answer all your questions.

story:
Thanks for the support!  We reached out goal of 3K but it's never too late to give to give a tax deductible donation!
_____________

on Friday, March 28th, thousands of people around the world will stop to.... 

what if the world stopped to dance?

would the earth shift on its axis?  

would strangers become friends? 

would we all speak a common language?

 join in, support us
celebrate the 10th year!

dance anywhere®

Friday, March 28...noon San Francisco, 3 p.m. New York, 4 p.m. Buenos Aires, 8 p.m. Rome and Paris…and hundreds of other locations around the world.

check out our website danceanywhere.org for locations and inspiration.

join us on March 28th...

As thousands of people around the world will stop to dance at the same time…wherever they are... in cars, on street corners, in subways, and at work…students, office workers, construction crews, dancers, and anyone who likes to dance will all stop to celebrate and record their events.

beginnings

In 2005, artist Beth Fein asked the question…What if the world stopped to dance?…
The annual “dance anywhere®” celebration has spread to 7 continents, 50 countries and 432 cities.

mission

  • by engaging people worldwide in a simultaneous, public art, performance
  • reconsider the definition of art, public space, and community
  • make dance accessible to more people inspire creativity
  • change perspectives through community art experiences

why do we need your help?

Since dance anywhere® is free for all participants and audience, we do not generate any income. We rely on the generosity of our supporters to pay for the assistants and interns who:

  • get the word out, in newsletters and social media
  • reach out to schools and diverse community groups
  • maintain the website and update content
  • interview artists, write, edit and publish blog posts
  • post performance - we need to gather all the media (like herding cats online)

Because we are a grassroots project your generous dollars enable dance anywhere®  to achieve our mission.

with your donation you get...

  • to redefine our ideas of art, public space, and community
  • to make dance accessible to everyone anywhere
  • the whole world to dance anywhere® and everywhere

other ways to help beyond a donation...

  • be a dancer!
    Move, twist, shake, stomp or jiggle (sign up at www.danceanywhere.org/participate)
  • take photos or video on March 28, 2014
  • Spread the word on facebook, twitter, instagram and other social media
  • use the Indiegogo share tools!

if you would like your gift to be tax deductible, please support us through our fiscal sponsor Kala Art Institute

perks

sticker                                                bumper sticker


    

poster  



                                                            canvas bag -both sides

dancer: Tanya Celeste / photograph by Weidong Yang

dancer: Josie Alvite  / photograph by Weidong Yang

dance anywhere® / photo: Weidong Yang

story:
Who we are & what we're doing & why

Every tree has a story. We have four. Four shorts about trees.

Seeking Still: Online dating is hard for everyone, but especially trees.
Tree Counsel: A tree can be a sign from God or just a tree.
Sophistree: A tree wants to die. The man who protects it must choose.
Does it Make a Sound? In the forest, choose your partner wisely.

Ray Burley Productions (RBP) made their first piece of theatre as a company in 2006. The company grew out of a need for more ensemble theater in Seattle, and gave themselves standards of ethics and quality that remain a part of their mission. It's in Los Angeles now, responding to that same discovered need. 

RBP went on hiatus for a few years when its founders started making new life journeys: some got married, one went back to school,  another had a baby, a bunch went traveling. It's back, and now it's bringing together great artists from all across Los Angeles (and one from Seattle)  for a thoughtful, intimate event. 

We're producing four world premieres from four different playwrights at the 2014 Hollywood Fringe Festival.  For some of the writers, this will be their Los Angeles theater premiere.

These 4 plays tell stories that will transport audiences to the fantastical, guide them to questions on the nature of being, and make them laugh, make them cry.

Trees stand stoically: changing the world, keeping it alive. We forget about trees sometimes, living in the middle of Los Angeles, until we notice the palms swaying elegantly or the deciduous leaves rustling, or we're on a hike through the needle-laden evergreens of Griffith Park. They live long lives, witness to events that no living person witnessed. They're a connection to the past and they preserve our future, but there are fewer of them each year. There's some funny in our shorts, but there's also that thread of philosophical musing that drives through each of them. What if we keep going the way we've been? What would happen if there were no more trees? Maybe these stories would get made up about them. 

Part of RBP's mission includes making theatre accessible to everyone. Because we believe finances should not be a hindrance to audiences, all our shows are Pay-What-You-Can, with suggested donations on a sliding scale, depending on income.

With your help, we can make our intimate show an experience our audiences will take with them into their everyday lives and maybe, hopefully, help them see the world with new eyes.

What we need

Brendan Weinhold and Stina Pederson are the purses behind the show. Honestly, you're helping them defray their out-of-pocket costs. 

Ray Burley Productions believes that the work of artists is valuable. To that end, every member of the team owns an equal part of the show. If we can pay all our expenses with your contributions, all our ticket sales money will go directly to our team in equal parts. Artists getting paid is a rarity, and it shouldn't be. Help us make it less rare!

These are our expenses:

  • Our biggest expense is renting the venue, the Bureau space at Schkapf. It's a very artsy space perfect for our very artsy show run by very artsy people, and it's pretty darn inexpensive, but even so, the rental fees for the run will be over $1000.
  • Fringe Fee. Being a part of the Fringe Festival means paying the Fringe Festival registration fee of $250. It gets us listed in the official Fringe program and means we're eligible for awards and have access to their staff for help making our show a success.
  • We also have a budget for costuming supplies. Our designer will be building everything herself, and you will be buying the supplies she needs to make our trees and other characters, fantastical and real. We have $100 budgeted here, but if this campaign is super-successful, we'll be able to increase that.
  • Our second biggest expense could be rehearsal space rental. If we have the funds, we'll be able to get a nice deal on renting our actual performance space for rehearsals. But even with a nice deal, that'd still run us up quite a bill of ~$1000. Our alternative is finding public spaces, like parks and/or production team members' homes. Which is okay, but not as ideal as rehearsing in the space.
  • We're required to have insurance. That costs money.
  • There's some miscellaneous stuff, like props, printing. We've allocated $100 for this. 
  • Marketing. We want everybody to see the show. That means they have to know about it. We'll do a lot of free advertising, but getting ads in places like Backstage, Bitter Lemons, LA Stage Alliance, and the print news costs some moolah. We've allocated $200 for this.

What if you raise more than enough to cover your costs? What about ticket sales?

If, through the generosity of donors and the popularity of the show, there is more money than costs, then all of the rest of the money will be split evenly between all the artists making the show, so they can afford to make more art.

What is theatre and why does it matter?

Lots of people have written on this topic. Here's what we're doing.

  • Our project helps artists give their voices a home in L.A.
  • All theatre impacts audiences with immediate, submersing experiences.
  • Trees are important. So is philosophy. We put ideas in audience brains.
  • Every brain deserves inspiration. Finances should not matter.

So why ours? Why did the authors write these stories?

Seeking Still uses trees as a metaphor for the isolation of being single, the feeling of being rooted in one spot by your fears, trauma, neuroses, and the quirks of your personality.  It isn't about what it's like to be a tree. It's about what it's like to be human, using trees as a metaphor.  Maybe you're just online dating to meet people.  But maybe you're online dating because you're looking for someone to come to you, to be your perfection, because you're so fixed in one spot you can't even think about being someone else's perfection. 

Tree Counsel arose out of a simple image of a man sitting under a tree, listening to church radio. What's that person like, and what happens when he meets someone very different from himself, but who is also drawn to the tree? This show explores the preconceptions and misconceptions we have about one another and how those can influence our relationships. 

Sophistree asks us to examine what motivates us to protect the environment, and more generally, what drives us to do anything about "making the world a better place." It examines how we choose to address personal and global problems given the impossibility of moral certitude. Today, we grapple with the biggest issues our species has ever faced, and at the same time face a torrential bombardment of often contradictory information. Moral certainty has never been more elusive, nor the need for action greater, than it is today.

Does It Make A Sound reminds us that we are not alone on this planet. We share it with so many other life forms. How do those other life forms feel about humans, each other, themselves... if you consider others' feelings, you can't help but respect them a lot more.  

Relative to having a drink at a bar, this is really cheap. Also, check out our perks. Some of them might actually be things you want. Even if they're not, come see our show!

Social media is good; holding hands is better.

We have a lot of friends. And each of our friends has a lot of friends. Please, whether you donate or not, if you feel comfortable doing so, tell anyone for whom the following is true (and anyone who has friends for whom the following is true) about us :

  • In Los Angeles and can come see our show
  • In the theater scene anywhere and who support live theatre
  • Believers in making art financially accessible
  • Interested in reminding our audiences how important trees are.

Word of mouth is the best. Like, in person word of mouth, I mean. Like, sitting down with your friends and saying "Hey, check this out. These people are making some freakin' theatre with an r-e at the end instead of e-r. Isn't that cool?" will probably make them look twice. And social media has broad reach... so both, I guess, is best?

Thanks for reading the wall of text. Now go hug a tree.
story_txt:
Who we are & what we're doing & whyEvery tree has a story. We have four. Four shorts about trees.Seeking Still: Online dating is hard for everyone, but especially trees.Tree Counsel: A tree can be a sign from God or just a tree.Sophistree: A tree wants to die. The man who protects it must choose.Does it Make a Sound? In the forest, choose your partner wisely.Ray Burley Productions (RBP) made their first piece of theatre as a company in 2006. The company grew out of a need for more ensemble theater in Seattle, and gave themselves standards of ethics and quality that remain a part of their mission. It's in Los Angeles now, responding to that same discovered need. RBP went on hiatus for a few years when its founders started making new life journeys: some got married, one went back to school,  another had a baby, a bunch went traveling. It's back, and now it's bringing together great artists from all across Los Angeles (and one from Seattle)  for a thoughtful, intimate event. We're producing four world premieres from four different playwrights at the 2014 Hollywood Fringe Festival.  For some of the writers, this will be their Los Angeles theater premiere.These 4 plays tell stories that will transport audiences to the fantastical, guide them to questions on the nature of being, and make them laugh, make them cry.Trees stand stoically: changing the world, keeping it alive. We forget about trees sometimes, living in the middle of Los Angeles, until we notice the palms swaying elegantly or the deciduous leaves rustling, or we're on a hike through the needle-laden evergreens of Griffith Park. They live long lives, witness to events that no living person witnessed. They're a connection to the past and they preserve our future, but there are fewer of them each year. There's some funny in our shorts, but there's also that thread of philosophical musing that drives through each of them. What if we keep going the way we've been? What would happen if there were no more trees? Maybe these stories would get made up about them. Part of RBP's mission includes making theatre accessible to everyone. Because we believe finances should not be a hindrance to audiences, all our shows are Pay-What-You-Can, with suggested donations on a sliding scale, depending on income.With your help, we can make our intimate show an experience our audiences will take with them into their everyday lives and maybe, hopefully, help them see the world with new eyes.What we needBrendan Weinhold and Stina Pederson are the purses behind the show. Honestly, you're helping them defray their out-of-pocket costs. Ray Burley Productions believes that the work of artists is valuable. To that end, every member of the team owns an equal part of the show. If we can pay all our expenses with your contributions, all our ticket sales money will go directly to our team in equal parts. Artists getting paid is a rarity, and it shouldn't be. Help us make it less rare!These are our expenses:
Our biggest expense is renting the venue, the Bureau space at Schkapf. It's a very artsy space perfect for our very artsy show run by very artsy people, and it's pretty darn inexpensive, but even so, the rental fees for the run will be over $1000.
Fringe Fee. Being a part of the Fringe Festival means paying the Fringe Festival registration fee of $250. It gets us listed in the official Fringe program and means we're eligible for awards and have access to their staff for help making our show a success.
We also have a budget for costuming supplies. Our designer will be building everything herself, and you will be buying the supplies she needs to make our trees and other characters, fantastical and real. We have $100 budgeted here, but if this campaign is super-successful, we'll be able to increase that.
Our second biggest expense could be rehearsal space rental. If we have the funds, we'll be able to get a nice deal on renting our actual performance space for rehearsals. But even with a nice deal, that'd still run us up quite a bill of ~$1000. Our alternative is finding public spaces, like parks and/or production team members' homes. Which is okay, but not as ideal as rehearsing in the space.
We're required to have insurance. That costs money.
There's some miscellaneous stuff, like props, printing. We've allocated $100 for this. 

Marketing. We want everybody to see the show. That means they have to know about it. We'll do a lot of free advertising, but getting ads in places like Backstage, Bitter Lemons, LA Stage Alliance, and the print news costs some moolah. We've allocated $200 for this.

story:
I'm creating my dream life. 

My dream is to be a performing artist. This dream is leading me to San Francisco and I'm running after it.

Hello! My name is Amber-Tiana and I'm raising funds to move to California! San Francisco to be specific. I've always had dreams of being a performer unfortunately for the last 15 years or so "Real Life" got in the way but no more will I allow such a thing to hold me back. 

I'm from Hawaii and live here still so broadway auditions are few and far between but when they come around I'm there! I used to do it as a time passer and a maybe-this-time-will-be-the-time-er but then I started getting serious. Then I started dropping $700.00 a trip to fly out to California for auditions. It got to the point where the casting directors would say, "Amber, did you fly all the way out from Hawaii again?" and I'd say, "Yes I did."

Auditions always went well. I always got a call back, never got a role but I was always so close! It's hard to be so close to your dream and live so FAR away from where the action is. 

IF (and when) I make my goal of $10,000 I will use it to do the following: 

1.) Moving costs from HI to SF. $1,000

2.) Pay for my ONE WAY TICKET to San Francisco. $500.00 

3.) Find an apartment, make a deposit, first months rent & last months rent. $2,500.00

4.) Rent for an additional 2 months… just in case. $2,000.00

5.) 3 months of transportation. $500.00

6.) Cost for audition needs. (Headshots, shoes, copies of resume, etc.) $500.00

7.) Spending money for the unexpected curve balls life throws at you like getting sick, a flat bike tire or the occasional festival which is critical to attend for networking purposes. $3,000.00 (Or more. More is okay. I'm not objecting to more.) 

I'm from a tiny island in the middle of the ocean and there aren't nearly as many opportunities here as there are in the mainland. I want to be able to live an amazing life and then come back and give back to my community. That is my goal. I hope that one day I will be able to create opportunities for people in my community so they can do what they love without leaving if they don't want to

The biggest risk I have is falling on my face. I could be packing up my entire life and moving to a city to live my dream and instead be hit with rejection after rejection after rejection. If that happens, I will get up and I will get up and I will get up. Nothing will ever be worse than not trying at all because I was too scared of failing.

If setbacks arise I will do what I need to do to rise above them. I've lived my entire life doing what people have told me to do based on their experiences of failure. I want to experience success so when I'm asked advice I can say, "Go for it. I did. You can do it. I did."

Once I achieve my goal a thank you concert will be held for all my contributors before I leave for California. Once I am in SF and settled I will produce a weekly video blog of documenting the amazing journey you all helped me create.

story:
Short Summary

We are PartyHAT Productions: an independent, experimental, and altogether new theatre company based in Denver, Colorado. This campaign is for our debut repertory productions of two brand new plays: Un-Speakable, by H.E. Young, and Fix, by Tony Ryan. Keep reading to find out a little bit about who we are, and about the shows that you kind people will be helping to make possible.

PartyHAT:

As a theatre company, we are primarily concerned with the new, with the norms, and with their subversions. Our goal is to present an obfuscation of identity and experience not often seen in the mainstream theatre, as well as to present the opportunity for any and all artistic voices to be heard loudly, regardless of background or identity. We hope to accomplish this both by providing a platform for new and emerging theatrical works by up and coming playwrights, as well as by presenting fresh and innovative takes on established dramatic and theatrical works. 

The Shows:

This campaign will support the production of two brand new works, written by two of our founding members.

Un-Speakable is a one act series of vignettes about relationships, their trials, their futility, their beauty, and their universality. It is about love, its agony, and its ultimate perseverance, conveyed through short scenes containing music, heightened reality, and the destruction of a suburban living room.

Fix is a one act play about Tracy, a woman who needs to be fixed, and Geoff, whom she meets on the side of the road, and who she believes can fix her. This does not go as well as she'd planned, as both their pasts destroy any hope of their future.

The Venue:

The Bakery is a small, independently owned arts collective nestled right near Coors Field in the LoDo neighborhood of Denver. Find out more about them, and about their mission at https://www.facebook.com/thebakerydenver.

What We Need & What You Get

Turns out, theatre costs money! So we need your money to make our theatre. We are asking for $1500, which we believe to be a thoroughly attainable goal, spread out amongst all of our supporters.

Your money will go to such things as renting the space, renting the lighting and sound equipment, buying props, building the set, buying the costumes, and, most importantly, paying the artists involved!

Ideally, we'd like to pay our playwrights, director, producer, actors designers, and stage manager $100 each minimum, plus a percentage of the proceeds from the production where applicable. They'd each do it for free if they could, but artists need to eat, and we want to thank everyone adequately for their contributions! The more we raise-- if we exceed our goal-- the more we get to pay our artists! We think that's pretty swell!

We could do these shows on a bare-bones minimum budget of $360, but in order to provide the best product possible for our skills and talents, and for your eye and ear-holes, we need a concrete design budget of $1700. We can provide some of the funds, but we are but lowly students, and we need your help to reach our design-based dreams!

The Impact

In early 2014, the founding members of PartyHAT Productions produced an independent project at the University of Denver entitled Gym Party. It was a risky, experimental, and highly interactive piece of theatre, and against all odds, it was a smashing success. This inspired us to create a venue-- our own theatre company-- wherein we could continue to develop and produce experimental theatrical endeavors.

We are passionate about new, emerging, independent, off-center, and experimental theatre. We believe that the world needs more theatre run by young people, for an evolving and emerging experimental theatre scene. We are passionate artists, and we wish to bring a new kind of entertainment media to the Denver theatre scene. Your donation will help us get on our feet, and help us prove what we can do, and that our work is valuable, by helping our first entirely independent come to fruition. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Live theatre is risky business! We want to be prepared for the worst, but with a living, breathing theatrical production, all sorts of exciting and entirely un-anticipated things can go wrong.

    Recognizing this, your donations will help us to be as prepared as humanly possible for whatever bizarre and frightening challenges may arise during our production process. Having a financial cushion will help us to ensure that our show proceeds as smoothly as it can, and that the finished product that you receive is the most professional, well-organized performance that it can be!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    No money? That's okay! We're students! We understand!

    If a financial contribution just isn't feasible for you at this time, there are other ways you can help! The easiest way is just to spread the word about PartyHAT Productions!

    You can do this by sharing our Indiegogo campaign, and by liking and sharing our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/partyhatproductions.

    Let's do this! Let's make some art!

story:
For those who don't know me, I'm a dancer, teacher and choreographer working primarily in Seattle.  Lately I have been working on a project that would take me and my dance company to New York, premiering our latest work and taking our program out into the city to work with at-risk teens.   These plans are now on hold due to a random and unprovoked act of violence on Capital Hill when I was beaten by 10 unknown assailants and my jaw was broken on both sides.  The damage to my jaw will require two surgeries, rendering me unable to work for at least 8 weeks and delaying, at some cost, our company's project in New York. 

Meeting the goal of this campaign would enable me to meet my living expenses during the 8 weeks I will be unable to work, satisfy some of the medical expenses not covered by my insurance and once recovered, resume the work I believe in and am passionate about.  Before I can continue my work helping others I need your help.

One more thing.  My injury has created great hardship for our small dance company and has affected the livelihoods of the other dancers.  I hope you will visit the DASSdance website and consider making a contribution at www.DASSdance.org. 

Thank you so much, and please remember that any amount, even a $10 or $20 contribution, will help a lot.

story:
Eyestrings Theatre Company presents:

SEE WHAT I SEE: A Shakespeare Experiment

We are really excited about our new production that we're taking to Oxford Playhouse 27-28 June.

Last year we decided to look at the theme of Mental Illness in Shakespeare and devise a new production that would present Shakespeare in a way never seen before.

We have taken text from over 18 of his plays and created a new narrative and an entirely new way to access Shakespeare's plays for a modern audience.

Having held workshops throughout the year, we are taking See What I See to The Oxford Playhouse 27-28 June to get the work in front of an audience and gain feedback in order for us to continue our process.

We really believe that we're on to something with this project and feel we are getting that bit closer to achieving an exciting new style.

We've managed to raise the majority of money for our trip to Oxford but need your help to get over that final hurdle and make the trip a real success.

We have a week before we perform so we're trying our best to see how much we can raise in our final week.... 

Our goal is £500 and this will go towards our travel, props, costume and our marketing costs.

If you are around Oxford next week we would love you to see the show.

We want as many people through the door as are very keen to hear your thoughts. This project is dependent on the audience and we cannot go further without your help.

You can book your tickets for Oxford here -

http://www.oxfordplayhouse.com/theatre/3197/See-What-I-See/Friday-27-June/BT-Studio
story_txt: Eyestrings Theatre Company presents:SEE WHAT I SEE: A Shakespeare ExperimentWe are really excited about our new production that we're taking to Oxford Playhouse 27-28 June.Last year we decided to look at the theme of Mental Illness in Shakespeare and devise a new production that would present Shakespeare in a way never seen before.We have taken text from over 18 of his plays and created a new narrative and an entirely new way to access Shakespeare's plays for a modern audience.Having held workshops throughout the year, we are taking See What I See to The Oxford Playhouse 27-28 June to get the work in front of an audience and gain feedback in order for us to continue our process.We really believe that we're on to something with this project and feel we are getting that bit closer to achieving an exciting new style.We've managed to raise the majority of money for our trip to Oxford but need your help to get over that final hurdle and make the trip a real success.We have a week before we perform so we're trying our best to see how much we can raise in our final week.... Our goal is £500 and this will go towards our travel, props, costume and our marketing costs.If you are around Oxford next week we would love you to see the show. We want as many people through the door as are very keen to hear your thoughts. This project is dependent on the audience and we cannot go further without your help.You can book your tickets for Oxford here -http://www.oxfordplayhouse.com/theatre/3197/See-What-I-See/Friday-27-June/BT-Studio

story:
A dance studio playground for adults!

     

Hi! Kathleen Hahn here.  

I have thoroughly enjoyed the past year I’ve spent in NYC, but it's time I head back to my home state and make my dream of having a dance and fitness studio come true.

For those of you that may not know my backstory, I lived in Asheville, NC for five years where I taught funky dance classes, yoga, and started my business, I Do Dances, choreographing First Dances for couples getting married. I  have spent 2015 in NYC studying dance, personal training for some of my favorite clients, and getting a few opportunities to perform.

Kathleen’s history with dance:

Dance has been the biggest part of my life since I was a wee three year old. I  started out studying ballet 3 to 5 days a week which eventually lead me to the University of North Carolina School of the Arts’ (UNCSA) boarding school for my last two years of high school. I made the switch to modern dance in college and received my Bachelor of Fine Arts also from UNCSA. I spent seven years in N.Y.C. performing with three modern dance companies, making dance films, working as a personal trainer and yoga instructor, and going to cooking school. And then I moved to Asheville...


The dream:

... and then 5 years later I decided to come back to NYC to be around more dance and performance and all the opportunities a bigger city has to offer. And one of the things this year has given me time to discover is that I passionately want my own space to share and teach dance, 24 hours a day if I want!

I get so much joy in teaching whether it’s helping couples with no dance experience  dance free of self consciousness on their wedding day, helping people realize they actually CAN dance, giving someone an opportunity to perform that never has, challenging seasoned dancers with something new, helping people feel free with their movement, feel sexy, in control, out of control, expressive, and, my main mission, making sure they have fun!!! I mean, I have enjoyed many, many of my 34 years of dancing but I’ve also spent a good amount of that time making sure my dancing “looked good” which doesn’t always translate into the most fun dancing ever. I am a big proponent of technique but I am a bigger proponent of FUN, and play! It can be easy as adults to forget how important play is. We need to dance more. We need to play more!

I am also a big proponent of understanding your body, appreciating your body, and living in a body that feels good. It is extremely satisfying to help people gain more appreciation and awareness of their body.

I believe that pretty much everyone inherently wants to move their bodies and dance, but through the years people start to build walls of self consciousness between themselves and their dancing selves. I desperately want to help people get back to their 6 year old selves where dancing just felt good and what other people thought of their dancing didn't cross their mind. 

Sometimes I've been known to convince my students to learn an entire dance zombie style and flashmob it in a random grocery store. 

A quick shoutout:

I have Loretta Woolley to thank for most of the things I created in Asheville. The studio/event space she shared with me in her downtown sandwich shop, Loretta’s Cafe, made all of my dance classes, and most all of my ideas, come to fruition. I am forever and ever grateful for her support in what was the beginning of my falling in love with teaching dance. Eat at Loretta’s Cafe and Mayfel’s for delicious food! 

DANCECLUB, the studio!

DANCECLUB will be open to adults of all ages. The studio will also be the home of I Do Dances, teaching couples personalized First Dances, helping with father/daughter and mother/son dances, flashmob style dances for the wedding party, and burlesque and pole bachelorette parties. The space will also be available for renting during off hours for rehearsals and events. Visit IDoDances.com (website improvements to come)to learn more. 

I taught over 400 students and 100 couples in my time in Asheville and they weren’t all women.  Everyone is welcome! I made over 400 dance videos on youtube  from my classes and performances. Feel free to check them out: Kathleen's Youtube Channel and DANCECLUB's website: DANCECLUBAsheville.com (will also be revamped soon with your help!) which will give you an idea of what I was up to in Asheville. 

Below is a list of some of the classes I will start with and continue to build from. I take requests! If there's something you've been wanting that I can provide I'd love to know about it!

  • Pole dancing classes galore! Learn slinky choreography, spins and climbs, inversions, how to dance with fluidity, all while building strength.

  • Dance and Sweat - A class good for all levels. Repetition makes it easy to follow and keeps your heart rate up. Always good music set to a decades theme or artist.

  • Burlesque dancing - Burlesque from a dancer’s perspective. Learn routines, chair dances, the art of striptease and more.

  • High heels - Amp up your sass and learn how to dance with fierce ease in heels.

  • Jazz/funk - A class series learning an entire dance to fun music you can’t resist.

  • Booty Camp - An upbeat strength training class designed to compliment dance training. A full body experience will make you feel stronger in your dancing and in life. 

  • Modern - exploring different qualities that will expand your movement vocabulary and compliment all other dance modalities.
  • Flexibility and Conditioning - An important part of any dancer or human's life! Especially necessary for pole dancing to expand your abilities and stay safe and healthy with a balance of building strength and length.

  • Flashmob class? - I loved teaching the flashmob class. My only hesitation is finding new places to flashmob! We may have to field trip to Black Mountain or Hendersonville!

The plan:

I will be moving back to Asheville in late January and opening the studio as soon as I find a space. I have begun the search for a space and have seen enough possibilities that I am confident it will happen quickly. I will be looking for a space that won't need a lot of extra work or construction for it to be DANCECLUB ready. 

The time I've spent writing a cohesive, thorough business plan, having 4 years of experience teaching in the Asheville market, and spending the last year expanding my skillset will no doubt be the foundation for my success. 

I have had a lot of time to think realistically about the challenges of owning my own business, my competition, how much work and effort, love and persistence it will take, how to make smart financial decisions and stay on top of it, and the importance of consistent marketing and sharing. I have used these thoughts to create systems to put in to place that will get me as close to guaranteeing my success as possible. I'm not just passionate about dance I thrive off of the challenge of owning my own business. And the act of you supporting me in something that means so much to me, well ...  will most likely make me cry from pure joy, immense gratitude, and extreme appreciation!

Your contribution will go towards:

Studio space - rent for three months

Poles and installation

Mirrors

Sound system

Lighting

Outdoor and indoor signs

Fitness equipment like mats, dumbbells, balls

Website revamping and S.E.O. help 

Marketing

Advertising

Insurance and utilities for the first 3 months

Business Licenses

A small amount of furniture and decoration for the studio 


Perhaps you can please share with other dance lovers and supporters of good things?!

Can you think of anyone you know that might be interested in supporting my campaign? Every little bit of spreading the word helps and I will very much appreciate any amount of talking it up you can do.
Share it on Facebook: 
Send the link in an email: 
Thank you ten thousand times for any amount and type of support; emotional, verbal, hugs, spreading the word, financial! 

Thank you, thank you from the bottom of my heart to the tips of my tapping toes!!!!!!! THANK YOU!!!


Have a question for me? Please ask. Have a class you’d like to see in Asheville? Let me know. Concerned you won’t get a space in class? Go ahead and buy a membership. ;)

Photographers credit: Peter Lorenz (top photo) and Steve Clarke (in red leo)

And a huge thank you to Adam Larsen for his brilliance in shooting and editing the video.

story:
About Us

This summer, Plays in the Park is bringing live theater back to Redwood Park in Arcata , CA.  We're shaking the dust off the classics with As You Like It, Shakepeare's rowdy, gender-bending romantic comedy, then throwing into the mix the heart-felt dramatic comedy Late: A Cowboy Song, written by Pulitzer-nominated playwright Sarah Ruhl.

What We Need 

Our local business community has already been incredibly supportive through sponsorships, but we still need that one last push!  Your contribution will go towards helping us pay expenses like:

-Royalties and insurance (over $1000 between them).

-Printing costs.  We've got scripts, posters, programs...  It adds up.

-Stage and lighting quipment rental costs.

Community Partners

Plays in the Park is proud to be a Dream-Maker Project of the Ink People Center for the Arts, and is partnered with both the Arcata Recreation Division and the North Coast Repertory Theater.  Along with our partners, we are firmly committed to the betterment of art, nature, diversity, and gender equality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute?  You can still help!

-Spread the word! Facebook, email, word of mouth - these are all great ways to help us raise awareness of our project and our fundraising.

-Volunteer!  Want to usher, work concessions, or maybe even work backstage?  Contact us at www.playsinthepark.org

story:
We are fundraising to put on the performance of Illuminatio:Creation at the Rainier Valley Cultural Center in Seattle on November 21st and 22nd of this year, 2014. 

In 2006, a small company of actors in Ciudad Real, Spain began developing a new play called Illuminatio:Yo Soy about their own collective journey to self-realization. Due to circumstances, the play was never performed. In 2012, the playwright, Antonio Delgado, showed Illuminatio to his friend, Amanda Goodwin, and asked if she would create the choreography for what he had intended to be a multi-disciplinary production. In 2013, The Illuminatio Project, a company of artists dedicated to performing the play Illuminatio:Yo Soy in Seattle as it was intended by the author, was born. What began as a tribute of each friend to their belief in the abilities of the other would develop into a journey of self-discovery for a small group of dancers in Seattle.

Creation is the second act to be choreographed and presented. The first part to be presented, Slavery of the System, was completed and performed in summer of 2013. Where Slavery focused on the darker and more difficult aspects of this journey of self-discovery, Creation reflects a process of searching in the darkness for something you know is there and then slowly trying to see it well enough to make others see it too. When I began, all I knew was that I wanted to make a dance about harmony. That led to research on mandalas, the Golden Mean, sacred geometry, and sound healing (there is a list of research materials on the Sources page of the website, if you are interested.)  The rehearsal process has been very exploratory, driven by the question of how we can embody these concepts and communicate them through movement.

Creation requires nine dancers, an original musical composition, a film component projected on the back wall as part of the performance, and original images to adorn the stage, as well as promotional and administrative support. Your donations pay for the performance venue and the artists’ time. Your support of this project, therefore, is crucial. The success of the project will be acheived through the combination of our creative contributions and your financial ones. The Illuminatio Project is powered by Shunpike (www.shunpike.org), and contributions are tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

story:
ETERNAL FLAME: THE BALLAD OF JESSIE BLADE has been a passion project of Tommy Jamerson’s and Josh Julian’s for the past two years. Combining their unapologetic love of camp, drag queens, and all things 80's, this totally tubular new play marks not only their first collaborative effort, but their first time having their work presented on an Off Broadway stage.

When young, fresh faced, go-getter Jessie Blade leaves his small town of Bible Hill, Minnesota and moves to the mean streets of Manhattan with a pocketful of dreams, he soon gets more than he bargained for.  With enough new wave references to tickle even the gnarliest funny bone and more plot twists and characters than an episode of Dynasty, this is one ballad that’s not to be missed!

We need YOUR HELP to bring this 80's extravaganza to life! From cast and crew costs to lights and sounds, bringing this storied decade into the modern day is no cheap trick. Our goal is to immerse our audience in all the decadence the 80's had to offer. Big hair, acid-wash jean, leg warmers, and even scrunchies are on the menu. Anyone who lived through the era knows it takes a lot of money to look that cheap!

Please help by donating TODAY!

You KNOW you don't want to miss out on this show, baby!

story:
Short Summary

Theatre Network of Wilmington has created a unique and accessible dramtic arts instruction program that has touched the lives of dozen of Wilmington children. In addition to after school programs at low or no cost to local kids, the Network has provided in school instruction for inner city students at DC Virgo Prepartory Academy, after school programs for Girl's Club of Wilmington, scholarships to the main after school program held at TheatreNOW and much more!

What We Need & What You Get

Currently the Network is desperately in need to funds to not only continue its work but to expand and bring on other dramatic educators to assist with classes and instruction. We also need many of the basics items that programs like this require (costumes, technical gear, set pieces, etc.) What you get in return is the knowledge that arts education will continue despite state school budgets being cut. As the Network is a registered 501c3, you will also be able to deduct your contribution on your taxes. 

The Impact

Our impact is felt in so many ways through the young people in our community. For the DC Virgo students, the transformation from the beginning of the 2012 school year to it's end in June was remarkable! In addition, the Girl's Club's end of year showcase was absolutely outstanding! These young ladies went from barely being able to speak in front of an audience to performing heartfelt, emotional scenes packed with amazing detail and energy!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't assist with our campaign financially, you can aid us by spreading the word. Arts education funding from our government is drying up or non-existant in many local schools and this is a way that you can help restore this valuable resource to our area's young people. Executive Director and primary educator Zach Hanner has watched shy children emerge from their shells and become budding performers in just a few short months through the program's improv-based instruction. These children are learning to be comfortable in front of an audience and their talents are shining through with just a little coaxing and motivation! The program works and now we just need your help to make it grow!

story:
OUR PROJECT

About Fathom Theatre
 
Founded in 2011, Fathom Theatre is a not-for-profit organization that explores ways of producing theatre and engaging the community in the beautiful rural setting of Twillingate, Newfoundland and Labrador. Fathom is a young and energetic group embarking on our mission to create and produce new work, design outreach activities, and enrich our community in the process.
 
2013 Fathom Theatre Festival

Our first ever Fathom Theatre Festival is a repertory theatre project that will take place in Twillingate, Newfoundland and Labrador from July 3 to August 18 and consist of the presentation of two original theatrical works (Of Heroes & Herring and Adrift) for a total of 28 performances. Our project is focused on the exchange of ideas, history, and culture through storytelling, where theatre becomes a ground for sharing our identity and our local talent.

The Plays
 
Of Heroes & Herring - Written by the Company & Directed by Greg White
 
Journey through the history of Twillingate, from the pioneers who forged a meaningful existence on our rocky shores to modern day struggles and celebrations. Using a mix of tradition and imagination we weave an exciting hour of music, comedy, and storytelling that thrusts you into the action and asks that you share a story of your own!
 
Adrift - Written by Greg White & Directed by Sarah Carter

It is early April 1917 and four young men must venture across the frozen waters off Fogo Island in search of seals. The wind changes, the ice drifts, and the men vanish, leaving only a gaff pole to wash ashore inscribed with “Down to Perish, April 11″. Hear the story told through the eyes of Joseph Jacobs, the owner of that gaff.

Based on a true story.

 

WHAT WE NEED

In developing this project Fathom Theatre relies on financial support from local businesses, project grants, our patrons, and especially donations from supporters like you ... but despite our hard efforts to secure funding for this project we have fallen short of our goal. We have recently been dealt a blow when we did not receive funding from a major arts funder. This has left us facing some tough decisions. With your help the festival will stay alive!

Your donation, whatever the size, will be used towards our productions costs (sets, props, rents, etc), and to ensure that our local performers are rewarded for their hard work and for sharing their talent with our community and our visitors.

 

NOT ABLE TO DONATE?

If you are not able to make a monetary donation you can always come to one of our plays OR help us spread the word about our project and our online campaign!

Visit Us

ALL performances take place at the Anchor Inn Hotel & Suites in Twillingate, Newfoundland & Labrador from JULY 3 to AUGUST 18, 2013.

Of Heroes & Herring - Wednesdays & Saturdays @ 8:30PM

Adrift - Thursdays @ 2:30PM & Sundays @ 8:30PM

For detailed info on showtimes and locations please visit: www.fathomtheatre.ca/whats-on

For ticket reservations please call 1-709-884-2777 or 1-800-450-3950


Contact Us

Website: www.fathomtheatre.ca

Email: info@fathomtheatre.ca

 

THANKS!
story_txt:
OUR PROJECT
About Fathom Theatre
 
Founded in 2011, Fathom Theatre is a not-for-profit organization that explores ways of producing theatre and engaging the community in the beautiful rural setting of Twillingate, Newfoundland and Labrador. Fathom is a young and energetic group embarking on our mission to create and produce new work, design outreach activities, and enrich our community in the process.
 
2013 Fathom Theatre Festival

Our first ever Fathom Theatre Festival is a repertory theatre project that will take place in Twillingate, Newfoundland and Labrador from July 3 to August 18 and consist of the presentation of two original theatrical works (Of Heroes & Herring and Adrift) for a total of 28 performances. Our project is focused on the exchange of ideas, history, and culture through storytelling, where theatre becomes a ground for sharing our identity and our local talent.The Plays

 

Of Heroes & Herring - Written by the Company & Directed by Greg White
 
Journey through the history of Twillingate, from the pioneers who forged a meaningful existence on our rocky shores to modern day struggles and celebrations. Using a mix of tradition and imagination we weave an exciting hour of music, comedy, and storytelling that thrusts you into the action and asks that you share a story of your own!
 

Adrift - Written by Greg White & Directed by Sarah Carter

It is early April 1917 and four young men must venture across the frozen waters off Fogo Island in search of seals. The wind changes, the ice drifts, and the men vanish, leaving only a gaff pole to wash ashore inscribed with “Down to Perish, April 11″. Hear the story told through the eyes of Joseph Jacobs, the owner of that gaff.
Based on a true story.
 


WHAT WE NEED
In developing this project Fathom Theatre relies on financial support from local businesses, project grants, our patrons, and especially donations from supporters like you ... but despite our hard efforts to secure funding for this project we have fallen short of our goal. We have recently been dealt a blow when we did not receive funding from a major arts funder. This has left us facing some tough decisions. With your help the festival will stay alive!
Your donation, whatever the size, will be used towards our productions costs (sets, props, rents, etc), and to ensure that our local performers are rewarded for their hard work and for sharing their talent with our community and our visitors.
 
NOT ABLE TO DONATE?
If you are not able to make a monetary donation you can always come to one of our plays OR help us spread the word about our project and our online campaign!

story:
What We're Doing...

We're raising funds to cover the costs associated with our 2013 Toronto Fringe Festival production of Strolling Player, which will run at the Tarragon Theatre Extra Space July 3 to 14. The show is written by Richard Willis with Heidi Reimer, directed by Robert Richmond, and produced by Lisa-Dent-Couturier of Compass Theatre Productions.

What the Show's About

Strolling Player is a creative project with a utilitarian inspiration. When English actor Richard Willis married Canadian writer Heidi Reimer, they applied for his Canadian residency. One grueling immigration form demanded a list of Richard’s location and activities each month since his eighteenth birthday. The years had been dictated by the vagaries and upheavals of an actor’s life. Age eighteen was a long time ago.

Strolling Player began as a blog giving the heart behind the facts on the government form, and metamorphosed into theatre when producer Lisa Dent-Couturier asked Richard for a one-man performance. Together Richard and Heidi shaped this accounting into a celebration of love and artistic dreams.

There’s the boy at his father's seaside theatre on the island of Guernsey, watching a play, entranced, and knowing his future. There's the paparazzi stalking a doomed marriage. There’s the fall off the stage on an opening night. A backstage brawl and a wedding ring, flung into a parking lot. Debilitating tours across America. Rehearsal in New York on 9/11, a performance for George Bush at The White House, a break-up in Venice. Encounters with Daniel Day Lewis, Richard Burton, Dr. Who, Oscar Wilde. And Shakespeare, his first love. Always, there is Shakespeare.

With original music by Dougal Rose and the expert direction of Robert Richmond, Strolling Player is raw, true, and beautiful, a theatrical life in 90 minutes.

A few sweet words about past shows:

"By turns funny, sad, and always excellent...Do not miss this one."

“Richard Willis delivered with…endearing audacity and vulnerability.”

“A spell-binding presentation.”

Who is Richard Sheridan Willis?

Richard has been a professional actor since the age of six. He trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. He was last seen in Toronto as the Father in The Railway Children, and is just finishing up performances in Washington DC at the Folger Shakespeare Theatre, playing the Chorus in Henry V and Malvolio in Twelfth Night to rave reviews. He has appeared on Flashpoint, Law & Order, Nikita, Dr. Who, Lost Girl, and numerous other films and TV series. 

Where Your Money Will Go

Our projected budget for this production is roughly $4,000. We want to cover half of our budget with this campaign. That's still a lot of beans! We are an emerging production company and are doing our best to support Richard's wonderful show, but we can't do it alone - we need your help! Here's how your contributions will be divided:

50% : honorariums to cast and crew
25% : promotion and marketing materials, posters, programs, etc. 
20% : props, costumes, set
5% : fee to fundraising site

We would be grateful for any amount you can donate. EVERY BIT HELPS! We understand how hard you work for your money so we want to offer something in return, from your name in our programs to free tickets, CDs and DVDs of the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help. We'd love it if you could get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, and anywhere else you feel inspired.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Three Women is a poetic play, what would be called a performance poem these days, about three difference birth experiences:  a live birth, a miscarriage, and an abortion.  The piece was written by Sylvia Plath, poet and author of The Bell Jar and explores their emotional states through poetry.  We are also intending to add dancers to the piece who can express the physical discomfort and contortions that these three women go through as well.
 
Written, as it was, in the early 1960s, it is an important text of early "second wave" feminism and the issues that women of that day (and ours) face in dealing with the medical profession, with society, and with themselves.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $350 for the initial Fringe Festival entry fee and then additional money to do advertising and marketing, which will include postcards, flyers, and guerilla marketing.  Even a donation of $10 will help tremendously. 
 
All donors, regardless of level, will be listed in our program, which will be distributed at our 5 performances, and also on any websites and/or Facebook pages that we set up.  For donors of $100 or more, you will also get a display ad/graphic in the program and on the websites.
 

The Impact

Shows like this are what fringe festivals were designed for--artistically-oriented, multidisciplinary shows.  Very often, though, it is the more humorous, more easily-accessible shows that do very well in the fringe.  Shows like this sometimes have small, if appreciative, audiences. 
 
We recently did a shortened performance of the piece and found that many writers and even English teachers did not know that this piece was part of Plath's artistic oevre.  So in addition to the themes of the poem itself, this will bring another piece of Plath's work to the attention of audiences--those who are familiar with her and those who aren't.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also join our mailing list, particularly if you live in Minnesota, and help us out by:
 
*Coming to the show.
*Posting flyers and placing postcards around town.
*Putting it out on Facebook, listervs, and your personal email list.
 
We need money to get the show rolling, but at the other end, we need audience members, too!

story:
TILL - The Story of Mamie and Emmett

A New Musical by Leo Schwartz

  • Leo Schwartz is a multi-award winning composer of Theatre and Film. His musical "Under A Rainbow Flag" (now titled "HONOR") was the recipient of the 2013 Joseph Jefferson Awards for Best New Work and Best Musical Production, a first in the 40+ year history of the Jeffs.

  • "TILL" is about the death of innocence and the amazing strength of a mother. It reflects the unique bond a mother has with her son and her strength in raising a boy on her own. Historians are better suited to explore the horrific deed and consequences of the sham trial of Emmett's murderers. Instead, my musical, "TILL", explores a son's growth into manhood, a mother's devotion, and a powerful unceasing love.


I'm asking you to help fund the recording of the score to TILL

  • First impressions are huge! A good studio recording of a new work is MANDATORY to getting the work on stage. It's what I had to do with HONOR and it is what I am going to do with "TILL".
  • "TILL" has a cast of of 5 women and 6 men. 24 songs in all. In order to pay for studio time, recording engineers, and the performers, including two pianists, I am putting up $2,000 of my own funds. But I need YOUR help to fund the rest.

About the Score!

The score to "TILL" is a brilliant mix of gospel, blues, theatre music, and even some country and western. Unique to the show is the presence of a Gospel Quartet who are on stage for the duration of the show, often taking part in the action, and singing, singing, singing!

A recent public performance of the duet "Cherish The Child" brought raves from the audience and the recurring question, "When do we get to hear the rest of the score?"

As of 11-7-13, 14 songs are completed and I anticipate the remainder will be done by the end of November.  I hope to go into the studio February 2014!

This is an important, human story that needs to be told. I hope you can help me.

story:
Λίγα λόγια για το έργο

Ο μεγάλος Γερμανός φιλόσοφος Ιμμάνουελ Καντ ταξιδεύει με τη σύζυγό του, τον υπηρέτη του και τον παπαγάλο του με ένα υπερωκεάνιο προς την Νέα Υόρκη, στη δική μας σύγχρονη εποχή (το έργο γράφτηκε το 1978). Το Πανεπιστήμιο της Κολούμπια πρόκειται να τον αναγορεύσει Επίτιμο Διδάκτορα. Ο Καντ υποφέρει απο γλαύκωμα και είναι σχεδόν εντελώς τυφλός. Το Πανεπιστήμιο της Κολούμπια διαθέτει τους καλύτερους οφθαλμιάτρους στον κόσμο, κι έτσι σκοπός του ταξιδιού δεν είναι μόνο η βράβευση του Καντ, αλλά και η εγχείρηση για να αποκτήσει ξανά το φως του. Ο Καντ πιστεύει πως δίνοντας στην Αμερική το “φως του Λόγου”, η Αμερική θα τού δώσει πίσω την χαμένη του όραση. Μαζί του στο ταξίδι, εκτός από τον οικογενειακό του περίγυρο, βρίσκονται μια εκατομμυριούχος που θέλει να ανελκύσει τον βυθισμένο Τιτανικό, ένας συλλέκτης έργων τέχνης, ένας καρδινάλιος που είναι υποψήφιος για Πάπας κι ένας ναύαρχος, όλοι οι εκπρόσωποι δηλαδή της ευρωπαϊκής μεγαλοαστικής τάξης, η οποία υποστήριξε, στην εποχή του αληθινού Καντ, με το χρήμα και την επιρροή της, τον Ευρωπαϊκό Διαφωτισμό. Στο τέλος του έργου, δεν είναι η επιτροπή του Πανεπιστημίου που περιμένει τον Καντ, αλλά το νοσηλευτικό προσωπικό ενός ψυχιατρικού νοσοκομείου.

Τι χρειαζόμαστε

Η παράσταση παρουσιάζεται για πρώτη φορά στην Ελλάδα και είναι μια συμπαραγωγή με το Θέατρο Τέχνης. Τα χρήματα που αναζητούμε θα καλύψουν μέρος της παραγωγής και των πνευματικών δικαιωμάτων του έργου.

Επειδή πλέον οι επιχορηγήσεις από το Υπουργείο Πολιτισμού έχουν καταργηθεί αναζητούμε άλλους τρόπους χρηματοδότησης για να κάνουμε εφικτό το ανέβασμα της παράστασης δοκιμάζοντας τη δυνατότητα που προσφέρει το crowfunding.

Αν θέλετε να συνεισφέρετε με όποιον άλλο τρόπο στη προσπάθειά μας, μπορείτε να στείλετε mail στο plirexousio@yahoo.gr ή μέσω facebook στη σελίδα giannos perlegas.

 ΣΥΝΤΕΛΕΣΤΕΣ


Μετάφραση: Γιάννος Περλέγκας και Ισμήνη Θεοδωροπούλου
Σκηνοθεσία: Γιάννος Περλέγκας
Σκηνικά -Κοστούμια - Κούκλες: Χριστίνα Κάλμπαρη και Βίλλυ Αττάρτ
Κατασκευές : Λεωνίδας Λαμπρινάκης
΄Κίνηση: Δήμητρα ευθυμιοπούλου
Μουσική: Κορνήλιος Σελαμσής
Φωτισμοί: Νίκος Βλασόπουλος
Βοηθοί σκηνοθέτη: Ερατώ Πίσση και Μαρία Γεωργιάδου

ΔΙΑΝΟΜΗ

Γιάννης Καπελέρης
Σύρμω Κεκέ
Κατερίνα Λυπηρίδου
Χρήστος Μαλάκης
Μάκης Παπαδημητρίου
Γιάννος Περλέγκας
Μιχάλης Τιτόπουλος
Δήμητρα Ευθυμιοπούλου
Τάσος Κορκός
Δανάη Λουκάκη
Άρης Ντελία

story:
About Us:

Fish2Fry Productions is a new production company founded in 2013 by Christian Martel and Aidan Black Allen. Fed up with waiting for the phone to ring, Fish2Fry aims to create meaningful film, tv and theatre work for the scores of talented established and up and coming artists in Toronto. 


'The Eagle With Two Heads' by Jean Cocteau is the passionate and tragic tale of a Queen falling in love with her would be assassin. Director Luke Gallo's vision of taking this piece and setting it in a dystopian future raises the personal and political stakes of the play even higher.

We have such a talented team of actors, designers, a director and a stage manager. The support from this campaign will allow us to stress a teeny bit less about the financial aspects of producing, and focus more on our true passion of telling stories.  

Christian and Aidan are financing this project entirely out of their own pockets- after hours of serving wings, 'teaching' children drama and French to English translations. Every dollar counts, so check out our AWESOME perks. And if you can't help financially, keep reading to find out other ways you can help!


What We Need and What You Get:

We are asking for $2,200, which is about 35% of our operational budget. Any amounts raised under our goal will go to the rights and TAPA membership and then split up accordingly for our other needs below.   This money is going to help us in SO many ways:


$900- Set Design. 
We have a beautiful space in the Pia Bouman Ballet School. The original play calls for the play to take place in a grandiose castle. Although our set will be much more conceptual, your funding will allow us to hire a carpenter and avoid (literally) cutting corners.

$700- Rights to the Play
Although in Canada plays become rights free once the playwright has been deceased 50 years, in France this number is 70 years. Your help will ensure that we are legally and ethically honouring the author and translator of this beautiful piece.

$300- Props and Costumes
We are fortunate enough to have a wide circle of artistic friends that we can reach out to and secure some of the props necessary for this production. Your support will make sure we have realistic props  
$300- TAPA Membership
Membership to the Toronto Alliance for the Performing Arts will not only add credence to our new company, it will also ensure that the play will be seen by Dora Awards judges and eligible for nominations. 

Our Perks:

We have amazing and unique perks to offer including: 
-Your very own Fish2Fry mug (destined to be a collectors item!)
- Complimentary tickets to the show and drink coupons (who doesn't like to drink at the theatre!)
- Signed poster from the whole creative team (Full of future Dora, Tony and Oscar winners!)
- 1 hour Improv Class taught by Aidan Black Allen (Second City Conservatory, Canadian Improv Showcase, Second City Longform Program, 'The Fame Show' Creator, 10 years experience teaching Improv across Canada) 
- Dinner for two created and cooked by your own personal chef Christian Martel. Or make it a party and he will come and cook for you and all your friends (Groups of 2 or more will need to help provide their own ingredients)
- KARMA and the indescribable pleasure of knowing you supported the arts in Toronto. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

We are determined to make this play happen no matter what. Thank you so much for taking the time to consider donating to our campaign. There are other ways you can get involved if you are unable to donate financially:
- We are looking for volunteer bartenders and front of house staff for one or more days during our show run (March 25th-29th). Please contact Aidan at fish2fryproductions@gmail.com if you are interested in donating your time.
- Spread the word! Please share this campaign on social media, 'like' us on Facebook  https://www.facebook.com/pages/Fish2Frÿ-Product... and of course make sure you come see the show in March.

story:
The Réjane Project's "To Live, Darling" springs forward! 

Well on its way to becoming a full-fledged show, "To Live, Darling," is ready for its next workshop (April 29 - May 11), which will focus on incorporating original music. We aim to integrate original songs written by Réjane's great-great granddaughter Adrien Reju. Through her music, Adrien will create a musical voice and themes for Réjane, giving her character even more depth. As always, your support can help make this show a success. Every dollar dramatically improves the overall quality of the show.

** THIS CAMPAIGN HAS RAISED AN ADDITIONAL $480, WHICH WAS DONATED DIRECTLY THROUGH FISCAL SPONSOR FRACTURED ATLAS. THANK YOU DONORS!! **

L'HISTOIRE

The Réjane Project was born when Ilana Turner – sitting in her friend’s living room – happened upon a Toulouse-Lautrec drawing and Boldini painting of the French actress Gabrielle Réjane. Réjane, it turned out, had birthed this friend’s mother. And so began the Réjane Project, which then begat the play “To Live, Darling.”

“To Live, Darling” incorporates original text, text from the plays that made Réjane famous in her time, and – after this next workshop – original music composed by Réjane’s great-great granddaughter Adrien Reju. European Director Christopher Sivertsen’s staging is developing from his lauded physical theatre style. “To Live, Darling” celebrates a woman who lived before her time both on–stage and off–, and whose reality frequently mirrored the (sometimes equally) groundbreaking characters she played on stage. 

Although Réjane’s story unfolded over a hundred years ago, many of this plays‘ themes are still familiar, embattled and entirely applicable today. As a working mother whose insatiable quest for artistic growth fed herself and the artistic and sociopolitical worlds around her, Réjane set a precedent for the world we know today. As Tina Fey said, “The life of a working parent is constantly saying 'This is impossible,' and then you keep doing it.” Réjane did it 125 years ago, and as she did, her life and work ultimately abandoned the grounded minutiae of naturalism for the detached simplicity of symbolism.

LE PRÉSENT

After five years of intensive research (in Paris and the US), two development periods, two workshops and inclusion in the staged-reading festival “Playwrights Express” by First Stage, “To Live, Darling” is ripe for full rehearsal and production. Art viaCorpora has already provided development support for “To Live, Darling.” The Réjane Project is currently in talks with a second Los Angeles theatre about further development and production. 

Said Rico Gagliano of the Dinner Party Download, "I saw scenes from 'To Live, Darling' at a showcase of new work, and was struck by its humor, intelligence and style -- kind of Howard Hawkes meets Moulin Rouge. Can't wait to see a full production that gets to play with the piece's ingenious backstage/frontstage structure."

LES CRÉATEURS

The Réjane Project creative team is:

Writer and Creator Ilana Turner 

Director Christopher Sivertsen

Musical Collaborator Adrien Reju

Dramaturg Tonia N. Sutherland

Between them the team has created original, transcendent physical theatre productions all over Europe; published articles in international magazines; performed leading and award-winning roles in film, TV and theatre; made several beloved records widely available on itunes; presented an academic paper based on Réjane research; and (almost) finished one apropos PhD in Archives and Performance. For more, please visit www.rejaneproject.com.

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

All funds donated to The Réjane Project will fund a Spring workshop in Los Angeles. Every dollar we raise means we are one step closer to having a complete show – rich in quality and high caliber talent – to present to live audiences moving forward.

Our goals are as bold as those of our inspiration! We've set a goal of $3000 by May 11th! (With another, more involved workshop slated for fall, our ultimate goal is actually $12k.) This goal will help us cover the following:

1. Travel costs – We could not be luckier to have international collaborators on our team, but the logistics of travel and board are not so lucky. (Miles are also welcome.) 

2. Rehearsal space – Physical theatre requires a reasonably high ceiling, a wooden or sprung floor, and space. These requirements limit our options, and hourly rental costs add up.

3. Artist fees – We respect actors’ and musicians’ skills, time, heart, and souls. They deserve to be paid for their work. Please help us do so!

4. Props and sets – These elements are minimal at this time, but they do exist. (They won’t stay minimal either.)

Private donations have made The Réjane Project possible. The Réjane Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of The Réjane Project must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law. No amount is too small – seriously.

WHY THIS SHOW IS IMPORTANT

In her day, Réjane was as famous as her colleague and friend Sarah Bernhardt. Réjane premiered works by the Goncourt brothers, Sardou and Meilhac & Halevy.  She also played Ibsen’s favorite Nora in the first French translation of "A Doll's House." Réjane later ran her own theatre (now the Théâtre de Paris) and toured the world. She was a mother, wife, divorcée, activist for women's rights, and Dreyfusard. Yet today, most people have heard of Sarah Bernhardt; almost no one remembers Réjane. 

Such remarkable women often slip through the cracks of history. Réjane made a significant contribution to theatre as we know it. Some consider La Belle Époque the "Golden Age" of theatre in Europe and the U.S. In this modern day and age, the arts are often the first programs cut from schools, and access to high caliber theatre can cost hundreds of dollars. Art itself thrives, inspires and teaches. Art heals. Art lives and breathes, and it must be cultivated and shown.

As First Lady Michelle Obama told us at this year's Oscars ceremony, "Every day through engagements in the arts our children learn to open their imaginations, to dream just a little bigger, and to strive everyday to reach their dreams."

 LE FUTUR

Our goal is to not only to create a living work of art that inspires generations of young artists to come, but to create a piece of theatre that is accessible to everyone. Once "To Live, Darling" becomes a full production, we can take it anywhere: across the US, to Canada, to Europe and beyond. This show is a chance to share a love of theatre, history, and to showcase the formidable talent of one woman – almost lost to modern scholars – who was truly ahead of her time.

By supporting The Réjane Project's "To Live, Darling," YOU become part of its creation, and that is truly priceless.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can't financially donate to The Réjane Project, you can help!

-Please, please share this link with people - every mention helps The Réjane Project be seen by more people. You can use the Indiegogo share tools.

- Like The Réjane Project and Réjane on Facebook. Follow us on twitter.

story:
'reasons to be pretty' is a labour of love. We are artists, working with artists, working for artists for the love of art. We need your support.

The cast and crew of this project are working hard to put up a piece of art that we hope you come out to support! Lady Shark Productions has taken on this play to give an opportunity to a young and vibrant cast. A cast that is willing to be in the trenches to deliver a show that is raw and exhilerating, chilling and true, touching and gripping. We are here to tell stories. Please help us to do so.

The obsession with physical beauty is confronted headlong in this brutal and exhilarating new play. In, 'reasons to be pretty', Greg's tight-knit social circle is thrown into turmoil when his offhanded remarks about a female coworker's pretty face (and his girlfriend's lack thereof) get back to said girlfriend. But that's just the beginning.

Greg's best buddy Kent, and Kent's wife Carly also enter into the picture and the emotional equation becomes exponentially more complicated. As their relationships crumble, the four friends are forced to confront a sea of deceit, infidelity and betrayed trust in their journey to answer the provocative question: How much is pretty worth?

Cast:
Alisha Bourassa
Taylor Bishop
Daniel Bates
Jessica Smith

Directed by: 
Hilary Marsh & Jamie Chrest

This production is for one weekend only!  

Lady Shark Productions is inviting you to be more than a number in a seat. Be part of this process. Be the reason that this play and this local, fiery little company is successful.

SUPPORT US TODAY!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise over $1500 in order to truly harness this piece of work.

Your money will go directly to the show that you see on the stage. It will help pay for the set, props and cast. You will see your donation at work before your very eyes!

 - If you donate $25 or more, you will receive a Lady Shark Productions', 'reasons to be pretty' official poster signed by the entire cast and crew.

- If you donate $100 or more, you will receive the signed poster (stated above) as well as be mentioned on the stage as an official sponsor of the show.

- If you donate $250 or more you will receive the benefits stated above as well as receive an official copy of the full script signed by the cast and a mention in social media of your contribution.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can donate as well as buy tickets to the show, you are AMAZING!


If you cannot come to the show, this is an even better reason for you to give. You can make this play a reality and show your support if you cannot physically be here to witness it. We love you!

Please tell your friends to support the show. Make it a night out!


For tickets, go to:
http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/340821
