story:
Short Summary

We are Next Reflex Dance Collective and are the creators of "en Route! a Touring Dance Project!  It is NRDC’s mission to create dance collaboratively with artists of all disciplines and to support the creation of experimental dance work. 

We have been touring "en Route!" since 2007 to various communities throughout Maryland, Virginia, and West Virginia.  The purpose of "en Route!" is to thread communities together through performances and outreach. Next Reflex Dance Collective works on a collaborative level with each community’s theaters and artists to produce a one or two night performance offering an array of accessible work targeting a new to dance audience. Such Collaboration builds local awareness and generates interest in the dance scenes in these locations.  Audiences are not only exposed to the work of their own local artists but also from artists of other communities who are involved in en route! that year.  In 2013, "en Route!" will tour to Richmond, VA & Baltimore, MD while also providing a home performance in Fairfax, VA.

Next Reflex Dance Collective is raising funds to go directly to the production expenses for "en Route" as well as paying the collaborating artists and their performers.  Although we have received some grant support from The Arts Council of Fairfax and The Virginia Commission for the Arts, we still need to raise a substantial amount of funds to enable this project to be a success.

As a contributor, you will help a program in which gives visibility to small organizations and independent artists in their own home community, as well as give them an opportunity to tour and connect with new audiences.  "en Route! a Touring Dance Project" will expand its boundaries even more this year by including artists of various dance genres from Flamenco to Indian to Jazz and modern dance.  We are excited to entertain and educate our audiences through these various dance styles that play such an important role on our society.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2,000 to completely fill in the gaps.  The funds go directly to paying for the rental of the theaters, technical staff, marketing, advertising, travel, artist pay, costuming, and videography.

We think $2,000 is a very manageable goal and along with our other planned fundraiser events, "en Route!" will be well on its way to Fairfax, Richmond and Baltimore with your support!

We have some exciting perks for those who donate: name recognition in the performance programs and on Next Reflex Dance Collective's website, special invitations to rehearsals, invitation to a post performance reception, free performance tickets, and more!

If we are not able to reach our goal, we will not receive all the contributions made!  The money that we do receive, will still go towards "en Route! a Touring Dance Project 2013".  

The Impact

en Route! a Touring Dance Project is valuable in that it offers exposure for small dance organizations and independent artists, gives them an opportunity to tour outside their own community when it would not otherwise be possible, and offers educational opportunities through accessible performances and classes for a general public.

"en Route!' has had major success in 2007-2010 in various communities throughout Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia.  We have collaborated with the most cutting edge artists and most of these artists re-apply each year to be part of this exciting project!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute at this time, there are other ways you can help! Ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.  You can also attend one of the "en Route!" performances!

We have some exciting perks for those who donate: name recognition in the performance programs and on Next Reflex Dance Collective's website, special invitations to rehearsals, invitation to a post performance reception, free performance tickets, and more!
If we are not able to reach our goal, we will not receive all the contributions made!  The money that we do receive, will still go towards "en Route! a Touring Dance Project 2013".  


The Impact
en Route! a Touring Dance Project is valuable in that it offers exposure for small dance organizations and independent artists, gives them an opportunity to tour outside their own community when it would not otherwise be possible, and offers educational opportunities through accessible performances and classes for a general public.
"en Route!' has had major success in 2007-2010 in various communities throughout Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia.  We have collaborated with the most cutting edge artists and most of these artists re-apply each year to be part of this exciting project!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute at this time, there are other ways you can help! Ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.  You can also attend one of the "en Route!" performances!

story:
Short Summary

Hub Performing Arts School was opened by Bob and Paula Chanda in 2007. It began as a summer musical theatre camp and has grown into something much larger, giving kids from Lubbock and surrounding areas a place to shine in acting, singing, and dancing. In Fall 2008 they formed their first Advanced Performance Team to compete at the Junior Theatre Festival. They were humbled that year to take home top 6 honors. Since then this by audition only Advanced Performance Team has served as a goal for members of the classes to strive for. It has given the kids opportunities to not only perform at community events, perform and learn in New York City, but also give back through bullying programs and mentoring actors at Lubbock's High Point Village.

This year Hub will be taking a team of 28 kids to the Junior Theatre Festival in Atlanta where they will perform 15 minutes from Schoolhouse Rock Live Jr. for adjudication. Many of these kids have not had the opportunity to attend before. Not only is their team critiqued on their 15 minute performance, the kids will also receive constructive feedback on ways to improve for the future. Awards are given out to teams and individuals who excel in many areas including spirit awards for positive attitudes and awards for community service. But in addition to feedback, awards, and the experience of seeing all the teams perform they also get to attend workshops to tighten their skills. Further, the kids have opportunities for fellowship with the kids from other teams where they can make new friends.

The Impact

The experience of the festival leaves the kids with a feeling of comradery with their teammates and other kids around the country that love performing. They realize the importance of each member to the team. They can bring back what they learned and share these skills with kids in the beginning theatre classes at Hub Performing Arts School. Just from being a member of the Advanced Performance Team kids are taught skills to make them better members of the community through community service and giving back. They also represent the Lubbock community spirit at the Junior Theatre Festival. Finally they also learn that it is just as important to shine in life as on stage! While the impact on these kids' lives is great, the desire is that they pay it forward to their community.

What We Need

The cost to attend the Junior Theatre Festival plus the cost of travel is expensive. The kids have done various fundraisers to help defray the cost of travel, but are trying to raise the final money to cover their attendance fees at the festival. Many of the team members are on scholarship and family members do not have the money to pay for the trip in the absence of this fundraising.

The cost to attend the festival is $165 per kid.

The team has 28 kids for a total of $4620.

In order to be able to reach our goal we are asking for $2500 toward these fees, but should we earn more it will also go toward these fees. 

Please see the perks you can get for your donation. But know that you are helping change a kid's life and hopefully have an impact on the community as well!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps, but if you can't spare the cash, there are other things you can do:

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Indiegogo has share tools that you can use on Facebook, Twitter and your other favorite social media outlets!
  • Spread the word!

Indiegogo has share tools that you can use on Facebook, Twitter and your other favorite social media outlets!
Spread the word!

story:
Who We Are

Edgy Women is the only feminist performance festival of its kind in the world. Based in Montreal, we have been pushing performative boundaries for the last 20 YEARS. For this anniversary edition, we are celebrating gender, art and athletics — and we need your help. 

Our grand finale on March 10th is EDGY LUCHA: a wrestling spectacle of intense proportion scripted by Belgian theatre artist Marijs Boulogne and involving half a dozen female québécois fighters. 

We want to know what might happen when you mix Belgian experimental performance art with female French Canadian pro-wrestlers...  

But it ain't cheap. 

The festival has covered promo and a venue rental, but to rent the ring and pay the artists we need an additional $3,500. 

Can you help? 

 

What We Need  

$3,500. This will help us enormously to cover the costs of running an independent festival as a not-for-profit and make this cultural output happen. 

It costs approximately $2,000 just to rent out our venue — the amazing Blue Cat Boxing Club in Montreal's Mile end — for a residency and performance. 

Hiring half a dozen wrestlers themselves, plus a referee and a half-time act, is another $1,500 minimum. 

Not to mention tech fees and set up/strike down... 

 

What You Get

What's in it for you? 

  • Cool perks! (see list). 
  • The satisfaction of knowing you are actively helping women kick ass. 
  • The priceless investment into the athletic and artistic development of a once-in-a-lifetime local happening.
  • Our eternal gratitutde.

 

The Impact

Female athletes (in any sport but especially in wrestling, mixed martial arts and fighting) are hardly ever given equitable financial or cultural support as their male counterparts. 

Think about it: 

  • the entire Canadian Women's Hockey League's annual budget is a fraction of the annual salary of one (mediocre) professional male player. 
  • when women's boxing was introduced in last summer's Olympics, the main debate was whether or not athletes should be made to wear skirts. 
  • 2013 is the year that — for the first time ever — the Ultimate Fighting Champion is including women in a female division. This historic fight takes place Feb. 23. 

Our festival aims to highlight and question this dispartiy, while also creating and transforming cultural spaces for our participants and spectators to push their artistic and athletic limits. 

 

Other Ways to Help

Please COME to our festival and BUY tickets! 

POST this page on your Facebook wall (and LIKE Edgy Women Fest while you're at it). FOLLOW us on Twitter to SHARE and RT the #EdgyWomenFest magic. READ our Blog for festival highlights! and TELL YOUR FRIENDS. 

DON'T FORGET the Indiegogo SHARE tools, too! And STAY TUNED for updates! 

... let's get ready to rumble. 

 

THANK YOU for your support. 

-Team Edgy Women.

story:
Peyton’s Story:

Peyton has had a natural talent for dance since she started at the age of four. We would watch in awe when she danced because all you could see was her amazing grace. Those adorable recitals still warm my heart. Peyton danced for several years at a wonderful recreational dance school in our area that helped her to identify and
understand her passion for dance.

It was one particular day that changed her course. Peyton was exiting a jazz class in mid-May and she told me that she needed to be challenged and she wanted to focus more on ballet because it is the foundation of it all. She was finding herself getting
frustrated more and more in class because she wanted more. Mind you Peyton was
eight going on nine at the time but Peyton was different. Peyton would say things to me at a very young age when leaving classes like, “Mommy, dance is an art and I find nothing funny about moving our hips!  I really don’t like when the other girls are
laughing at what we are doing.” She really wanted more and I listened…

In the summer of 2012 some major changes happened in our lives that put us closer to Saratoga Springs, NY.  This move opened up some options that would have otherwise not been available. We found the American Dance Center. Or I should say Peyton found the school/her Madame! When Peyton was given a few names of schools and the instructors she told me, the American Dance Center is the one. The transition of schools was really a magical experience. In so many ways it was meant to happen. Peyton had to meet with Madame Phyllis Latin and try out to get into the school. Madame saw the talent and passion. The immediate connection between them was beautiful and emotional. Madame assured her that if she started with her now that she will be dancing in a company around age 16, providing she is up for this journey and all that it will take of her. I think that is all Peyton needed to hear. She went into Madame’s SISP that summer and started dancing with The American Dance Center in September, 2012.


Peyton and Madame Phyllis Latin-2013 End of Year Showcase

Peyton has been putting her all into her dream ever since that wonderful day. She
dances 20 plus hours a week. Her week consists of many hours of pre-professional intensive ballet training as well as private lessons with Madame. She embraces her passion with her dreams right in front of her at all times. She sacrifices an awful lot and certainly does not lead the life of a typical 12 year old girl. Most social invitations get declined and if the timing happens to be somewhat right (hardly ever happens), she is often letting them know she will be late or leaving early. Peyton commits 100% of herself  knowing what she wants and not compromising or complaining even close to as much as a mother of a 12 year old would expect!

In addition to chasing her dreams she knows how important education is and
maintains a 4.33 GPA and is consistently on Principals Honor Roll. She was
chosen by the school this year to commit to one day a month to participate in the
peer network group. This group was put in place to support Autism.  She gets great joy out of this group!

Understanding that having an artistic balance is important! Peyton has been
playing piano since she was four and continues to take lessons once a week. Her
piano teacher understands her schedule and now Skypes with her to ensure she
gets her lesson in (I am forever grateful for this! Balancing Peyton's schedule
along with a very active 5 year old and a full time job is an amazing balancing
act!). Of course Peyton needs an escape and when she has had enough of it all,
you will find her lost in her sketch pad or painting. Needless to say she is an
ARTIST through and through!

Why put a Campaign Together?

Peyton was accepted into the 2014 Boston Ballet SDP which is a huge win for her and a big step towards her ultimate goal, The San Francisco Ballet Company! The Boston Summer Dance Program is $5380 for six weeks of training. Supporting my family on one income this has presented itself to be a big challenge. Peyton works very hard and has an amazing future ahead of her! These summer programs are an
essential part of a pre professional dancer’s future. We are turning to our network, family, friends, patrons of dance and the performing arts, and supporters of dreams!  With collective support you can help her take this first big step which is just the beginning of her amazing professional journey!

The Goal, $5380!

All the money earned through this campaign will go directly toward the tuition and housing for The Boston Ballet Summer Dance Program. It is a six week program, Monday through Friday, starting on June 29th through August 2nd.  The tuition with room and board is $2925 (tuition), $2400 (room & board), $55 (registration fee).  Total cost, $5380.  When she finishes this program she will have one week to rest and will then be going directly into The American Dance Center’s SISP.  This summer intensive runs for two consecutive weeks.  If she raises more than she needs it will go towards this two week SISP that costs, $950. 

Other Ways You Can Help!

We ask that you spread the word!  You would be amazed at how many lovely people among us love to support young talented artists like Peyton.  Tell your friends about Peyton and ask if they would like to help her reach her dream!  You can easily “share” that you donated by using the tools on this site.  Post the link on your Facebook, Instagram and/or Twitter! The next time you are at a ballet know that you are helping Peyton get on that stage to dance for the world!

The next time you are at a ballet know that you are helping Peyton get on that stage to dance for the world!

story:
Hello! 

Welcome to the official Indiegogo for The Phebe Project, an independent production of the play Ephebophilia, written by Dusty Wilson and directed by Clint Worthington.

THE PLAY

Ephebophilia follows a young couple, Imogen and Jackson, who are on the verge of losing their home in the midst of the 2008 housing crisis. In a desperate attempt to save their house from foreclosure, they decide to find, lure and extort money from unsuspecting sexual predators. Along the way, young Imogen, torn between her real and online identities, searches for the truth in her own relationships. Ephebophilia was a finalist in On the Brink Productions Search For the Next Great (Young) American Playwright, and was a finalist in Quiet Productions New Works Festival.

Ephebophilia is a fascinating new work that blurs the lines between reality and fantasy, as scenes wander seamlessly between the real world and the cold, alienating world of the Internet. Playing with themes of identity, truth and the influence of media on our lives, the characters of the play all search for ways to reconcile who they are with what they can do - a Lolita for the digital age. 

THE PRODUCTION

The story of bringing Ephebophilia to the stage has been a long and dramatic one. Having spent the past year or so in the pre-production stage with a previous theatre company (even going so far as to have actors cast, designers hired and a space reserved), the production was suddenly left without a home when, due to unforeseen circumstances, the company was forced to dissolve.

However, not being the type to let such unfortunate events stop us, the production team decided to keep going - we took over the reservation of our performance space (Collaboraction, at the Flat Iron Building in the Wicker Park neighborhood of Chicago) and chose to produce it independently under the name The Phebe Project. 

The world of producing independent theatre can be difficult; however, we believe so much in the strength of Dusty WIlson's evocative, compelling work, as well as the stellar talent we have both on and off stage, that we felt we could not stop now. With your help, we can make this production a reality.

THE CAST AND CREW

Cast:
Imogen - Claire Saxe
Jackson - Andrew Saenz
Alan - Arne Saupe
Imogen (u/s) - Tricia Rodriguez

Production Team:
Clint Worthington - Director
Julia Gray - Stage Manager

T. Paul Lowry - Scenic/Projection Designer
Sam Silva - Sound Designer
Emma Deane - Lighting Designer
Shawn Quinlan - Costume Designer

Jake Fruend - Graphic Designer
Imre Trevino - Videographer

Danielle Stack - Production Manager
Julia Rohed - Producer

WHAT WE NEED

We need to raise at least $7000 in order to make Ephebophilia possible. Below is a breakdown of where that money will go:

$4000 - Space Rental
$1500 - Set/Projection Equipment
$1000 - Actor/Designer Stipends
$500 - Costumes, Props, Lighting & Sound Equipment

WHERE TO FIND US

Like us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/thephebeproject

Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/thephebeproject

Follow us on Instagram @thephebeproject

Performing January 16th - February 9th, 2014
Thursdays-Saturdays 7:30PM
Sundays 3:30PM

Collaboraction (Room 300)
Flat Iron Building
1579 N Milwaukee Ave
Chicago, IL 60622

Please consider donating to The Phebe Project and help make this production that almost didn't happen, happen. 

Thanks!

The Phebe Project

story:
Hello everyone! My name is Trey Wright and I was born and raised in Louisville, KY. I am currently at 3rd year student in the process of receiving my BFA from the University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music (CCM). I was headed into my final summer before graduation and was looking for a way to put my feet in the water professionally, before it was time to move on with the career era of my life. With that, I decided to audition for the School at Steppenwolf Summer Intensive. This is a teen week residency at the renowned Steppenwolf theater of Chicago, studying with members of their ensemble. There I would be making awesome connections for the future, as well as receiving an even deeper education of the one I'm currently getting at UC. 

To make a long story short, I was fortunate to be accepted to their summer program and am hoping to go. There's only one small thing, as you all probably caught on. The tuition cost for the School at Steppenwolf is $4000. My goal is to raise 3000 as I want to be accountable for part of my way there and living expenses. The days last from 8-6:30 pm, which only allows for a weekend job. If I were able to go, I'd be there from Mid June-Mid August.

I know times are rough, that's why I'm asking for no donations larger than $5. If you wish to donate more, by all means you can. Whether financially or not, ANY kind of support is appreciated!!

Thank you everybody!!

Trey

I am currently at 3rd year student in the process of receiving my BFA from the University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music (CCM). I was headed into my final summer before graduation and was looking for a way to put my feet in the water professionally, before it was time to move on with the career era of my life. With that, I decided to audition for the School at Steppenwolf Summer Intensive. This is a teen week residency at the renowned Steppenwolf theater of Chicago, studying with members of their ensemble. There I would be making awesome connections for the future, as well as receiving an even deeper education of the one I'm currently getting at UC. To make a long story short, I was fortunate to be accepted to their summer program and am hoping to go. There's only one small thing, as you all probably caught on. The tuition cost for the School at Steppenwolf is $4000. My goal is to raise 3000 as I want to be accountable for part of my way there and living expenses. The days last from 8-6:30 pm, which only allows for a weekend job. If I were able to go, I'd be there from Mid June-Mid August.I know times are rough, that's why I'm asking for no donations larger than $5. If you wish to donate more, by all means you can. Whether financially or not, ANY kind of support is appreciated!!Thank you everybody!!Trey

story:
Inspired by the events surrounding the polarizing Jay Pollard espionage case, Martin Blank's original spy thriller The Law of Return depicts the actions of a notorious intelligence analyst abusing his level of access and threatening U.S. national security-or is he?

Whether driven by ideology or personal gain, Pollard, a United States Naval Intelligence analyst based in Suitland, Maryland, removes thousands of classified documents and turns them over to Israel. Once found out by the United States, Pollard leads police on a wild chase through D.C., desperately hoping to get to the Embassy of Israel and seek asylum. Why stage this play now?

On April 3, 2014 Jay Pollard was the number one trending topic on The New York Times website. President Obama is currently considering pardoning Pollard as part of a hotly debated Middle East peace deal. Pollard appears in The New York Times regularly alongside stories of WikiLeaks, the NSA, and Edward Snowden. What must be made public and what must be kept secret?

What We Need & What You Get

It takes a substantial amount of money to put on a show in the Big Apple, and this production is no different. We are fortunate to already have donors in place to cover the major costs of renting an Off-Broadway theater this August, rehearsal space, props, costume and set materials plus much more. However, it will take at least an additional $15,000 (plus) to help pay for the people who really matter: our amazing creative team! All the money you donate is tax deductible to the extent of the law and will go directly toward the salary for actors, stage manager, casting, designers, and director.

No gift is too small! In addition, your donations are tax deductible through the sponsorship of this production by Fractured Atlas. If you're not able to donate but want to support us, please spread the word about this campaign. Thanks!

About the Artists: 

Lanie Zipoy (Producer) Select credits include Mac Rogers' Universal Robots (2009 ITBA Best Off-Broadway Play), Laura Marks' Bethany (Associate Producer, Women's Project Theater) and Mari Brown’s 23 Feet in 12 Minutes (New Orleans and AFO Fest). She is co-founder of Voices Inside/Out, a prison theater exchange project. She is a Time Warner Foundation Fellow of the 2012-2014 Lab at Women's Project Theater, NYC.

Phil Newsom (Producer) Select NYC producing credits include Martin Blank’s Avenue of the Americas, the award-winning Musical Ten Reasons I Won’t Go Home With You (nominated, excellence in producing award, MITF), Super Sidekick the Musical “Best of FringeNYC 2012” and Aaron Kozak's award winning The Birthday Boys with ArtEffects Theatre Company, a company he co-founded in 2009 in NYC.

Martin Blank (Playwright) is the author of nine produced plays. His full-length drama The Law of Return, was produced at Maryland Ensemble Theatre, Center Stage, Jerusalem, and most recently at The Kennedy Center's Page-to-Stage. His new comedy Closing Time was recently seen at The Kennedy Center's Page-to-Stage and Play Club West. He is also Artistic Director for American Ensemble Theater and attended the University of Maryland and the Yale School of Drama.

Elise Thoron (Director) For over twenty years, Elise has created cross-cultural exchanges with Russian, Japanese, and American theater artists.  As Associate Artistic Director at American Place Theatre, she developed and directed many new plays, and co- founded Literature to Life, a theater literacy program, now nationwide.  At the Public Theater, she directed Tony award-winning poet Lemon’s County of Kings, which tours the world, and now his play ToasT. She is writing a new opera, Hatuey, with Frank London; her music theater pieces have been produced in the US and Europe.

Debra Bergsma Otte (Costume Design) is a professor of design and Coordinator for the Production and Design Program at Montclair State University. Her credits include design for regional, Off-Broadway and university productions, television, dance, puppet design for Henson Associates and industrial work. She has served on the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival National Committee and on the National Selection Team as well as Region II Chair and Design Chair. She is the recipient of two Kennedy Center Gold Medallions for her work in arts education. Her MFA is in Design for Stage and Screen from Tisch School of the Arts (NYU).

Theresa Evangelista (Graphic Design) is a graphic artist with more than 10 years of experience in book publishing and marketing design. She was born and raised in Queens, NY where she lives with her husband and their three goldfish.

Mary Spadoni (Stage Manager) New York: The Who & The What (LCT3) Loot, Volpone (Red Bull Theater), Good Person of Szechwan (The Foundry/The Public), Somewhere Fun (The Vineyard), Luther, Enfrascada, Dot (Clubbed Thumb), Map of Virtue (13P), Paradox of the Urban Cliché (LAByrinth), The Birthday Boys (ArtEffects), The Book of Grace (The Public). Regional: Avenue Q, Sylvia (Weathervane Theatre), Camelot, Emmet Otter (Goodspeed Musicals), A Raisin in the Sun, Great Falls, and Hedwig…Inch (Actors Theatre of Louisville). Mary is a graduate of St. Norbert College and a writer for www.piesetc.com.

 
Scenic Design: Alexis Distler

story:
Merci de soutenir le Théâtre I.N.K.!

Fondée en 2002, la compagnie crée et met en scène, pour les publics adolescent et adulte, des textes inédits tout en portant une attention particulière à l'intégration de l'image et du mouvement dans l'interprétation théâtrale. Cette compagnie montréalaise est dirigée par Annie Ranger et Marilyn Perreault.

Le Théâtre I.N.K. est reconnu comme organisme de charité et remettra des reçus pour les montants de 25$ et plus.

Vos dons serviront à soutenir notre prochaine création Lignedebus.

Résumé : Un autobus de ville avec, à son bord, une quarantaine de vies. Des passagers qui arrivent là avec passé, rêves et détresse aussi. Plusieurs vies, un seul point commun : ils étaient là. À ce moment-là. Une tragédie aux fils emmêlés qui a provoqué la consternation. 

«Certaines tragédies sont appelées à tort des accidents, de malheureux incidents.  Personne ne veut être un fait divers.» - Sandy

Inspirée par des conversations et des comportements typiques vus et entendus dans les transports en commun, l’auteure et metteure en scène, Marilyn Perreault, recrée l’autopsie d’un drame de la vie quotidienne dans une mise en scène aussi chorégraphiée que théâtrale.

Lignedebus sera présenté au Théâtre Aux Écuries du 4 au 22 février 2014 www.auxecuries.com

Texte et mise en scène : Marilyn Perreault

Avec : Victoria Diamond, Nora Guerch, Hubert Lemire, Marilyn Perreault, Annie Ranger, Hugues Sarra-Bournet et Victor Andrés Trelles Turgeon

Assistance à la mise en scène et régie : Clémence Doray

Décor : Patrice Charbonneau-Brunelle

Costumes : Elen Ewing

Éclairages : Martin Gagné

Musique : Michael Leon

Conception vidéo : Thierry Francis

Direction Technique : Jérémi Guilbault-Asselin

Œil extérieur : Éric Jean

Conseils dramaturgiques : Paul Lefebvre et Nadine Desrochers

story:
Someone recently once said to me me," You only have this one life. Don't waste it being unhappy. Don't live it without taking risks. Never be afraid to fail. Failure is just a stepping stone in the right direction to accomplishing your goals". I would love to apply that to my life. Which is why I am asking you all for you support.

Thank you all for taking the time to read this. I graduated almost 4 years ago and have been working as a professional Actor ever since. I've always known that I wanted to live in New York and I believe now is the time to do so. With the funds raised ,along with that I am saving, I am going to have enough that will allow me to rent a place in the city and give me time to acquire both a "Muggle" job and audition my soul out. All the money received will go towards moving expenses and that wonderful place I can call home.

   As we all know moving is not a cheap venture, especially into New York. With the $1200 I am trying to raise, along with personal savings, it will allow me to put down the deposit and first month's rent on a place within my budget in a safe area. But with all this talk about what I am looking for, I have almost forgotten about YOU! Along with my skills in acting I am fairly crafty with my hands as well. Everyone who helps me to achieve my goal will get a personal phone call (if you aren't anonymous) thanking you. The thanks will continue each level of contribution. You may get a wonderful handmade Thank you card as well, a song dedicated to you and etc.

   I know that was a bit to read, but I want to thank you all in advance. Moving to New York has always been a dream of mine and it's finally time to make that dream come true. I believe it is the next step in growing and honing my art. With all of the opportunities in New York, I feel that is the perfect place to continue working to become the best I can. I know that everyone cannot give, but you can always share! Share my link and let people know that you LOVE ME so much and that you want for them to help me.

story:
Downstage needs your help to launch a ticketing model that will help us bring new people to the theatre, offering an artistic experience that is exciting and directly relevant to their lives while creating more diverse and vibrant audiences. 

Read on to learn how you can help us make the shift!

Breaking Down Barriers

Downstage is a Calgary-based theatre company with a mandate to produce Canadian theatre that creates conversation around social issues. Over the last eleven years, we've created and produced numerous World Premiere plays centred around topics that are highly relevant to Calgarians. We're passionate about creating opportunities for social bridging through our work - connecting citizens with others who aren't like them to engage in vibrant discussions. 
We know that for our work to be truly impactful, we need to attract an audience that reflects the demographic diversity of our city. And we know we want to introduce new people to theatrical experiences that are going to be meaningful to them. But how?
Our research has shown that cost is the most significant barrier to attending professional theatre. This is for two main reasons:

  • Investment risk: If you've never seen a play and don't know what to expect, or even worse have only ever seen boring theatre that has nothing to do with your life, why would you spend your money on tickets? 

  • Real cost: 1 in 10 Calgarians live in poverty, with many others on the edge. Even discounted tickets can be out of reach for many.

Sure, in the past our tickets haven't been wildly expensive, maxing out at $25, and we've always offered discounted and free tickets to special groups, but it's time to create a more sustainable model. 


The Pay-It-Forward Ticketing Model

This new program is based on significant research with our audience and community partners who work with different demographic groups, and studying emerging best practices in other cities. 
This is what our Pay-It-Forward program will look like:
  • For all our future programming, a minimum of 25% of tickets will be available for free at the door, first-come, first served
  • The remaining tickets will be sold in advance at a modest price (e.g. $25)
  • Our ultimate goal is to be at a 50-50 split of free to paid tickets, but with some programming it will scale even higher (like with our current show, rihannaboi95, where 100% of tickets are free)
  • Audience members don't need to jump through any hoops to prove financial need and can use the program as often as they want
  • If they enjoy the show, they can 'pay-it-forward' by spreading the word to others and/or by making a financial gift towards the fund, allowing others to have an artistic experience

We know that we can make this model sustainable in the long term but we need a strong base to start from. That's where your gift comes in! 

Maybe you watched our free production of rihannaboi95 and want to pay-it-forward with a gift that feels in line with the value you got from the show, or maybe you have experienced our work in the past and want others to have the same opportunity. Either way, a donation at any level will be impactful and appreciated. 

We are looking to raise $6,000 to cover the core costs of offering rihannaboi95 for free in our current season as well as offsetting the cost of tickets for 25% of seats for a ten-show run of a World Premiere play in 2015-16; that way, all subsequent gifts made through the pay-it-forward program will give us the ability to continue the program in seasons to come. But let's not stop there - if we exceed our fundraising goal, we'll be that much closer to moving toward a 50-50 split!


Risks & Challenges

We know that simply making tickets free doesn't make them magically accessible to all. A large part of this program is sustained engagement with different community groups to get the word out to Calgarians who may be interested in the opportunity, as well as parallel work to remove other barriers (such as location, start times & childcare). However, we are confident that this program will go a long way towards allowing new people to access our work once they've heard about it and see the value to their own lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

We would be grateful if you would spread the word about this campaign to others who may be interested, either via social media, email or just chatting with friends. And between April 23 - May 2, 2015, be sure to check out our production of rihannaboi95, a livestreamed play presented online  - visit our website for more information.

story:
The Play

Winner of the Tony Award for Best Play and Olivier Award for Best Comedy, 'Art' begins by asking an age-­old question: ­ what IS art? After Serge pays a massive amount for a particular painting, he and his friends Marc and Ivan square off over the canvas, asking this very question. As their arguments become less theoretical and more personal, the conversation becomes filled with that which should never be said among friends.

About Theatre Coup d’Etat

Ivey Award­-winning Theatre Coup d’Etat maintains it's tradition of a minimal set and an actor­-driven production. Combined with the intimacy of the Club Room at Muse Event Center, Theatre Coup d’Etat’s production of 'Art' is another can’t-­miss experience.

Among the Coup d'Etat's hallmarks is introducing theatre to new venues, many of which have gone on to become consistently successful performance spaces for other theater companies as well as their own. These include the American Swedish Institute, where the company’s Ivey Award winning production of Hamlet was the first play performed. The critically acclaimed production of One Flea Spare at the Soap Factory Basement in 2014 opened another new and successful venue. In the summer of that year, the company brought Shakespeare to the south side of the Minnesota River, with their popular outdoor production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream at Kelley Park in Apple Valley. 

Theatre Coup d’Etat productions and performers are regularly featured in awards and “best-of” lists. These include:

  • 2013 Ivey Award for Best Director, Hamlet
  • 2014 “Years Best”, City Pages, One Flea Spare
  • 2014 “Best Show”, Lavender Magazine, One Flea Spare
  • 2014 Favorite Show, Cherry & Spoon, One Flea Spare 
Company members have received recognition for Extraordinary Performance 2010 (James Napoleon Stone and Peter Beard,Bent), Best Supporting Actor 2012 (James Napoleon Stone, Killer Joe), Classical Performance of the Year 2012 (Meri Golden,Romeo & Juliet), Best Classical Actress 2014 (Ellen Apel, One Flea Spare), and Best Supporting Actor 2014 (Brie Roland,Miss Julie). 

Theatre Coup d’Etat’s mission is to provoke an emotional and analytical response in our audiences by showing the depth of the human condition through both classical and contemporary works.

www.theatrecoupdetat.com

Performance Dates and Times

'Art' previews ­- free admission

March 25 and 26

showtime 7:30pm (doors 7:00pm)

'Art' performances - ­ $20

March 27, 28, 29, and 30

April 3, 4, 5, and 6

April 10 and 12, 13

April 17, 18, 19, and 20

showtime 7:30pm (doors 7:00pm)

Location

All performances held in the Club Room at Muse Event Center, located at 107 3rd Ave N, Minneapolis, MN 55401

What We Need

The purpose of this campaign is to help with costs of production. First and foremost are the artists' salaries: our actors, stage manager, costumer, and director. Coup d'Etat firmly believes that artists should be paid for their work, just like any other craft. The remaining costs include rehearsal space, production rights to the show, and marketing. Great projects are made possible by generous contributors like you!
story_txt:
The PlayWinner of the Tony Award for Best Play and Olivier Award for Best Comedy, 'Art' begins by asking an age-­old question: ­ what IS art? After Serge pays a massive amount for a particular painting, he and his friends Marc and Ivan square off over the canvas, asking this very question. As their arguments become less theoretical and more personal, the conversation becomes filled with that which should never be said among friends.About Theatre Coup d’EtatIvey Award­-winning Theatre Coup d’Etat maintains it's tradition of a minimal set and an actor­-driven production. Combined with the intimacy of the Club Room at Muse Event Center, Theatre Coup d’Etat’s production of 'Art' is another can’t-­miss experience.Among the Coup d'Etat's hallmarks is introducing theatre to new venues, many of which have gone on to become consistently successful performance spaces for other theater companies as well as their own. These include the American Swedish Institute, where the company’s Ivey Award winning production of Hamlet was the first play performed. The critically acclaimed production of One Flea Spare at the Soap Factory Basement in 2014 opened another new and successful venue. In the summer of that year, the company brought Shakespeare to the south side of the Minnesota River, with their popular outdoor production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream at Kelley Park in Apple Valley. Theatre Coup d’Etat productions and performers are regularly featured in awards and “best-of” lists. These include:
2013 Ivey Award for Best Director, Hamlet

2014 “Years Best”, City Pages, One Flea Spare

2014 “Best Show”, Lavender Magazine, One Flea Spare

2014 Favorite Show, Cherry & Spoon, One Flea Spare 
Company members have received recognition for Extraordinary Performance 2010 (James Napoleon Stone and Peter Beard,Bent), Best Supporting Actor 2012 (James Napoleon Stone, Killer Joe), Classical Performance of the Year 2012 (Meri Golden,Romeo & Juliet), Best Classical Actress 2014 (Ellen Apel, One Flea Spare), and Best Supporting Actor 2014 (Brie Roland,Miss Julie). Theatre Coup d’Etat’s mission is to provoke an emotional and analytical response in our audiences by showing the depth of the human condition through both classical and contemporary works.www.theatrecoupdetat.comPerformance Dates and Times'Art' previews ­- free admissionMarch 25 and 26showtime 7:30pm (doors 7:00pm)'Art' performances - ­ $20March 27, 28, 29, and 30April 3, 4, 5, and 6April 10 and 12, 13April 17, 18, 19, and 20showtime 7:30pm (doors 7:00pm)LocationAll performances held in the Club Room at Muse Event Center, located at 107 3rd Ave N, Minneapolis, MN 55401What We NeedThe purpose of this campaign is to help with costs of production. First and foremost are the artists' salaries: our actors, stage manager, costumer, and director. Coup d'Etat firmly believes that artists should be paid for their work, just like any other craft. The remaining costs include rehearsal space, production rights to the show, and marketing. Great projects are made possible by generous contributors like you!

story:
What is this?

This Minneapolis (MPLS) hosting a Backroom Shakespeare Project (BRSP).


I'm Allie Babich, a senior in the University of Minnesota/Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program and an honors student. In my thesis research, I'm investigating a 'grassroots Shakespeare' movement that's taking the American theater by storm. I've decided the best way to investigate this phenomenon is to throw myself into the fray and make a play with some U of M students and alumni and members of Chicago's Backroom Shakespeare Project, whose goal is to put Shakespeare back where he belongs: undirected and in a bar.


That's right: Serious actors. No director. One rehearsal. Shakespeare in a bar.


It's how Willie would have wanted it: rowdy, irreverent, alcohol-infused, and utterly exhilarating.


We'll be putting on Twelfth Night at 8PM on January 19th at the Republic in Seven Corners. Join us! It's going to be a grand olde time.


The show is free, the production is not.

The performance is absolutely free--that's part of the deal. It's Shakespeare for the people. He would have charged you a penny. We're even more generous; we'll let you in for free. BUT, it is costing us some money to make that happen.


While I'm thrilled beyond belief to be working with a crack team of artists from the Twin Cities and Chicago, there are some costs involved in bringing artists from the original BRSP up to Minneapolis and in their sharing of skills and methodologies. This is where we could use some help.

Since we're not asking for any money at the door, if you're planning on coming, please consider dropping a few dollars in this digital hat. Every little bit counts!


Why would you ever do this?

This project is, by nature, insane. And terrifying. But that's why we're doing it. 


We want to be as recklessly playful with it as we are deadly serious about it.

This is also an opportunity to welcome home some conquering heroes and alumni of the U of M, and to share their knowledge and accomplishments with their BFAmily and the entire Twin Cities theater community.

All of the artists involved in making this happen are classically trained. We know the rules, we understand that this is how most theaters operate these days. We're curious what happens when we break those rules. This is a chance for a group of brave (and/or foolhardy) actors to come together and experience Shakespeare as his own actors would have: sans director, sans big-budget sets and costumes, sans luxurious weeks of rehearsal. We just have the words and ourselves and each other, and you, dear audience. 


Broke?

Even if you can't contribute them dollars (if you're reading this, you're probably a student, an artist, or the parent of one of those scrappy entrepreneur/creators, and so you understand), support us by coming to the show! January 19th is the eve of the age of Aquarius, and whether we're destined for greatness or madness, it will be a night like nothing you've seen before.

story:
Who We Are



Whistlestop Theatre Company are a new and exciting company composed of young talent from throughout the U.K.

We are female-led and our primary objective is to create innovative, original, entertaining and above all accessible theatre, with a keen eye to immersion, interactivity and creativity on a shoestring budget. We keep it fresh and original through creative collaboration. We work as a company always, and although not specifically a devising company, we not only welcome, but depend on the input of the people we work with.

Through a constant process of adaptation we are able hone our skills and showcase the innovation and imagination of our company. We stick with the theme of retelling and reshaping classics for a modern audience in the hopes of bringing a new understanding of what classical theatre means today.

We also like to present a platform for new and emerging artists to practise their craft and always strive to work with the community in which we are performing. We tailor each play to the space we are performing in so our set really is the site.

Our aim is to entertain and excite, and we are passionate about integrating the audience into the theatrical experience and breaking down the old fourth wall. We believe many minds are greater than one, and it’s easier to carry props with multiple pairs of hands.

More info aplenty at:

www.whistlestoptheatre.co.uk


The Story So Far

Our premier production was a retelling and reshaping of a familiar classic with a twist, produced for a modern audience, Shakespeare's 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'. What started out as an idea grew into a full scale touring production that saw us perform in various London venues including The Old Red Lion Theatre, the Barons Court Theatre, The Courtyard Theatre as well as appearing at Secret Garden Party and Leefest. through the constant process of adaptation we were able hone our skills and showcase the innovation and imagination of our company.

After Midsummer the show and company blossomed and we continued with the theme of retelling classics after being commissioned by the Bussey Buidling to create and produce our second Shakespeare 'Twelfth Night, or What You Will.' although we are not specifically a Shakespeare company we relished the opportunity to sink our teeth into and adapt such powerful text. We were fortunate enough to get a transfer to the White Bear Theatre in august.

Our next stop on the Whistlestop tour was a collaboration with award-winning theatre company Rift that which saw us produce our very first piece of new writing as part of the Shakespeare in Shoreditch Festival, October 2014. the play in question is 'Bobby D', written by BBC writer in residence Sebastian Baczkiewiez. We were very excited to be a part of this incredible immersive theatre project.


What Do We Need

If we're totally honest we need a great deal more than £5,000 but it's a great starting point, We are trying to raise money to put ourselves in a position where, first and foremost, we can pay all our actors, artists, technicians, creatives and everyone in between a living wage. Raising funds also helps fund our publicity and marketing needs, insurance and legal fees and any education and outreach programs we are working on. All of this enables us to realize our bigger aim to produce more shows and make a bigger impact on our community.



Our Next Stop
We have some really exciting projects up our collective sleeve. We don't want to give too much away but in keeping with our company mantra we are developing a triptych. This will be an evening of three short plays all united by a common theme - the personal is political, and the political can be bawdy and risque. Expect an evening of excitement and irreverence with plays from Harold Pinter, Tennessee Williams and good ole William Shakespeare.


We will also shortly be announcing  our next feature length project coming in March, but for now, details are top secret.

Why Donate
Every little bit really does help and to show our appreciation of your generosity we are offering some great perks, from complimentary tickets to our productions, cast meet and greets, signed copies of our production posters and advertisements for you/your company. And of course our eternal love and thanks.
We are at a crucial time as a growing company and your support is more important now than ever before, so that we can continue to create exciting and relevant theatre that supports  young artists and enriches our community.
Even if you can't donate you can still help us out by sharing this page, visiting our website, liking us on Facebook, or following us on Twitter. Each share, like or tweet helps us to expand our theatrical horizons.
A massive thank you in advance from everyone at team Whistlestop.

story:
The Wedding Day From Hell

We've all been intimately involved in a large scale social occasion such as an important birthday, an ancient marriage anniversary or, of course, a wedding. For some, a day of untold happiness, for others: a chronically-stressful, prosecco-infused, suit-bearing, bride-pushing, taxi-wrestling Olympic game of blind-folded tight-rope walking. Of course, in a one-act chamber musical comedy, which would you rather see characters singing and dancing about?

 

The Proposal

So assuming, like us, you chose the latter of the two, may we proudly present Confessions of an Ex-Drag Queen; hilarious new musical comedy about the highs and lows of the tying of the knot. We find ourselves in the picturesque morning of a seemingly picturesque wedding, as Spencer and Denise are about to swear their lifelong commitment to one another. The only issue is, Spencer, the groom, is nowhere to be found a mere four hours before the wedding is due to start. Naturally, Denise does the only sensible thing, which is to panic and resort to the various alcoholic wedding gifts, leaving Kristen, best woman to Spencer, to deal with the situation. Searching for clues as to where Spencer might have fled to, Kristen, through a steaming hangover the night before, stumbles across Spencer's memoir, entitled "Professional Confessional" and begins a journey through Spencer's dubious past.

An outrageously funny book, a catchy score and a ridiculously fun show are what we would like to share with you. An intimate chamber piece, in which Kristen stumbles across a number of hilarious and dubious characters, with their interesting contributions to Spencer's former drag career. A hilarious new musical, with song and comedy and most importantly, plenty of heart.

 

The Love Story

Confessions began as an idea for a one-performer show, which was shelved due to the lack of time to fully develop the idea. A few years later, when looking for a project to follow up from A Little Bit of Life, Glitter Theatrical's 5 Star Reviewed Debut Production, Confessions came to attention again. Using the premise of someone going missing on their wedding day and a series of confessions, the idea was re-developed to become a three-hander with intimate venues in mind.

 

The Guests

THE CREATIVES

Mikolaj Chrobot
Director & Producer

Lukas McCabe
Composer & Producer

Jack Stone
Bookwriter & Lyricist

 

THE CAST

Kristen (The Best Woman)
To Be Announced

Denise (The Bride)
To Be Announced

Spencer (The Groom)
To Be Announced

 

 

The Ceremony

Where will Confessions be tying the knot? The Chapel Playhouse near London's Kings Cross Station is one of London's newest and most exciting fringe theatres underneath the Chapel Bar and Cafe. Confessions will be tying the knot at 2:00 and 7:00 on Saturday 16th November and Sunday 17th November with tickets to the big day(s) already on sale.

 

Help us to Help You

London has a varied portfolio of theatre available today, from musicals about problems being solved through the magic of pies to plays about dark forces in a magic world and hip-hop government officials to the happiest woman on earth (Mary Poppins). London's fringe theatre circuit is one of the fastest-growing genres of contemporary theatre and an exciting place to be a part of. Confessions of an Ex-Drag Queen is one of the latest additions to the fringe scene in London, offering a fun evening out for audience members all for a fraction of the cost of a West-End Production. Join us in this pursuit and help us make this show the best it possibly can be, all whilst having your name attached to it.

 

The Party Favours

All of the perks for this crowdfunding campaign are in some way exclusive to IndieGoGo and will be available to our generous donators who helped make the production exclusively or with exclusive features. By donating to the production, you are automatically mentioned in the programme under our Donators section, unless you opt. specifically not to be mentioned. All physical perks included on this crowd funder can either be shipped or given to you at the performance.

 

Happily Ever After

What is the plan after the run at the Chapel Playhouse you ask? That, interweb chums, is a very good question. One plan that is for certain following the initial run is to prepare the show for amateur and professional licensing, which will be set up on the Glitter Theatrical Website shortly following the New Year. Future Productions by Glitter will be planned as we go along, however this show will act more as the first step in a long line of future productions by Glitter, some of which we've already got dates set on. So long story short, your donations and support will not only be in the devleopment of Confessions, but in the development of Glitter Theatrical as a company.

 

Questions, Suggestions, Confessions?

If you'd like to get in touch with us about anything that you're unsure of, curious about or would like to confess, you can do so in a number of ways:

Social Media:
We are social media maniacs and love connecting with people through our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and LinkedIn pages. Simply search "Glitter Theatrical" and click on the account that shows our Glittery Logo and smashing promotion of Confessions.

Letters:
We love a letter. One of the few traditional methods of communication besides talking face to face. If you'd like to send a mail of any description (within reason), please send to:

Lukas McCabe
Glitter Theatrical
Unit 18532
PO Box 6945
London
W1A 6US

Email:
Emails are, arguably, the fanciest way of communicating these days. There's nothing quite like sending an email, with correct email etiquette and then receiving a response. If you'd like to send an email, please send it to:
lukas@glittertheatrical.co.uk

Unfortunately, these are all the means of communications we have at present.
We're very open to questions about the production!!

 

Thank you for taking the time to read and consider our pitch, we hope to see you at the World Premiere of Confessions of an Ex-Drag Queen.

For more information:

www.glittertheatrical.co.uk/confessions

story:
What is Shakespeare in Detroit?

Shakespeare in Detroit is the premiere classical theatre company in Detroit, Mich. for the past 7 seasons, having pioneered the first park performance of the Bard in the city proper. 

Our work currently serves our community in three ways:

  • Shakespeare STEAM - we collaborate with educators in Detroit to introduce the Science of lighting a production, the Technology of sound design, the Engineering of a form or costume, the Art of classical performance and the Mathematics of building a set to 3rd through 12th graders. 
  • We produce free, outdoor productions so that everyone, no matter their socio-economic status, can enjoy professional theatre. 
  • SiD produces site-specific performances, celebrating the rich history of Detroit in historical venues throughout the city. 

 

This campaign supports our STEAM prorgramming with students during the 2019-20 academic year. This work is already happening at three schools and we are asking for your support to help us make the next semester, beginnining in January 2020, a success. 

Our founder was a Detroit Public School student from kindergarten to high school graduation, and she was introduced to Shakespeare at 8 years old by her mother (hence the program beginning with 3rd grade), which is why this project is so close to our hearts. Our work is currently taking place at Boggs School, Clippert Academy and the Detroit School of Arts. And we will work with the students at the new Detroit Public School, The School at Marygrove, this upcoming winter semester. 

The 3rd to 8th graders are participating in a series of workshops to connect their understanding of, for example, how lights work in a show: if you mix red and blue lights, they will appear as purple onstage. Another example of these workshops include using building blocks to assess weight, placement and measurements to build a "Capulet house" and a "Montague house" so that there is a basic understanding of how a set is built for a play. 

The high school students are creating a full, onstage production of Romeo & Juliet, which the younger students will come to DSA to enjoy. 

What We Need & What You Get

The funding will help us match a corporate gift of $7500, helping us raise a total of $15,000 to help us buy supplies such as building the set for Romeo & Juliet at The School at Marygrove as well as paying for scripts, copies of The Complete Works and compensating the teaching artists who will work with students to direct the show. 

You get cool perks when you support! We get a lot of requests for SiD swag like t-shirts or hoodies, WELL, HERE'S YOUR CHANCE to get these items, just in time for the cold winter season. 

If we don't make our goal, the funds still go to Shakespeare STEAM. Perhaps, for example, the balcony for Romeo & Juliet won't be as grand as we want it to be, but the program will go on! 

The Impact

Shakespeare STEAM is a new way of thinking about theatre. We don't know of any other educational opportunities like this one in the state of Michigan. And we are considering this 2019-20 academic year, which is currently live and happening, to be our pilot and we look forward to sharing the results of this inaugural year with the public in June 2020. 

There are approximately 125 students enrolled in the program, the majority are in 4th and 5th grades. 

Risks & Challenges

The risks include if we don't get enough funding, this may be the pilot, and only, academic year for our work. It is our goal to create educational experiences similar to the premiere arts education of surrounding suburbs and that requires covering costs such as teaching artists/talent, supplies for our STEAM stations where students used applied practice to learn ALL the elements of theater, not just the A. 

The challenge is that there has never been a program like this before, to our knowledge, in Detroit schools. The learning curb for the city, schools, our artists and the students is a large one that requires the right people to nurture and develop. This again, requires the proper funding so we can continue to hire the right people to help make #ShakespeareSTEAM a success for years to come. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give to this campaign, there are a couple of other ways you can help:

  • Volunteer for our upcoming 2020 season as an usher or member of Team SiD
  • Share our campagin with all of your friends on Facebook and Twitter

Thank you for supporting #ShakespeareSTEAM!
story_txt:
What is Shakespeare in Detroit?
Shakespeare in Detroit is the premiere classical theatre company in Detroit, Mich. for the past 7 seasons, having pioneered the first park performance of the Bard in the city proper. 
Our work currently serves our community in three ways:


Shakespeare STEAM - we collaborate with educators in Detroit to introduce the Science of lighting a production, the Technology of sound design, the Engineering of a form or costume, the Art of classical performance and the Mathematics of building a set to 3rd through 12th graders. 
We produce free, outdoor productions so that everyone, no matter their socio-economic status, can enjoy professional theatre. 
SiD produces site-specific performances, celebrating the rich history of Detroit in historical venues throughout the city. 

 
This campaign supports our STEAM prorgramming with students during the 2019-20 academic year. This work is already happening at three schools and we are asking for your support to help us make the next semester, beginnining in January 2020, a success. 
Our founder was a Detroit Public School student from kindergarten to high school graduation, and she was introduced to Shakespeare at 8 years old by her mother (hence the program beginning with 3rd grade), which is why this project is so close to our hearts. Our work is currently taking place at Boggs School, Clippert Academy and the Detroit School of Arts. And we will work with the students at the new Detroit Public School, The School at Marygrove, this upcoming winter semester. 
The 3rd to 8th graders are participating in a series of workshops to connect their understanding of, for example, how lights work in a show: if you mix red and blue lights, they will appear as purple onstage. Another example of these workshops include using building blocks to assess weight, placement and measurements to build a "Capulet house" and a "Montague house" so that there is a basic understanding of how a set is built for a play. 
The high school students are creating a full, onstage production of Romeo & Juliet, which the younger students will come to DSA to enjoy. 

What We Need & What You Get
The funding will help us match a corporate gift of $7500, helping us raise a total of $15,000 to help us buy supplies such as building the set for Romeo & Juliet at The School at Marygrove as well as paying for scripts, copies of The Complete Works and compensating the teaching artists who will work with students to direct the show. 
You get cool perks when you support! We get a lot of requests for SiD swag like t-shirts or hoodies, WELL, HERE'S YOUR CHANCE to get these items, just in time for the cold winter season. 
If we don't make our goal, the funds still go to Shakespeare STEAM. Perhaps, for example, the balcony for Romeo & Juliet won't be as grand as we want it to be, but the program will go on! 

The Impact
Shakespeare STEAM is a new way of thinking about theatre. We don't know of any other educational opportunities like this one in the state of Michigan. And we are considering this 2019-20 academic year, which is currently live and happening, to be our pilot and we look forward to sharing the results of this inaugural year with the public in June 2020. 
There are approximately 125 students enrolled in the program, the majority are in 4th and 5th grades. 

Risks & Challenges
The risks include if we don't get enough funding, this may be the pilot, and only, academic year for our work. It is our goal to create educational experiences similar to the premiere arts education of surrounding suburbs and that requires covering costs such as teaching artists/talent, supplies for our STEAM stations where students used applied practice to learn ALL the elements of theater, not just the A. 
The challenge is that there has never been a program like this before, to our knowledge, in Detroit schools. The learning curb for the city, schools, our artists and the students is a large one that requires the right people to nurture and develop. This again, requires the proper funding so we can continue to hire the right people to help make #ShakespeareSTEAM a success for years to come. 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't give to this campaign, there are a couple of other ways you can help:

Volunteer for our upcoming 2020 season as an usher or member of Team SiD
Share our campagin with all of your friends on Facebook and Twitter

Thank you for supporting #ShakespeareSTEAM!

story:
Our Story

Good Women will be producing a self presented showcase of dance from December 1-3, 2011. We will be showcasing our own choreographic works along with two other artists from the community. Because the Edmonton Dance Community is small as self presented event is crucial to the development of artists work and also the growth of our community. This will be Good Women's first independently produced formal evening of dance.
Good Women has been active in all areas of the community, from performing, to volunteering, to public education and to providing opportunities to other artists in Edmonton. The Good Women workshop series are workshops that allow local dancers to experience a teaching style or choreographic style that is not currently being explored in the city. 
GWDS provides opportunities for artists working in the city with the second annual “What’s Cooking?” event. It takes place on April 29th 2011 (widely celebrated as International Dance Day). This event consists of an evening in which artists could present works in progress to a public audience in a friendly, informal environment. Artists also had the opportunity to receive feedback directly from audience members and other artists. It was a very successful on a number of levels and we hope to recreate these works in a finished and formal setting for December 2011

Our first "What's Cooking?" event in 2010

As well as providing a buffet style dinner, audience members were treated to the works of eleven different Edmonton based artists. Audience members were given a written survey for feedback, as well as the chance to dialog with each artist after their work in process was showcased.  This proved to be one of the most successful ventures Good Women Dance Society has taken on to date. The response from both the artistic community and general public was overwhelming, needless to say, the event was sold to capacity. Developing this relationship with the audience is a huge focus for our collective, and also provides a great way for us, and emerging group, to build an audience. The society has concluded that ‘What’s cooking?’ will be an annual, if not semi annual event. We wish to also have some of these local works further developed and presented in a formal setting, giving the audience an opportunity to see their feedback developed and integrated in the work. It is now time to takes this event to the next level!

The Impact

In addition to benefiting the community, having a self presented show in our season would directly benefit the Good Women Dance Society. The reasons for this are numerous.  As stated in Good Women’s mandate, it is our goal to produce innovative and exciting choreographic works with integrity and conviction. 
Collective artists have struggled with having to perform in theatres that- while they may be fine for other art forms to perform in- are not suitable for a dance performance.  By self-presenting a show we would ensure that all of these factors would be at an acceptable -if not ideal- level. We have selected the Westbury Theatre as a performance venue and it provides sprung floors, lots of space, a raked seating arrangement to allow for optimal sight lines, and better lighting equipment. With these factors in our control Good Women and the other artists will be able to perform their best and our work will look professional.
The result of this project will be a full evening of professional level contemporary dance that showcases local artists performing innovative and relevant choreography. The show that Good Women will present is an opportunity for the collective artists as well as members in the community to push themselves to create work that can stand on it’s own and gain recognition outside of the local festival circuit. It will also be a chance for artists to create work under ideal circumstances in which elements such as rehearsal and performance space, lighting design, mentorship, and deadlines will be under their control.  This level of control will allow choreographers and performers to improve their artistic abilities and create dance that stretches beyond what has been possible in the past. All of this will ensure that we are creating dances of the best quality.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to secure funds in order to produce this show. In order to pay for the venue, technicians and marketing we need to raise at least $5000. This is even without paying any of the dance artists involved. Without this income the project will not be able to go ahead. Our collective is small, only one year old so we do not have a pool of income to dip into. We would love to support the community by offering this performance opportunity to other movement artists and believe it is important to start producing our own shows as an organization but we need your help!


Other Ways You Can Help

Visit our website www.goodwomen.ca
like our facebook page "Good Women" http://www.facebook.com/pages/Good-Women/129045...
spread the word and support local dance!

story:
UPDATE 8/23/2011

Thank you so much to all of our donors!!! WE HAVE REACHED OUR FUNDING GOAL!!! This production would not have been possible without your generous support.

If you still want to donate, it's not too late! Wars & Whores will be in the Fringe and beyond and any further donations will be put toward the following:

-Cast Recording
-Future Show Development,
-Improved Sound Equipment

Thanks again for all your help! We hope to see you in a few weeks!!

(Note: You can still watch the original video [with more song previews from the musical] right here.)

UPDATE 8/12/2011

Thank you to everyone who has contributed to Wars & Whores! Your generous support goes a long way to making our production possible. In just a few short weeks, we have almost reached our fund-raising goal of $3500! With only a few hundred dollars more, we will be able to present a performance unlike any you've seen before. Many thanks to all our financial contributors and all those who support us professionally and emotionally. Thank you!

Our Story

Welcome to the Underground Shakespeare Company's indiegogo campaign for our production of Wars & Whores: The Henry IV Musical! Wars & Whores is an original musical collaboration based on Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I and will be presented as a world premiere at the 2011 Philly Fringe!


The Underground Shakespeare Company was founded at the University of Pennsylvania, and since its creation ten years ago, has been devoted to bringing quality Shakespeare-related performances to the university and the West Philadelphia community. The company has had an exciting year with the celebration of its tenth anniversary, and now with its first original and professional production: Wars & Whores!


You never knew Shakespeare was all about the hootenanny. This raucous original new musical presents the Bard’s classic tale of a prince’s coming-of-age as it was intended--with all the foot-stomping, harmonica-blowing, acoustic-throwdown tunes your boxcar-riding bones can handle. And yes, whores.


We've begun this campaign because we are starting from scratch! Our company members have written and composed the show and will be acting, directing, and committing a major portion of their non-existent free time to this production. We've incorporated local and out-of-town artists to bring you the best production of our show we  can present. We're all here because we love theatre and are committed to reaching as many people as we can with our energetic take on a treasured classic.


With this campaign, we are hoping to raise $3500 to get our production off the ground and to hopefully continue to bring the Philadelphia more original and reinterpreted Renaissance works! Your tax deductible contribution to our fundraising project will help cover the following costs outlined in this rough budget:


Performance and rehearsal space ~$1300


Physical Production including set, sound, and lighting ~$1000


Publicity and Marketing ~$500


Transportation Expenses ~$1000


Fringe Festival Requirements ~$300


As you can see, your contribution is vital to the success of our project, and any money we receive goes straight into the development of our show rather than anyone's pocket.


Any and all contributions are appreciated. For donations of $1 or more, we provide benefits and prizes, including posters, mugs, free tickets, personalized songs, artistic lessons, and much more! Check out the cast and crew to see if you already know some of the artists involved with Wars & Whores!


Cast: Ron Bopst*, Thomas Crawford, Eric Johnson*, Zane Johnston, David Kurnov, Gary Kurnov, Sarah Levine, and Jesse Tendler

Band Members: Jeffrey Barg, Jim Jordan, and Byron Kho

Director: Benjamin Kamine

Assistant Director: Sean Leo

Fight Director: Peterson Townsend

Composer and Lyricist: Jeffrey Barg

Book Adapter: Sarah Ollove

Stage Manager: Monica Valentin

Costume Designer: K. Moriah Smith

Lighting Designer: Charles Foster

Consultant: Miriam White

Producers: Chris Bresky* & Megan Edelman


*Member of Actors Equity Association

The show has been developed and rehearsals are in full-swing! All we need now is your generous support! And whether or not you can contribute financially, we would love to see you at our show. All performances are at the beautiful and rarely-seen Sanctuary of the Rotunda (4014 Walnut Street), conveniently located in University City! Tickets can be purchased on the web here: http://ticketing.theatrealliance.org/sites/live...


Performance dates and times are as follows:


Friday, September 9th at 7PM

Saturday, September 10th at 2PM

Saturday, September 10th at 7PM

Sunday, September 11th at 2PM


Thank you for your support!


The Underground Shakespeare Company is resident at and sponsored by Rodin College House.
